Marie -07 fair; San Antonio 41 drizzle. -West: Albuquerque 15 fair; Anchorage 12 fair; Boise 13 snow; Casper 17 windy; Fairbanks -21 fair; Great Falls 28 windy; Honolulu 73 fair; Las Vegas 30 fair; Los Angeles 52 fair; Medford 25 foggy; Pendleton 39 cloudy; Phoenix 39 fair; Portland, Ore. 37 foggy; Reno 09 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 10 foggy; San Diego 48 fair; San Francisco 40 fair; Seattle 39 rain; Spokane 25 snow. -International: Calgary 28 windy; Montreal 07 partly cloudy; Ottawa 01 partly cloudy; Regina 09 snow; Toronto 07 fair; Winnipeg -01 windy; San Juan 73 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Official Says War Inevitable to Force Iraqi Withdrawal
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's exiled foreign minister said today that he believes it is too late for peace initiatives and that war is thus inevitable in the Persian Gulf. ``The whole world has given enough time for a peaceful settlement of the gulf crisis,'' Sheik Sabah Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah told a news conference. He and Kuwait's ousted emir, Sheik Jaber Al-Sabah, arrived Wednesday for a three-day visit. Chinese President Yang Shangkun told the emir on Wednesday that before considering war the international community should first exert more economic and diplomatic pressure on Iraq, the official Xinhua News Agency said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing wa asked at a news conference today what new sanctions China would suggest, but was unable to name any. He simply reiterated his government's position that ``unremitting efforts'' should be made for peace. A militarily enforced U.N. embargo imposed after President Saddam Hussein seied Kuwait on Aug. 2 has halted virtually all trade with Iraq, which had been heavily dependent on imports, but has failed to persuade Saddam to back down. Saddam faces a U.N.-imposed deadline to withdraw by Jan. 15 or face possible attack. The Kuwaiti foreign minister said he had not heard of any Chinese peace initiatives, but he maintained that only military force would dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. ``Whether by the Arab world, whether by the friendly countries, whether by the Third World countries, or by the big powers, it is very late for such (peace) initiatives. It would not be useful,'' he said. The foreign minister said Yang told the emir China would continue to press for an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal. The Kuwaiti foreign minister said the emir came to thank Chinese officials for their support in international efforts to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait. He said Kuwaiti leaders appreciate China's position on the gulf crisis, even though it refused to back the United Nation's authorization of the use of force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. China abstained in the vote on the U.N. Security Council resolution last month, but supported all previous U.N. measures seeking to pressure Saddam into withdrawal. The Kuwaiti emir ends his three-day China visit on Friday and will return to exile in Taif, Saudi Arabia, Kuwaiti officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Trams Defy Obsolescence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Seems the ... Belgian streetcars' to CORRECT to Bucharest. Picks up 5th, `On the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Who wants to buy a bunch of Belgian stretcars that have been around for 25 to 30 years? At least three major European cities. The prospect was problematic for Belgian foreign trade officials. Seems the streetcars are practically indestructible. The foreign cities that buy them - Bucharest, The Hague, and Marseille are interested - will be lost markets for new Belgian streetcars. On the other hand, there's pride at stake. The ``Societe des Transports Intercommunaux de Bruxelles'' (STIB), which owns the cars, recalls that it sold some of its old streetcars to Cairo, which later resold them to Copenhagen. And 40-year-old Belgian trolleys are still running in the streets of Asuncion, Paraguay. The cars' owner said Wednesday that it has offers from those three major European cities for 92 old trolleys, and would like to sell at least 50 at $50,000 apiece. That will make for more room in jammed depots, for one. The company has 48 new trolleys on order - from Belgian firms, of course - for $100 million. STIB says Bucharest wants to reuse the old streetcars, Marseille is mainly interested in their bogies, the same as those on its own cars, and The Hague wants them for spare parts. The company gave up the idea of modernizing the old cars. That would cost more than new streetcars.

DOC.HEAD: Transformer Explodes in Lower Manhattan
DOC.TEXT: A transformer exploded in Manhattan's Financial District today, sending flames eight stories high and possibly spewing hazardous PCBs on seven floors of a skyscraper, officials said. Twenty-six firefighters and 14 others were treated for possible exposure to the carcinogenic polychlorinated biphenyls, said Lt. Jim Powell, a Fire Department spokesman. The transformer exploded just after 12:30 a.m., Powell said. The resulting blaze blew out windows in the fifth, sixth and seventh floors of a nearby building and caused a small fire in the second floor, he said. The fire was under control at 3:16 a.m. Officials from the Department of Environmental Protection were on the scene, he said, and samples from the building were taken to the department's chemical lab for analysis. Of the 26 firefighters treated for possible PCB contamination, four were hospitalized, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says 10 Rebels Killed in Suicide Attempt on Army
DOC.TEXT: Helicopter gunships killed 10 Tamil rebels who attempted a suicide attack on an army camp in tractors loaded with explosives, government officials said today. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said Wednesday's operation was the third suicide attempt on the Elephant Pass camp in the past week. Wijeratne, who is in charge of the government campaign against the Tamil Tiger rebels, said that in each case the attack was foiled by helicopter gunships. ``Troops in helicopter gunships Wednesday killed a large number of rebels when they destroyed some vehicles loaded with explosives and being driven into the Elephant Pass camp,'' Wijeratne said at the weekly Cabinet briefing. He did not give details of the previous attempts. Military officials said 10 Tigers were killed in the attack Wednesday. They said the helicopters fired on the Tigers while they were driving four tractors and a jeep into the Elephant Pass camp. The camp, 180 miles northeast of Colombo, guards one of the main entrances to the Tiger-controlled Jaffna Peninsula. There was no confirmation of the report from the remote area or from the Tigers, who seldom disclose casualties or details of their operations. Five other Tamil Tigers were shot and killed by government troops in two other encounters in northern Sri Lankan on Wednesday, the military officials said, speaking as usual on condition of anonymity. The rebels launched the war for a separate Tamil homeland in 1983, accusing the Sinahlese-controlled government of discriminating against the Tamil minority. More than 14,000 people have been killed since then. Wijeratne said he was unaware of a Tiger truce offer to mark the new year. Sathasivam Krishnakumar, a London-based leader of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, said in a Christmas Day telephone interview the Tigers would offer a unilateral cease-fire starting Dec. 31 and lasting two or three days. The latest battles between the government and the Tigers started six months ago when the rebels broke a 13-month-old cease-fire, overran police stations and massacred hundreds of police officers. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, have long complained of discrimination by Sinhalese in jobs, the economy and use of the Sinhala language. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population and have controlled the government since the Indian Ocean island became independent from Britain in 1948.

DOC.HEAD: One Wounded in Israeli Shelling
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shelled Shiite Moslem villages in the Syrian-policed Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon during the night, wounding one person, police reported today. They said more than 50 155mm howitzer shells were fired into the villages of Qalia, Dellafi and Mazraat Luci between 8 p.m. Wednesday and 1 a.m. today. The shellfire came from an artillery battery on a hill near the Israeli-occupied town of Shebaa, police reported. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the shelling began shortly after guerrillas attempted t infiltrate Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' in south Lebanon. ``After foiling the infiltration attempt, the Israelis opened up with artillery fire, apparently in retaliation,'' the spokesman said. The violence came amid increased action in the region, with Palestinian and Lebanese guerrillas stepping up their attacks on the Israeli buffer zone.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Revived After Freezing in Snow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th, 5th and penultimate grafs to CORRECT doctor's name to Veach, sted Beach.
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old girl was revived after she wandered out into the snow and froze to the point of clinical death, her body temperature 24 degrees below normal. Brittany Eichelberger was in critical but stable condition Wednesday at Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh, nursing supervisor Patty Wentroble said. Her fingers and toes were frostbitten, but she was sitting up in bed and talking, Wentroble said. ``The remarkable thing was that the child's body temperature was 74 degrees and she was successfully resuscitated,'' said Dr. John Veach of Davis Memorial Hospital, where Brittany was revived. ``She was in complete cardiac arrest with no heart activitiy and no breathing,'' Veach said. ``Because she was so cold, she had a deathlike appearance, and in fact she was dead.'' Brittany was found lying in snow Monday morning clad only in a nightgown. It was 27 degrees at the time. Her mother had last checked on her five hours earlier. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed and a tube put down Brittany's throat to get her breathing again while she was rushed to the hospital, where she became responsive about three hours later, Veach said. Brittany likely will remain hospitalized another three weeks, Wentroble said.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Capital Faces Financial Disaster, Financial Adviser Says
DOC.TEXT: The nation's capital faces a financial crisis rivalling that of New York City when it tottered near bankruptcy in the 1970s, a financial adviser to Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon says. Franklin D. Raines, chairman of Dixon's Transition Financial Management Committee, says Washington's deficit for this fiscal year could reach $300 million, $100 million more than the administration of outgoing Mayor Marion Barry estimated. ``In five or six months the district will run out of cash and be unable to meet payrolls or pay its bills unless drastic actions are taken immediately,'' Raines wrote in a Dec. 21 memo obtained by The Washington Post. Aides to Mayor Marion Barry and an advisory commission made up of business and civic leaders projected a $200 million deficit. But Raines said it would be between $275 million and $300 million by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year. The difference will come from ``additional unbudgeted spending and a further deterioration of tax revenues due to the recession,'' wrote Raines, a partner in the investment finance firm Lazard Freres. Raines, who has also advised the cities of Chicago and Cleveland, wrote: ``In my 11 years of working with governments in financial difficulty, I do not believe I have ever encountered a situation as potentially disastrous as this one.'' ``The nation's capital is at serious risk. Its problems are as big as those that faced New York City in the 1970s but despite the lessons of New York and other big cities which experienced financial crisis all the major actors in Washington have avoided their responsibility for many years.'' Dixon said Saturday that she was familiar with a tendency politicians have to feign surprise at problems they face after taking office in an effort to buy more time to effect change. ``I know that approach,'' she said. ``I thought about using it myself. I don't have to use any props. Good ol' Marion, he left me with something that's for real.''

DOC.HEAD: Council Backs Old Plan to Change Member Makeup
DOC.TEXT: The City Council, under orders to change how members are elected in order to better represent minorities, has decided to back a plan that would expand the council and draw new districts. The 11-member council agreed Wednesday to request a November 1991 election under a plan that voters approved in August 1989. The plan was forced by a settlement in a 1988 federal lawsuit that said the election system made it difficult for minorities to be elected. The move comes after voters earlier this month defeated a government overhaul that called for the election of 14 council members by districts and the mayor by the city as a whole. Under the current system, instituted in 1975, eight members are elected from districts and three others, including the mayor, are elected from the city at large. Supporters said the plan would have helped ease racial inequities that make it difficult for minorities to get elected. Opponents said the system would have resegregated Dallas. They backed a plan calling for 10 candidates to be elected by district, four by larger districts, or regions, and the mayor by the city as a whole. On Wednesday, a majority of council members agreed to request the November 1991 election following the opponents' plan, with districts to be drawn later, using new census figures. Using 1980 census figures, the council was unable to draw City Council district lines that a majority of the members would support. Consequently, the council decided against submitting a specific plan to the U.S. Justice Department or to U.S. District Judge Jerry Buchmeyer of Dallas, in whose court a voting rights lawsuit against Dallas was filed in 1988. The action increases the likelihood that a federal judge will decide on his own a new system of government upon Dallas. The referendum earlier this month was part of the settlement of the 1988 lawsuit brought by Roy Williams and Marvin Crenshaw, blacks who failed in their at-large council bids. They charged that the election system made it difficult for minorities to win office. Black and Hispanic leaders nationwide have long charged that at-large elections dilute minority voting strength.

DOC.HEAD: AWOL Reservists Turn Themselves In, Seek Conscientious Objector Status
LaserPhoto JV102 of Dec. 26
DOC.TEXT: Two college students were thrown into the brig and could face desertion charges after failing to show up when their Marine Corps Reserve unit left for a Persian Gulf deployment, officials said. James E. Summers Jr., 20, and Demetrio R. Perez, 21, longtime best friends and roommates in Gainesville, surrendered at the Armed Forces Reserve Center on Wednesday and asked for conscientious-objector status. ``We're confident we are doing the right thing,'' Perez said. ``I am following my conscience,'' Summers said, ``and that comes first.'' Maring Maj. Reggie White in Jacksonville said they were processed in Jacksonville and then taken to Camp LeJeune, N.C., for possible court-martial ``for their 29-day deserter status.'' Maj. Bill Grein, a Marine spokesman in New Orleans, said the two will probably be held in the brig until they can speak with their commanding officer. Their lawyer, Ellis Rubin of Miami, said there was a federal warrant for their arrest so he advised them to turn themselves in. The military could either discharge the pair, hold a hearing on their conscientious-objector status or order them court-martialed on the desertion charges. Rubin said the charges also could be reduced to ``unauthorized absence.'' Marines can face up to one year in the brig for unauthorized absence and one year for missing the unit, which left town Nov. 27. The Army had 77 conscientious objector applications through November this year, said Pentagon spokesman Maj. Doug Hart. Last year, there were 74 applications and 22 soldiers were discharged. ``Basic warrior training exposed me to darkness, death, killing and war,'' says Perez in his application for conscientious-objector status. ``This is when I realized that my conscience would not allow me to participate in any war.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Beefs Up Forces On Israeli Border Amid Gulf War Jitters
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan has increased its security forces along the cease-fire line with Israel as a precaution against any surprise attack by the Jewish state, military sources said today. ``We can't afford to be taken by surprise by the Israelis, and the beef-up is a precautionary measure in response to a massive military deployment by the Israelis on the other side of the demarcation line,'' one source said, referring to the border set up after the 1967 Middle East War. Information Minister Ibrahim Izzeddine declined comment on the reported buildup. Israel's 141,000-strong armed forces have been on alert since Kuwait was invaded Aug. 2 by Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has repeatedly threatened to attack Israel if the U.S.-led multinational force launches a military strike on Baghdad. Israel has warned Saddam it would retaliate if he carries through with his threat. The Jordanian military source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``We have no intention of launching any military strike against anyone, but we have to be on alert to protect our national security.'' He declined to give any figures of military strength along the western border. Jordan has a 100,000-man army, including conscripts, and 40,000-strong militia known as the Popular Army. A visitor to the Jordan Valley, 15 miles west of Amman, reported seeing a heavy buildup of tanks, artillery and soldiers in recent days. U.S. officials said on Wednesday they believe Saddam will attack Israel if he believes that a gulf conflict is inevitable. By hitting the Jewish state, the Arabs' main enemy, the Iraqi leader would hope to split the Arab states aligned with the United States from the coalition. Senior Israeli legislator Eliahu Ben-Elissar declared on Wednesday that Jordan was included in the Israeli warnings to retaliate because it is ``in such close alliance with Iraq'' and because of its location. Ben-Elissar said Saddam's missiles and combat jets ``cannot do much against Israel without Jordan.''

DOC.HEAD: Cocaine Cargo Washes Ashore Near Police Academy
DOC.TEXT: A box containing 143 pounds of uncut cocaine washed ashore just two blocks from the State Police Training Academy. The cocaine is worth at least $1.8 million and would be worth even more after being cut or diluted with other substances for street sale, said First Assistant Monmouth County Prosecutor Alton Kenney. A federal drug agent said it's not uncommon for illegal drug shipments to wash ashore like the cocaine found last week. ``One of the things (smugglers are) starting to do is tow the stuff. They'll hook a tow line on it, fix it so it goes under the water,'' said Donald Ashton, agent-in-charge of the Newark office of the Drug Enforcement Administration. ``Occasionally, the tow lines will break, or if a Coast Guard cutter was approaching, they'd cut the line.'' He said smugglers also drop shipments from planes or freighters to waiting boats.

DOC.HEAD: Plant Used in First ``Rocky'' Movie Is Wrecked by Fire
DOC.TEXT: A former meat packing plant used for a scene in the first ``Rocky'' movie was destroyed by fire early today. Firemen fought the flames, fed by a large amount of paper and boxes stored inside, for five hours in in freezing temperatures before bringing the blaze under control, Fire Commissioner Roger Ulshafer said. The two-story building in the city's Kensington section was occupied by the Cosmopolitan Advertising Co. and a Veterans of Foreign Wars post. At the time of the ``Rocky'' filming, it was owned by Cross Brothers Meat Packing Co. The scene in the 1976 movie showed character Rocky Balboa, played by Sylvester Stallone, using a side of beef as a punching bag as he trained for his big fight against champion Apollo Creed.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court OKs Repatriation of Marcos Money
DOC.TEXT: In a ruling published today, the Supreme Court conditionally approved returning to the Philippines $350 million sent to Switzerland by late President Ferdinand E. Marcos. The court said the money, frozen in several Swiss banks since March 1986, must be returned as soon as a criminal court in the Philippines issued a ``legally binding'' verdict in the case. That verdict, it said, should indicate whether the funds would be confiscated or returned to claimants. It gave the Philippines a year to open the criminal proceedings. If no verdict were returned within the deadline, Swiss banks would end their seizure of the assets ``upon request of those affected,'' the court said. It said the Philippine trial must conform to the standards set in the Swiss federal constitution and the European Human Rights Convention, covering chiefly the independence of the judiciary and the impartiality of judges. Before returning the funds, Swiss authorities must determine that all conditions have been met, the court said. Bank records seized in Zurich and Bern, however, can be turned over to Philippine authorities under the ruling, dated Dec. 21. Marcos, his family and aides have been accused by the Philiipine government led by President Corazon Aquino of looting the treasury. Marcos was forced out of office in a 1986 ``people power'' revolution. Zurich District Attorney Dieter Jann said the court's warning about failure to meet the Dec. 21, 1991 deadline did not mean the assets would automatically revert to the Marcos family. He said the family would probably have to prove its claim to the money in protracted civil law proceedings. Jann said the deadline was ``relatively short.'' He said it seemed to make plain the Swiss desire that the Philippines ``take concrete action at last'' in preparing a criminal trial in the case. The ruling rejected 11 appeals against lower court decisions to release funds totaling $350 million that are now blocked at Credit Suisse in Zurich and at Swiss Bank Corporation in Fribourg. The appeals were filed by lawyers on behalf of Marcos' widow, Imelda, and other family members, as well as of three foundations based in the principality of Liechtenstein. The decision ended more than four years of litigation in Swiss courts. Following Marcos' flight to the United States, all Swiss assets linked to Marcos and his family were provisionally frozen March 24, 1986 under an unprecedented government decree. The freeze was extended indefinitely after the Philippine government requested Swiss judicial assistance in efforts to recover the money, originally estimated to total about $1 billion. Marcos' lawyers frequently cited the absence of formal criminal charges as a reason why the request for judicial assistance should be turned down. But in a July 1, 1987 ruling, the Supreme Court authorized such assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Finance Minister Quits, Saying No Progress Toward Market Economy
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Russia's finance minister has resigned, saying the largest and richest Soviet republic has made no progress in the transition to a market economy, the Russian legislature's newspaper reported today. Boris Fyodorov, 33, was quoted as telling Rossiiskaya Gazeta that lawmakers in the Russian republic have been unwilling to take responsibility for necessary but unpopular measures, such as lifting artificial price controls. ``Regrettably, there is nothing like progress toward the market,'' he was quoted as saying. Fyodorov told the newspaper important decisions, such as forming private companies, setting up a stock market and bringing Russian accounting practices in line with international norms, ``get bogged down in the depths of the apparatus ... for months on end.'' ``Cabinet ministers seem to believe in all seriousness that they can run the economy as they would run a factory,'' he was quoted as saying. ``Populist measures involving ever new outlays are taken one after another, while the revenue base is being curtailed.'' ``This is a shortcut to financial bankruptcy for the republic and for the (Soviet) Union as a whole,'' he reportedly said. On Nov. 1, the Russian Federation began a program to switch from a centrally planned, command economy to a free market within 500 days. Russian lawmakers said they wanted to move faster than the national government, but their policies often conflict and create confusion rather than reform.

DOC.HEAD: Trading on Stock Exchanges Delayed By Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with stock markets reopening, details on SEC request to regional exchanges; ADDS background on previous trading disruptions. DELETES outdated material. No pickup. Version moved on financial wire slugged PM-Stock Markets.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Trading on the New York and American stock exchanges was delayed 90 minutes today after a fire broke out in the Wall Street-area building that houses their computer operations. The exchanges opened at 11 a.m. because of the fire, which followed a transformer explosion. The Securities and Exchange Commission asked all other exchanges to refrain from trading until the information system was up and operational, spokeswoman Mary McCue said. ``It's only fair that market participants have access to the same information,'' she said. The over-the-counter market began trading at 9:30 a.m. Regional exchanges, which include the Midwest, Pacific, Cincinnati, Boston and Philadelphia exchanges, trade some of same stocks as the New York and American exchanges, but handle only a small percentage of the total volume of stock traded on the major exchanges. The blaze erupted at the building that houses the Securities Industry Automation Corp., which controls the computer system for stock trading, said New York Stock Exchange spokeswoman Sharon Gamsin. The stock exchanges are located several blocks away. The company, a joint venture between the two major stock exchanges, was evacuated about 2:30 a.m., about two hours after the explosion, she said. Officials said earlier that the fire may have caused hazardous PCBs to spew onto seven floors of the building. The Environmental Protection Agency gave Securities Industry Automation permission to re-enter the building at midmorning. Over-the-counter stock trading is conducted independently of the New York and American exchanges. The National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System, or NASDAQ, reports quotes for over-the-counter stocks. Trading is usually light in the week between Christmas and New Year's. Twenty-six firefighters and 14 others were treated for possible exposure to carcinogenic polychlorinated biphenyls as a result of the fire, said Lt. Jim Powell, a New York City Fire Department spokesman. Of the 26 firefighters treated for possible PCB contamination, four were hospitalized, Powell said. It was not immediately known if any Securities Industry Automation employees were among the injured. The transformer exploded just after 12:30 a.m., Powell said. The fire was under control at 3:16 a.m. Trading disruptions are relatively rate. More than a year ago, trading on the New York Stock Exchange was halted when a fire-related power problem at Securities Industry Automation briefly delayed the opening one day. Last month, a power failure disrupted trading for 90 minutes. The exchange shut down after trading began Nov. 23 and resumed later that morning. In mid-August a fire at a Con Edison power substation forced the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and other futures markets in lower Manhattan to close by early afternoon. The New York Stock Exchange was unaffected by the outage but trading volume slowed.

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Over New Plan to Shoot Bison in Montana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd-4th grafs bgng, `Montana's Department ...' to CORRECT that wardens, rangers already permitted to participate in hunt; new plan, if revised, will be decided upon Friday. SUBS 10TH graf, `Under the ...' with 3 grafs to CLARIFY that background concerns current plan in effect; DELETES incorrect 12th graf, ``Under the old plan...' Picks up 13th graf, `Officials say...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: When hunters legally killed 569 potentially diseased bison outside Yellowstone National Park two winters ago, citics complained that they wounded Montana's proud reputation as a refuge for wildlife. Now officials are thinking of modifying the hunt to make it clear that the purpose is to keep Montana cattle herds disease-free. But conservation and animal-rights groups still aren't satisfied. Montana's Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks is considering a change in rules that now call for state game wardens and national park rangers to join private hunters in killing adult bison that cross from Yellowstone into Montana in search of winter forage. The department plans to make its decision on Friday after today's hearing. ``I think the plan we have now is a good plan and will work,'' Gov. Stan Stephens said in a recent interview. But the New York-based Fund for Animals has sued to stop all bison killing. The Greater Yellowstone Coalition, an environmental group, says the state should consider non-lethal alternatives. The Montana Board of Livestock, frustrated with the long debate, has asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to quarantine Yellowstone. About half of the 2,500 to 3,000 bison in the 2-million-acre park are believed to carry brucellosis, a disease that causes cattle to abort. Montana spent millions of dollars over a decade to eradicate brucellosis in its cattle. ``Why should we have one vestige of infection left?'' asked James Glossen of USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. ``From an agricultural perspective, we don't want that reservoir of infection in Yellowstone.'' Under the current plan, negotiated with the National Park Service, private hunters are called to kill bull bison, and game wardens and park rangers may be called in to kill cows that wander out of the park, sometimes onto private land. Calves would be captured, neutered and sold. Bison that remain inside Yellowstone may not be harmed. Officials say the plan seeks to spread the responsibility for the killings and mitigate some of the outrage that followed the killing of 569 bison by private hunters during the winter of 1988-89. Eleven have been killed so far this season. Officials also say cows are more likely to carry brucellosis than bulls, and putting the responsibility for their killing in the hands of wardens and rangers should reduce the chances of their spreading disease. But the Montana Wildlife Federation, a conservation group whose ranks include hunters, says the bison killing ``is damaging the Montana record as a progressive wildlife conservation state.'' ``The eyes of all America are watching,'' Wayne Pacelle, Fund for Animals' executive director, said last week. ``The Park Service clearly is not going to benefit by having the public see its rangers shoot its very symbol.'' K.L. Cool, the state's Fish, Wildlife and Parks director, has agreed there is no sport involved in shooting the slow-moving animals, likening it to ``shooting cattle in a feed yard.'' He said he would be willing to consider a better alternative but that in the end the spread of brucellosis must be controlled. Ranchers in the area are watching the debate especially closely. ``Bison in Yellowstone Park are of great value to all of us,'' said James Stermitz, a rancher near the park's northern gate. ``Bison outside of Yellowstone Park can only offer problems that would not get better.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Condemns Russian Republic for Budget
With PM-Soviet Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today condemned the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, for passing a 1991 budget that he said was dramatically at odds with national plans. Gorbachev, speaking to the national parliament, said Russian lawmakers agreed to provide only 23.4 billion rubles toward the national budget for next year, 119 billion rubles less than the republic's contribution this year. If other republics follow Russia's lead and cut their contributions to the 250 billion ruble national budget, he said, the result would be ``a collapse, not only of the economy, but of the union.'' ``What are we supposed to do, disband our military entirely and stop all fundamental scientific research? That's not serious,'' Gorbachev said. The Soviet president urged the Russian parliament to suspend its decision. He also asked the Congress of People's Deputies national legislature to pass a resolution calling for actions to resolve the budget dispute, including creation of a national economic stabilization fund. The Congress was expected to vote on the resolution later today or early Friday. Its session was originally scheduled to end today but was extended by one day because of the vice presidential voting, which Gorbachev's nominee, Gennady I. Yanayev, won on the second ballto. The Soviet Union is passing through turbulent times of bare grocery store shelves, ethnic violence and nationwide political paralysis. The national government has been at odds with Russia over how to proceed with the economy. The Russian legislature's newspaper reported today that the republic's finance minister has resigned, saying the federation had made no progress in the transition to a market economy. Boris Fyodorov, 33, was quoted as telling Rossiiskaya Gazeta that lawmakers in the Russian republic have been unwilling to take responsibility for necessary but unpopular measures, such as lifting artificial price controls. On Nov. 1, the Russian Federation began a program to switch from a centrally planned, command economy to a free market within 500 days. Russian lawmakers said they wanted to move faster than the national government, but their policies often conflict and create confusion rather than reform.

DOC.HEAD: 25 Reported Killed in Garment Factory Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with 30 people killed. Pickup 6th pvs, `Another victim...'
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through a garment factory in a Dhaka suburb today, killing at least 30 people, police and hospital sources said. Hundreds fled from the flames, causing a stampede. About 100 other people suffered burns. Police said most of the bodies were found on the third floor, which houses a cutting room where cloth is piled before being made into garments. Survivors said the room usually was kept locked so workers couldn't smuggle anything out of the factory. Twenty-four charred bodies were pulled from the rubble, and doctors said five people succumbed to injuries in hospitals. Another victim, a 9-year-old girl, died in the stampede as the 500 employees fled the flames, the police said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Parveen Akhtar, a worker whose hands were badly burned, said the worst devastation was in the cutting room. ``There were at least 100 people in the cutting room with heaps of clothes. The room usually remains locked,'' she said. It was not immediately known whether the third-floor cutting room door was locked when the fire started, but other workers said factory's the main entrance on the ground level was locked. ``Initially they (the guards) prevented many from escaping. The guards thought the fleeing people may run with shirts that the factory produce,'' said Amena Begum, a sewing machine operator. ``It was like a hell. There was screaming all around,'' said Mohammad Ali, a 25-year-old factory worker. Police said they suspected the fire was started by a short circuit in the five-story building occupied by the privately owned Sareka Garments Co. They said the company's managing director was among the dead. Firemen fought the blaze for about three hours before bringing it under control.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rules Indiana's Out-of-State Trash Law Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today ruled Indiana's new law regulating out-of-state trash are unconstitutional, saying the flow of rubbish into the state is all part of commerce. U.S. District Judge John D. Tinder concluded that the law's three key provisions violate the Constitution's commerce clause that allows free trade among the states. ``However noble and popular these three provisions of House Enrolled Act 1240 appear to be, they must give way to the constitutional principles,'' Tinder wrote. ``The same protection that the commerce clause gives to the citizens of other states who feel the need to import waste into Indiana protects Indiana citizens when they export hazardous waste to other states. ``Commerce, even in such `bads' as waste, is a two-way street.'' Tinder's ruling comes five months after the conclusion of a trial on a lawsuit filed by two Pennsylvania trash haulers who challenged the law shortly after it was signed last spring by Gov. Evan Bayh. Bayh, vacationing in South Carolina, was preparing a statement in reaction to the ruling, his office said. Attorney General Linley E. Pearson, whose office handled the legal defense of the new law, said he knew it would be difficult for the state to overcome the commerce clause argument. About a half-dozen other states have had similar trash laws struck down on the same ground, he said. ``I've always maintained it would be an uphill battle,'' said Pearson. The provisions struck down today required a trash hauler to certify where the largest part of the waste in a shipment was generated, and required a hauler to receive a health officer's certification that the shipment contained no hazardous or infectious waste. The third provision imposed a dumping fee equal to the fee charged at the landfill closest to the point of origin of the trash shipment. The law was passed with bipartisan support after Bayh and legislators expressed alarm that Indiana had become a dumping ground for trash from Eastern states. Tinder said his ruling doesn't prevent Indiana from regulating out-of-state trash, but the law requires that refuse should be treated the same as in-state waste, not in a tougher fashion. Those efforts could include ``imposing and enforcing stringent regulations on infectious or hazardous waste,'' Tinder wrote. The judge also noted that his ruling doesn't disturb other provisions of the law that require solid-waste management plans within Indiana, impose a tipping fee on all waste deposited within the state, and require haulers of waste within Indiana to certify the county of origin of the trash shipment.

DOC.HEAD: Famous Arab Singer `Repents,' Gives Up Show Business
DOC.TEXT: Mohammed Abdo, a Saudi Arabian singer famous in the Arab world, has ``repented'' and given up singing, the Arriyadiyah newspaper reported Thursday. Some fundamentalist Moslems consider singing to be ``haram,'' or sinful. The newspaper, which usually concentrates on sports news, said Abdo wept when he declared his repentance at prayers in a mosque Wednesday night and vowed ``he would never sing again for the rest of his life.'' It said he recited some verses from the Koran, Islam's holy book, asking for forgiveness and ``in melodious sound'' led the congregation in prayer. The newspaper said ``the congregation shouted Allahu Akbar (God is great) while welcoming Abdo back to the fold of Islam.'' It added that Adnan Akbar, a famous Saudi fashion designer who also gave up his profession ``out of fear of Allah,'' was in the mosque when Abdo announced his decision to give up show business. Abdo, of Yemeni origin, began his career in the mid-sixties in Lebanon. He usually spent summers performing in Cairo or London.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Protest New Language Law
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Algerians marched through the streets today protesting a new law forbidding foreign languages. They said the measure is a product of the government's political and religious intolerance. The law passed Wednesday night makes Arabic the national language and exacts stiff fines for using anything else in official transactions. French is now used commonly in the workplace in this former French colony, and Berber is spoken by nearly a third of Algeria's 27 million people. A leftist opposition leader, Hocine Ait-Ahmed, a Berber, called the law a ``veritable coup against democracy.'' ``Under the pretext of defending the Arab language, (they) are fingering democracy,'' he told French radio earlier today. The protesters, estimated in the tens of thousands, marched past the presidential palace. They erected a tent to show their anger at the government's refusal to allow Ait Ahmed's Front of Socialist Forces party to set up a headquarters in Algiers. The law, which passed the National Assembly 173-8 with 13 abstentions, must be signed by President Chadli Bendjedid before it can take effect. He has not said whether he will do so, but members of his party support the law. According to the law, the use of Arabic in all official and work transactions as well as in schools is to be ``total'' by 1997. TV programming must also be in Arabic, but existing French newspapers are not affected. Ait-Ahmed accused the government of ``complicity'' with Islamic forces that he blamed for pressuring the government into the new law. The Moslem fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front has emerged as the main opposition party. Bendjedid moved toward pluralism following riots in October 1988. The Islamic Front, winner in municipal and local elections this summer, has tried to enforce the Islamic dress code in several towns where it has the majority. Under the new law, all documents prepared by the government or private businesses in a language other than Arabic will be ``nullified'' and fines from $100 to $500 levied. Political parties will be fined from $1,000 to $10,000 for not complying with the law.

DOC.HEAD: Three Injured by Accidental Gunshots In Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Three people suffered gunshot wounds Thursday when an Uzi submachine gun carried by a security guard accidentally discharged on Jerusalem's crowded Ben Yehuda mall, police said. The man with the gun was one of two security guards for a group of South American tourists, police said. They said both guards and a 54-year-old woman passerby were shot in the legs and slightly wounded. The Ben Yehuda mall is one of Jerusalem's main shopping areas and is usually crowded with shoppers and patrons of outdoor cafes. Some tour groups in the city have armed guards because of tension between Jews and Arabs. Police said the guard was questioned and released without charge.

DOC.HEAD: State Industry Minister Dies
DOC.TEXT: Franco Piga, the state industry minister who recently mediated a battle for control of Italy's chemical industry, has died of a heart attack, his family said Thursday. The 63-year-old Cabinet minister died while an ambulance was taking him to a hospital late Wednesday night in the Dolomite resort of Cortina D'Ampezzo, where he was spending Christmas holidays, the family said. A Christian Democrat, Piga received the post in Premier Giulio Andreotti's government in July, after five ministers quit in a political dispute. He served as head of the Italian stock market regulatory agency, Consob, from 1984 to 1988. As industry minister, Piga played a key role in working out an agreement between the state energy group ENI and the private chemical industry giant Montedison, allowing ENI to buy a controlling stake in their long-disputed joint-venture Enimont. The premier's office announced that Andreotti will temporarily hold the ministry post until a replacement is named.

DOC.HEAD: Ants, Ants, Ants And More Ants Invading Homes to Escape Cold
DOC.TEXT: The record cold wave is driving ants, ants and more ants into houses and apartments throughout the San Francisco Bay area in search of warmth and food. ``People are frantic, some hysterical,'' said Ann McDonald, whose husband, Rich, owns a pest control company. One of McDonald's customers in Sausalito left half a cake out Christmas night. When she got up the next morning she found ``the ants had taken over.'' ``They were all over everything,'' Dorothy McLaird said. The counters and cupboards were alive with what McDonald estimated as 30,000 ants. Mice also are moving in. ``Any hole the size of a pencil they can squeeze through,'' said Ken Alexander of Jackson's Pest Control. ``Suddenly you open a cupboard and there is a little telltale thing telling you the mice have moved in.''

DOC.HEAD: President's Resignation Expected, Military Denies Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The army today said it had been constitutionally empowered to force the civilian government from power on Christmas Eve. It denied the characterization of the ouster as a military coup. Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, acting army chief, said the National Assembly would receive resignations today from President Ramsewak Shankar and Vice President Henck Arron and would elect new chief executives by Saturday. The military forced the civilian government from the National Palace on Monday, following a dispute between Shankar and military Cmdr. Desi Bouterse, a former dictator of the South American nation. ``There is no coup at all,'' Graanoogst said on television. ``The United States, the Netherlands, France and others who have protested are premature.'' Graanoogst referred to two articles in the constitution that charge the army with the responsibility to ensure ``a peaceful transition to a democratic and socially just society.'' He said the military had been assured by jurists that it had acted constitutionally. Graanoogst, No. 2 in the five-member military command headed by Bouterse, said Many nations have condemned the military action and demanded that the legitimately elected government be reinstated. The assembly convened today for the first time since Graanoogst announced Monday night that the president had been deposed. Resignations of the civilian leaders were expected. One journalist, speaking on condition of anonymity, said said if they resign, ``they'll be doing it at gunpoint.'' The constitution requires the assembly to appoint new chief executives if the president and vice president resign. Bouterse seized power in 1980 from Arron, who was president, and headed a military dictatorship for seven years being allowing democratic elections in 1987. He continued to wield considerable power as army chief, a post he angrily resigned Monday in a dispute with Shankar. Shankar and Arron were elected by the National Assembly in 1988 after Shankar's three-party coalition, the Front for Democracy and Development, won a landslide victory in the 1987 elections. Suriname is an ethnically diverse country of 400,000, bordered on South America's northeastern Atlantic coast by Guyana and French Guiana, and to the south by Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Go Off At Bank After Man Starts Counting Down
DOC.TEXT: Two bombs went off at a bank today after a man put a package on the counter and started counting backward. The blasts - one inside the bank and the other outside the bank - caused extensive damage, but no injuries, officials said. A bank employee told a radio station a man walked into a First Union National Bank branch shortly after 9 a.m. and set a package on the teller counter. After the man began to count down loudly from 10, the employee said, he fled. About 10 people were in the bank at the time, officials said. They realized what was happening and fell to the floor before the blast, said the employee, who asked not to be identified. The blast shattered a window and damaged the teller counter. Debris was strewn across the floor. A second bomb went off outside, said FBI Agent Tom Lusby. Details were sketchy, but Police Assistant Chief D.R. Stone said they were investigating whether the explosions were part of a bank robbery. ``I heard a very large explosion,'' said Beth Allen, manager of Camera World, next door to the bank. ``It sounded like the heater in our building had exploded, it was so loud.'' ``When I came out of the store, I saw all the bank employees running out of the bank and into our store,'' Ms. Allen said. ``They weren't screaming, but they were in a hurry to get here.'' Bank spokeswoman Sandy Deem said officials were on the scene and that she could not comment. Police said they believed the suspect escaped in a white four-wheel drive vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: Television Director Richard Irving Dies at 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to UPDATE with mortuary confirmation; picks up 3rd graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: Television director and producer Richard Irving, whose credits included ``Columbo'' and the ``Six Million Dollar Man,'' has died at the age of 73. Irving died Sunday after heart surgery at an undisclosed San Diego hospital, and was buried Wednesday following a funeral at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles, according to the mortuary. Irving, a onetime Broadway and film actor, was a dialogue director at the RKO film studio before entering television. Later he helped establish Revue Productions, the MCA Universal television production subsidiary. He oversaw the production of 36 TV films during one six-month period in 1971. In 1949 and 1950, he produced 22 episodes of the 90-minute ``Mystery Theatre'' features. Irving produced the Gruen and Chevron Theater anthologies, ``Pepsi-Cola Playhouse,'' ``Name of the Game,'' ``Columbo,'' and ``Wagon Train.'' He also directed the pilot film for ABC-TV's ``Six Million Dollar Man'' and the NBC-TV miniseries ``Seventh Avenue.'' He was executive vice president of Universal TV until 1979. Shortly after his departure, he directed the mini-series ``The Jesse Owens Story.'' Most recently, Irving directed the ABC series ``The Insiders'' and NBC's ``Hell Town,'' and produced the TV movie ``The Last Days of Pompeii.'' Irving is survived by his wife, Joanne; a daughter, a son, three stepchildren and seven grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar-Winning Art Director Dead At 67
DOC.TEXT: Academy Award-winning art director and set designer Gene Callahan, who worked on more than 50 movies and 1,000 television programs, has died at age 67. He died at his Baton Rouge home Wednesday. No cause of death was given. Callahan won Oscars for his set designing work in ``The Hustler'' starring Paul Newman and Jackie Gleason and for art direction in ``America, America.'' He received a third Academy Award nomination for ``The Cardinal.'' In a 1969 interview, Callahan, a Baton Rouge native, described his work: ``As a production designer, I am responsible for the `look' of the show - from locations, or exterior scenes, and how they are to be shot, to the design sets themselves, their constructions, their painting, and then the set decoration. Sometimes I design the titles, too.'' From building a village in Greece to painting a mountainside a different shade to building shores in Turkey, his work ran the gamut. Callahan, who started working in theater by designing opera sets in the 1940s at Louisiana State University, recently worked as production designer for the movie ``Steel Magnolias,'' shot in Natchitoches, La. As set decorator, his many film credits included ``Butterfield 8,'' ``Splendor in the Grass,'' and ``Long Day's Journey into Night.'' As art director, he earned film credits for ``Funny Girl,'' ``The Stepford Wives,'' ``Julia,'' ``The Eyes of Laura Mars,'' ``Seems Like Old Times,'' ``Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' ``Grease II,'' ``Places in the Heart,'' and ``Children of a Lesser God.''

DOC.HEAD: American Moslems Feel They Have Special Role In US Force
DOC.TEXT: Lance Cpl. John Scott is a Marine grunt, training for the dangerous job of breaching Iraqi defenses. He is also Kashim Ishmael Elijah Scott, a follower of Islam who feels he has a special purpose defending the birthplace of the religion despite differences with his hosts and the U.S. military over his faith. ``I feel like I have more of a purpose than the average Marine. Most people here are wondering why, they are trying to grasp a reason. I feel I am defending Mecca and Medina, which is sacred ground,'' Scott said. The 20-year-old from Los Angeles is a member of the Alpha Company in the 1st Battalion, Third Marine Regiment, which was deployed in September. When he got to Saudi Arabia he reaffirmed his Islamic faith in a Saudi mosque, ``just to feel that I did it in the homeland.'' Lance Cpl. D. Carlos Timmons, 21, of Atlanta, Georgia, decided to convert to Islam while in Saudi Arabia. ``Not many brothers can say `I made shahada in Saudi Arabia,''' he said. Making shahada, which means witness in Arabic, is one of the five main tenets of the faith. An adherent must say ``I witness that there is no God, but God, and Mohammed is his prophet,'' in the presence of a learned prayer leader. He also must accept the other four principles: praying five times a day, fasting during the holy month of Ramadan, donating money for the poor annually and making a pilgrimage to the holy cities of Mecca and Medina - where Mohammed founded the faith - at least once in his lifetime. Members of the predominately black Islamic sect in the United States are sometimes called Black Muslims. In the United States, charismatic Black Muslim leaders like the late Malcolm X used Islam to stress black nationalism. Some have called for creating a separate, black nation in the United States that would be loosely based on Islam. ``The Saudis stress we have to come back to the principles, that U.S. Muslims have strayed from the faith, its books, the oneness of God,'' Scott said. ``They said we were getting too much into the social aspect of things and not praising God enough. That was the only derogatory thing we heard from them,'' he added. For their part, the Saudis have been trying to counteract the negative image Islam has in the United States due to a decade of confrontation with some of its more extremist elements, especially Shiite Moslem kidnappers in Lebanon and others fueled by the revolutionary zeal of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. ``Islam was introduced in the picture of Khomeini, of terrorists and so forth. This is not Islamic,'' said Mohammed Al-Okat, a Saudi who organizes lectures for the troops on Saudi culture. Here, the holy book the Koran is considered the constitution. Followers of Islam recognize Jesus as a prophet, but reject that he is the son of God and don't accept Christmas as a holiday. ``Such honoring is only for God, not for any human being,'' said Dr. Mohammed Al-Dabbal, director for literary criticism at Imam Mohammed Ibn Saud Islamic University of Riyadh, in an interview. Scott and Timmons said they do not celebrate Christmas. Other tenets of the faith they do not follow strictly, but they pointed out that Mohammed himself allowed soldiers fighting a war some leeway. They only pray three times a day, for example. ``We do too much'' to pray five times, said Timmons. They want recognition from the U.S. military in the form of enlisted prayer leaders and time out for prayers on Friday. There is no firm statistic on how many of the 300,000 U.S. troops here have converted, but Christian chaplains said they have heard of dozens. It is not clear how many were Black Muslims. The office of the senior Defense Department chaplain in Washington said there are about 2,700 followers of Islam in all U.S. military services, but no prayer leaders. It stressed in a statement that the U.S. military respects the right of all Armed Forces members to practice any religion, as guaranteed in the Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Military Buildup Costs Small Towns Heavily When Doctors Leave
DOC.TEXT: The callup of reservists for the Persian Gulf buildup is striking medical care hard in rural America, leaving some small towns without doctors and forcing retired physicians back to work. Dr. Victor Hoefner Jr., 70, was enjoying his retirement last month when his son, Dr. Victor C. Hoefner III, an Army National Guardsman, was called up for duty the Persian Gulf. Now the elder Hoefner has taken over his son's family practice in this western Colorado community. The Pentagon won't say how many doctors have been called up, citing security. In addition to the activation of members of the Army, Navy and Air Force reserves, the Army has begun forcing some retired medical officers back into uniform. The effect of the callup is quickly felt in small towns, and the indefinite duration of the crisis is adding to the problem, according to rural health experts. ``Are we talking three months, six months or a year?'' asked Toby Turner, spokeswoman for the National Rural Health Association in Kansas City. ``Rural health has been in crisis anyway, and losing 50 percent of your small hospital's staff at one time is just too much of a blow. The military is just filling slots in these units without paying any attention to a medical reservist's role at home.'' ``The pattern we're seeing is that when people are called from a small community, it's felt much more because the likelihood of a critical position being affected is greater and the likelihood of having adequate backup is less than a large hospital,'' said Al Chechik, spokesman for the Wisconsin Hospital Association. The call-up of physicians, nurses and technicians has the potential to strip the U.S. Public Health Service staffs on Indian reservations, although not too many have been called as yet, officials said. The Public Health Service hospital in Crownpoint, N.M., serving Navajos and other tribes in the area, lost its only ear, nose and throat specialist. ``The Public Health Service is part of the armed services, and we sign a statement that we can be pulled for non-combatant duty,'' said Dr. Annie Kusava, a pediatrician in Crownpoint, who carries the rank of lieutenant colonel. In Verdigre, Neb., the lone physician was called up, leaving the northeast Nebraska community of 617 without a doctor. Dr. Ken Pavlik, an Army Reservist, leaves a medical clinic and patients in the Knox County hospital and nursing home. He arranged for Dr. D.J. Nagengast, who lives 25 miles away in Bloomfield, to make rounds and check on his patients. ``There is no question that this is going to be an inconvenience to a lot of people,'' Pavlik said. While the number of physicians pulled out of rural areas apparently isn't great, their departure leaves a far larger gap than would that of their big-city counterpart. ``It hurts the rural hospitals where there have been shortages anyway,'' said Pete Moberg, spokesman for St. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction. St. Mary's is a regional hospital, with accident victims or emergency surgery patients transferred from lesser-equipped rural hospitals. ``If a little hospital loses its doctor and a scrub nurse, there's going to be no surgery done there at all,'' Moberg said. St. Mary's is receiving more patient referrals from doctors and other hospitals in the Western Slope region because of the call-up, Moberg said. Dr. Jose Luis Rodriguez, the only plastic surgeon in Glenwood Springs, 90 miles east of Grand Junction, closed his office and referred patients to doctors in Grand Junction after he was activated. He is a lieutenant colonel in the National Guard. In Wyoming, even more sparsely populated than Colorado, there are only about 600 doctors in the entire state and seven are already gone or on standby. ``In a state like Wyoming, the impact of losing physicians is great,'' said Rich Johnson, executive director of the Wyoming Medical Society. ``There are not a lot of choices in medical care in many communities.''

DOC.HEAD: Relative of Childhood Kidnap Victim Slain
DOC.TEXT: An uncle of Steven Stayner, the youth who survived a seven-year kidnapping ordeal and later died in a motorcycle accident, has been slain in his home, authorities said. Jesse ``Jerry'' Stayner, 42, died Wednesday. The victim's brother, Delbert Stayner, is the father of Steven Stayner, who was kidnapped in Merced in 1972 when he was 7. Eight years later, Steven escaped with another kidnap victim near Ukiah, 200 miles north of Merced; he died nine years later in a motorcycle accident. The man who abducted them, Kenneth Parnell, was convicted and served five years of an eight-year prison term. Jerry Stayner was shot in the chest in his home just outside Merced, said Merced County sheriff's Detective Rick Marshall. ``Maybe someone was in there (the house) when he came home for lunch, but we have no leads,'' Marshall said. He said the victim's pickup had been taken.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Neutral In Persian Gulf Crisis, But Outcome Will Have Impact
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Iran is neutral in the Persian Gulf crisis, but whatever the outcome it will have an impact on Iran's future in the region and beyond. The crisis also will have a profound effect on President Hashemi Rafsanjani's efforts to steer Iran away from the legacy of the late revolutionary patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Iraq was Iran's foe in the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war. If Iraq emerges from the current crisis with its military power intact, Iran would be wooed by the countries of the region as a counterweight to Saddam Hussein's ambitions. If Iraq is driven out of Kuwait and its military might destroyed or seriously weakened, Iran would be left in a powerful position that would make its Arab neighbors uneasy. A victory for America and the international force and any continuation of a U.S. presence in the region might incense Iran's anti-Western radicals and create the possibility of new turbulence in the region. Rafsanjani, leader of the country's so-called pragmatists, has largely pushed aside radical rivals in a political power struggle that surfaced following Khomeini's death in June 1989. But the hard-liners, opposed to his drive to repair relations with the West and Iran's Arab neighbors, are seeking to undercut Rafsanjani by whipping up anti-American passions. Some even want to align Iran with Iraq in a new Islamic front against ``the Great Satan.'' ``The Iranians are faced with a dilemma: They don't want the Iraqis to further tip the regional balance by coming out of this situation in possession of parts of Kuwait,'' said Philip Robins, an analyst with London's Royal Institute of International Studies. ``On the other hand, they are concerned about the buildup of Western forces, particularly the Americans, in the region,'' he noted in a telephone interview. Shireen Hunter, an analyst with Washington's Institute of Strategic and International Studies, fears that war ``could set back the process of moderation, consolidation and reconstruction going on in Iran now. ``If war erupts, and if it extends into Iraqi territory, the radicals are going to try to use the opportunity to undermine Rafsanjani's moderate policies,'' she said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. ``A solution where Iraq is not destroyed but is left weakened is in Iran's best interests,'' Hunter noted. Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi, who has emerged as the foremost leader of the radicals, said: ``I would not support a confrontation with the United States hand-in-hand with Iraq. ``But if it was a pan-Islamic thing, together with all the other Moslem countries, I'd support that,'' he said in an interview. `The radical position is that if possible, the way should be paved for the humiliation of American forces in the Persian Gulf,'' said Morteza Firozi, a senior commentator on the influential English-language Tehran Times daily. Iran's 55 million people are Persians, not Arabs. But they are overwhelmingly Shiite Moslems and, despite the Persian Gulf war, feel kinship with fellow Shiites who make up 55 percent of Iraq's population. Hunter said that if the Shiites' holiest shrines in the Iraqi cities of Najaf, Karbala and Kazimain, all south of Baghdad, are damaged in any hostilities, ``popular passions in Iran would really rise.'' Iran has insisted Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. But Rafsanjani also has condemned the foreign forces sent to the Persian Gulf, which Iran considers its turf. The Kuwait crisis has brought considerable gains for Rafsanjani, including as much as $4 billion in oil price increases that boost his drive to rebuild the economy. The crisis has also led to improved relations with the West and the other Arab states and Iraqi acceptance of Tehran's conditions for formally ending the 1980-88 war. Robins noted: ``It would be highly unlikely that Iran will in any way become involved in a military conflict on either side.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Ali Mohammad Besharati said in an interview: ``If there is a war, our policy is clear: We do not intend to join any forces in the gulf or to help one side against another. Our policy is to seek a peaceful solution to the crisis.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Anwar Faruqi has monitored Iranian affairs for The AP from Cyprus since 1987 and recently returned from Tehran.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Snap Hit California Crops Worst
DOC.TEXT: Crop damage from the cold wave that gripped most of the nation before Christmas was mostly confined to fruit and vegetables in California, a government report said Thursday. The severe cold in California ``caused extensive damage to the citrus and vegetable crops,'' the Joint Agricultural Facility said. But Arizona and Texas crops escaped serious freeze damage, it added. ``Rain and snow over the eastern third of the nation provided moisture to growing crops and delayed late harvest of corn and soybeans,'' the report said. ``Lack of moisture in Florida resulted in continued use of irrigation in fruit groves.'' The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports show the general effects of weather on crops but do not foretell actual losses or production estimates. While the low temperatures in California damaged the citrus crop, the report said ``damaged fruit can be processed but will be limited by processing capacity.'' In southern Texas, growers in the Rio Grande Valley ``reported little damage to growing crops'' from cold weather, the report said. However, there was some minor damage to spinach and beet crops in the San Antonio winter garden area. The Agriculture Department has forecast 1991 consumer food prices will increase an average of 2 percent to 5 percent from this year. Retail food prices gained and estimated 6 percent this year. Ralph L. Parlett Jr. of the department's Economic Research Service said it was ``too early to tell'' for certain what impact the western freeze last week will have. But Parlett said fruit and vegetable prices will go up ``a little more'' next year than has been forecast. Overall, however, Parlett said he is sticking with the agency's forecast of a 2 percent to 5 percent food prices increase next year.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Gets Advanced Soviet Anti-Aircraft Missiles, Radio Says
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran test-fired a Soviet-made, SA-6 anti-aircraft missile Thursday, acknowledging for the first time it had acquired the advanced long-range weapon. The SA-6, known by the NATO code-name ``Gainful,'' is a long-range missile capable of hitting targets 40 miles high. It carries an 88-pound, high-explosive warhead at nearly three times the speed of sound. The acquisition of radar-guided SA-6 missiles was believed part of a $6 billion defense and industrial deal signed by Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani in Moscow in June 1989. A Tehran radio broadcast, monitored in Cyprus, said the surface-to-air missile was fired at the Fajr missile base by the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps. It did not say where the base was, or how many missiles the Iranians have bought. The missile purchase is a big boost for Iran's badly depleted military, which suffers a chronic shortage of advanced weapons. The Iranians are known to have U.S.-made, HAWK anti-aircraft missiles, some obtained in former President Reagan's clandestine arms-for-hostages deal in 1985-86. They also are believed to have Soviet SA-7s, Swedish RBS-70s, British Rapier and Chinese HQ-2Js, the Chinese version of the Soviet SA-2 system. Iraq, Iran's foe in the 1980-88 war, has at least 300 SA-6s along with other surface-to-air missiles. In August, Iraq agreed to Iranian conditions to end the war, enabling Baghdad to send thousands of troops from its border with Iran to its frontier with Saudi Arabia. A U.S.-led multinational force was deployed in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iran has urged Baghdad to pull out of Kuwait, but it has also condemned the presence of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. In September, the Iranians unveiled Soviet-built, MiG-29 advanced fighter jets acquired under the 1989 deal with Moscow. The Iranian air force, believed to have less than half its estimated 170 U.S.-built combat aircraft serviceable, is thought to have one squadron of 14 MiG-29s. The Revolutionary Guards, an elite miltiary force in Iran, have their own naval and air wings, independent of the regular armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Calif. Gov-Elect Names Former Sierra Club Leader as Resources Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect Pete Wilson has named a former executive director of the Sierra Club to be his cabinet secretary in charge of all state water, parks, fish and game and wildlife agencies. Douglas Wheeler, 48, currently the executive vice president of the Washingotn, D.C.-based World Wildlife Fund and Conservation Foundation was named Wednesday as secretary of the state Resources Agency. The Republican governor-elect said his appointment of Wheeler ``makes good on one of my campaign promises ... to very vigorously pursue the preservation of our physical environment.'' Wheeler served 16 months in the Sierra Club post, resigning in 1986. Although Wheeler clashed with some Sierra Club leaders, his appointment was taken as a strong signal from Wilson to environmentalists, and applauded by spokesmen for those groups. Corey Brown, general counsel to the California Planning and Conservation League, said Wheeler ``has a very good reputation working closely with environmentalists and the private sector in managing our natural resources.'' ``It's a very positive thing that Wilson has done,'' said Sierra Club state director Michael Paparian. ``Wheeler has worked with with the environmental community. He is someone who builds consensus.''

DOC.HEAD: Orders for `Big Ticket' Goods Plummet 10.5 Percent in November
DOC.TEXT: Orders to manufacturers for ``big ticket'' durable goods plummeted 10.5 percent in November, the government said Thursday. The report likely signals more layoffs in the factory sector, which lost 200,000 jobs last month and more than 800,000 in the last two years. The orders drop matched the post-1958 record falloff for one month, set in January of this year. It reduced orders to a seasonally-adjusted $115.9 billion, the lowest level since May 1988, the Commerce Department said. On Capitol Hill, the chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., predicted that nationwide unemployment could hit 8 percent in the current downturn. The jobless rate rose to 5.9 percent last month. ``We will in fact have a recession'' said Hamilton in his 1991 economic forecast. He said it could prove moderate or severe, depending on the outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``A settlement in the gulf could reduce inflation and encourage an early recovery,'' Hamilton said. ``But if the crisis intensifies, the downturn will be longer and deeper. If war comes, all bets are off.'' Orders for durable goods - items expected to last three or more years - had risen 3.6 percent in October, but have been down in six of 11 months so far in 1990. ``To me this is the last nail in the coffin for the recession,'' said economist Sung Won Sohn of Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. ``It's such a whopping and across-the-board decline that it indicates we are in a deep recession.'' ``I think employment will continue to take a pretty significant beating,'' said Sohn, who is forecasting a loss of an additional 75,000 manufacturing jobs in December. However, some analysts saw a glimmer of hope amid the gloom. They said pressure from overseas competitors has forced manufacturers to trim payrolls sooner than in previous recessions. That could help avoid even bigger layoffs later, they said. ``We look for a bad (employment) number in December. But, to the extent that manufacturers have succeeded in keeping payrolls in line with what they feel will be the worst-case outlook for demand, I am hopeful that the worst of the job loss may be behind rather than ahead of us,'' said economist Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Co. In November, declines in new orders were widespread, but deepest in the transportation and defense industries. Transportation orders fell 27.4 percent in November. That included a drop of 38.8 percent in aircraft and parts, more than offsetting October's 20.4 percent increase. Boeing Co. earlier reported new orders of $5.2 billion, down from $10.7 billion a month earlier. Automobile and parts orders also fell. Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders fell 3.5 percent to their lowest levels in two years after edging down 0.2 percent in October. New orders for defense equipment dropped 24.5 percent. Orders excluding defense were down 9.6 percent. Non-defense capital goods - a barometer of business' investment in expansion and modernization - fell 16.4 percent in November. Only orders for non-electrical machinery - which includes computers - showed no decline. They were unchanged from October to November. Electrical machinery orders fell 7.6 percent and primary metals orders, which often decline when orders for autos decline, dropped 9.8 percent. ``You are seeing cascading weakness spreading from industry to industry,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch. The backlog of unfilled orders - a good indication of how busy factories will be in months ahead - dropped 1.1 percent to $497.5 billion. It was the largest one-month decline since November 1985. Shipments dropped 3.6 percent to $121.7 billion, the lowest level since last January.

DOC.HEAD: W. Va. Growth Rate Was Nation's Lowest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Suggested for side-by-side use with AM-Census-West Virginia
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Census, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Coal is still king in West Virginia, but it's a monarchy where more and more subjects are opting for a new realm. A dip in the market in the mid-1980s, as well as the automation of the industry, were among factors in a mass exodus in the 1980s. According to U.S. Census Bureau figures released Wednesday, West Virginia's population was 1,801,625 this year, a 7.6 percent decline from the 1,949,644 counted in 1980. West Virginia lost a higher percentage of residents than any state. No bordering state lost population and West Virginia was one of only four states to lose people. ``I think it's a red flag in economic planning,'' said John Hurd, president of the state Chamber of Commerce. ``I think when people don't stay here or come here, I think it's pure and simple they can't make a living in West Virginia,'' Hurd said. ``There's just not enough job opportunities for them.'' Mark Polen, vice president of the West Virginia Coal Association, said there are 40,000 fewer jobs in the state's coal industry than in 1976, when the market for metallurgical coal still was booming. In the mid-1980s, that market bottomed out and southern West Virginia, where metallurgical coal is the main product, suffered. Despite unemployment as high as 40 percent in some counties in the state's southern coal fields, the industry is having a bumper year. It will produce 152 million tons of coal this year with a work force of 24,500. That's the best production since 1951, when 163 million tons were mined, said Gary White, president of the state coal association. In 1980, the mines employed 43,600 and each miner produced 10.97 tons. Today's more-mechanized mines produce 23.6 tons of coal per miner, White said. Unemployment isn't a statewide problem. ``If we're still losing population it means we have a labor surplus,'' said Ed Merrifield, director of the state's office of labor and economic research. ``Eventually, you'll reach a point where supply equals demand.'' In 1979, 658,600 people were working in West Virginia. This year, there are 625,000, Merrifield said. Manufacturing has declined from 117,200 in 1979 to 87,600. Employment in the glass industry dropped from 16,500 to 7,500; metals employment slipped from 24,800 to 14,400 and chemical work dropped from 25,800 to 17,500. Gov. Gaston Caperton believes the economy has turned the corner. ``The decade of the '80s was a decade of despair for West Virginia, but the '90s will be a decade of growth,'' said gubernatorial spokesman George Manahan. Others, however, are concerned the state's population is gradually aging. In 1979-80, 387,786 children were in West Virginia schools. That number had fallen by 64,000 this year, Department of Education officials said. ``The loss of population has been a constant bleed for three decades now,'' said Troy Stewart, political science professor at Marshall University. ``You have fewer people consuming fewer items and fewer people left to pay the bills,'' Stewart said. ``The tax structure must be shaped in a way to cover the services, but ensure someone is left to pay the bills, too.'' Caperton's administration imposed record-high taxes of $457 million in the past two years. That included reimposition of the sales tax on food at 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Key Lawmaker Predicts Recession Will Push Jobless Rate Near 8 Percent
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Congress' Joint Economic Committee predicted Thursday that unemployment during the current economic downturn could rise to nearly 8 percent. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., in an economic forecast for 1991, said he based the estimate on jobless increases during recessions since World War II. The rate in such periods has increased by at least two percentage points, he said. In November, the rate went up to 5.9 percent. Hamilton, who issued a written report and held a news conference, said ``we will in fact have a recession'' next year, but it will not be typical of past downturns. This recession will be more unpredictable, Hamilton said, because of record debt piled up during the expansion of the 1980s and the Persian Gulf crisis. ``A settlement in the Gulf could reduce inflation and encourage an early recovery,'' Hamilton said. ``But if the crisis intensifies, the downturn will be longer and deeper. If war comes all bets are off.'' Hamilton, emphasizing he spoke only for himself, said last year's deficit reduction agreement was ``a step in the right direction, but did not finish the job.'' He said a new agreement will be needed beyond 1991. The key to long-term recovery is to increase national savings, which would require an additional $80 billion of budget savings in fiscal 1995, Hamilton said. . To ease suffering during the current downturn, Hamilton proposed reinstating the extended benefits program for those out of work for longer than six months. The program, virtually eliminated, should be renewed because ``many jobless workers could exhaust their benefits,'' Hamilton said. The proportion of the unemployed who receive jobless benefits has dropped from about 50 percent 10 years ago to about 33 percent today. Hamilton said the best way to shorten the downturn is by lowering interest rates to encourage construction and investment. Noting the Federal reserve already has eased credit, the chairman pointed out that the Fed does not control the long-term rates that influence investment.
