DOC.HEAD: $360,000 Price Tag for Marshals' Security
DOC.TEXT: Federal marshals say they have spent more than $360,000 on security and transportation for Manuel Noriega since the deposed dictator was escorted out of Panama after the U.S. invasion. The Marshals Service has cited ``the extraordinary costs of security details'' each time Noriega has been shuttled from and to his private prison suite for court appearances 24 miles away. The information was obtained by The Miami Herald on a Freedom of Information Act request and published Thursday. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges of accepting $4.6 million from the Medellin cocaine cartel to protect U.S.-bound drug shipments. The security bill through November totaled $363,694, including everything from decoy vehicles to overtime for Noriega's flight aboard a C-130 cargo plane from Panama to Homestead Air Force Base south of Miami. ``It's not cheap, but it's not unique,'' said Marshals Service spokesman Steve Boyle in Washington. ``In situations where there's high potential for media interest or security concerns, the costs are quite extraordinary.'' Noriega has appeared in court five times since Jan. 3, when he surrendered to face drug indictments in Miami and Tampa. Boyle refuses to say how much each courthouse trip costs because ``we don't want to give anyone the basis to calculate the level of security he gets.'' He notes that marshals have handled other costly inmates, such as Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas. The transportation bill for the Medellin cartel smuggler ``exceeded $1 million before we were finished'' with his 7{-month trial in Jacksonville. Federal expenses for Noriega's quarters at the Metropolitan Correctional Center southwest of Miami already have raised some eyebrows. His custom-built cell features an exercise bicycle, telephone, copying machine and computer - equipment the government installed to guarantee his rights to physical exercise and attorney access without endangering his security.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Sends Envoys Back to Posts, Says He's Ready to Talk
LaserPhotos BAG1, DHR1-3,5, PAR1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Thursday sent a group of senior diplomats back to their overseas posts, saying it was ready for ``serious and constructive dialogue'' to avert war. But it denied it was launching a new peace initiative. Kuwait's foreign minister said it was too late for peace initiatives in the Persian Gulf, maintaining that only military force would dislodge Iraq from the oil-rich emirate that it invaded Aug. 2. Less than three weeks before the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait or face possible force, President Bush sought to dismiss newspaper accounts that his two senior military advisers told him U.S. forces are not fully ready to fight. ``Don't believe these reports you're reading,'' Bush told reporters outside the White House. He interrupted his Christmas vacation for a day of work. Bush also met with Soviet Ambassador Alexander Bessmertnykh, who delivered a letter from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Aides said they did not know the content of the message. On Wednesday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein met with 20 diplomats who had been recalled to Baghadad, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. They included the envoys to the United States, the Soviet Union and the United Nations. ``We are ready for a serious and constructive dialogue based on mutual respect and the rejection of the course of hegemony and arrogance which the American administration tries to impose on us,'' the state Iraqi News Agency quoted Saddam as telling the diplomats. The report Thursday was monitored in Cyprus. But Saddam repeated his demand to link an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza Strip with any Iraqi pullout from Kuwait, the Iraqi diplomats said on condition of anonymity. The United States has refused to link the two issues. Saddam showed little willingness to compromise on the issue. Iraq is ``ready to take any sacrifice for the battle it wages against the United States and its allies,'' the news agency quoted him as saying. Iraq also denied reports in recent days that Saddam was preparing a diplomatic initiative ahead of the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline. The diplomats said the envoys were beginning to leave Iraq on Thursday to return to their posts overseas. Iraq said it still has not agreed to any direct talks with senior U.S. officials to try to avert war. Bush also denied any movement on direct U.S.-Iraqi talks. On Thursday, Saddam met with Soviet Deputy Premier Igor Belousov about the gulf crisis, a Soviet diplomat said. There were no details on their discussions. Kuwait's foreign minister, Sheik Sabah Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, said that only military force would dislodge Iraq from Kuwait. ``The whole world has given enough time for a peaceful settlement of the gulf crisis,'' the Kuwaiti official told a news conference in Beijing. ``Whether by the Arab world, whether by the friendly countries, whether by the Third World countries, or by the big powers, it is very late for such (peace) initiatives. It wuld not be useful,'' the sheik said. Iraq has more than a half-million troops, 4,000 tanks, 2,500 armored personnel carriers and 2,700 artillery pieces in Kuwait and southern Iraq, U.S. officials said. It test-fired a surface-to-surface missile Wednesday within its own borders, aimed away from the multinational forces, U.S. officials said. No further details were disclosed. Previous tests put some of the 300,000 American forces deployed in Operation Desert Shield on a heightened state of alert. The U.S. Command would not comment on the current alert status. In other developments Thursday: -Thousands of women and children demonstrated in Baghdad to protest the U.S. interception of an Iraqi freighter in the Arabian Sea. The protesters marched from downtown Baghdad to the U.S. and British embassies, singing patriotic songs and shouting slogans denouncing the interception of the ``peace ship.'' The Iraqi freighter was seized Wednesday by U.S. and other forces. It was reportedly carrying sugar to Iraq in violation of the U.N. trade embargo. -Iran test-fired a Soviet-made, SA-6 anti-aircraft missile, acknowledging for the first time that it had acquired the advanced long-range weapon. A Tehran radio broadcast did not say where the surface-to-air missile was fired, or how many of the advanced weapons Iran has bought. Iraq in August agreed to Iranian conditions to end the 1980-88 war between the two nations. -Jordan has beefed up its security forces along the cease-fire line with Israel as a precaution against a surprise attack by the Jewish state, Jordanian military sources said. They declined to give any figures of military strength along Jordan's western border. Israel's military has been on alert since Iraq invaded Kuwait and said it would retaliate if Iraq attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Governor Signs Stringent Clean-Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a clean air bill Thursday that goes beyond new federal requirements for auto emissions in limiting pollutants blamed for acid rain and the greenhouse effect. The measure is based on California's tough new standards. Supporters said Massachusetts is the first state in the nation to go along with California's tighter controls. State Rep. David Cohen, who sponsored the bill, said last week's passage of the standards in Massachusetts may encourage other states to follow. ``There are many, many states that are looking at doing what we did, but they were afraid,'' Cohen said. ``Massachusetts was a trailblazer in this action.'' ``We hope to create a domino effect,'' said Jenny Carter of the Massachusetts Public Interest Research Group. Massachusetts air quality failed to meet federal health standards on at least 40 days during the past three summers. ``This law will help reverse that trend,'' Carter said. New York also is considering the California standards, said Benjamin Marvin of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. The Massachusetts bill says the new standards will be phased in beginning in 1993, but in reality state officials reached a verbal agreement with automobile manufacturers to start the program with the 1995 model year. Carter said she expects most manufacturers will adapt to the new law by refining catalytic converters. She estimated that the measure would cost consumers an extra $170 when they buy a new car, but tighter warranty standards included in the new law would help defray that one-time cost. The plan calls on car makers to cut smog-causing hydrocarbon and nitrogen oxide emissions by 50 percent to 75 percent beyond what is required under the new federal Clean Air Act, averaged over their entire fleet. Dukakis said the federal government must do more to fight pollution and to save energy so that the United States becomes less dependent on foreign energy supplies. ``There's one other way to clean the air and that's to make automobiles more efficient,'' Dukakis said. An operator at General Motors Corp. in Detroit said company officials would not be available to comment because of the holidays, and a recorded message at Ford Motor Co. said offices there are closed until Jan. 2. Dukakis also signed two other environmental bills, one to protect endangered species and the second to make local conservation commission members front-line agents in monitoring wetlands protection laws. The endangered species bill protects the habitat of threatened species from alteration. It also establishes a process for listing species as endangered, threatened or of special concern and prohibits the taking or selling of species that make the list. The wetlands conservation measure gives local conservation commissioners the power to protect wetlands. In 1988, the state's Supreme Judicial Court ruled that the conservation commission lacked authority to enforce the wetlands protection act.

DOC.HEAD: Burglars Left Without a Paddle
DOC.TEXT: Police say the larcenous hopes of two boat burglars were dashed when they realized they were up a creek without a paddle. ``Their master plan is to burglarize the boat, load up the dinghy and make good their escape,'' said Detective Bill Wagner. ``What happens is they get the dinghy loaded and realize it has no oars.'' A 19-inch television, a 13-inch television and several bottles of liquor were abandoned in the dinghy Christmas Eve, but the thieves then turned their attention to a nearby house. Rolex watches, 40 figurines and other household goods were stolen and fenced, police said. A car parked in the driveway made a getaway possible the second time. Police later arrested Marvin Lee Jones, 25, in the house burglary. A second suspect remains at large.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: Don't believe report of non-readiness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; edits to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he was ``very comfortable'' with the state of readiness by U.S. military forces in the Persian Gulf, despite concerns expressed by military commanders that the force won't be fully prepared for offensive action until mid-February. ``I feel that the situation is exactly where I was told it was going to be at this time,'' Bush told reporters at the White House. ``Don't believe those reports you're reading'' that readiness is lagging. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, and has authorized the use of force after that date to evict Iraqi forces. The United States will have more than 400.000 troops in the region by the time the current buildup is complete. Bush also said there had been no progress in efforts to work out a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Baghdad to discuss a peaceful situation to the gulf situation. The president, briefly interrupting a Camp David vacation, also met with Soviet Ambassador Alexander Bessmertnykh. The diplomat delivered a letter from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Aides said they did not know the content of the message, which came as the Soviet Union is embroiled in domestic political turmoil. Bush's comments on the Persian Gulf were the latest in a series of mixed signals about readiness for military action. Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, a senior commander in Saudi Arabia, told reporters last week that U.S. forces would not be fully ready for offensive action until mid February. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who met with area commanders in the Middle East, concluded his visit by saying ``the situation is not improving'' with regard to Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and ``the days are drawing closer when we may be forced to resort to military force.'' Bush said that Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made a report to him after their trip to the Gulf that was ``quite different than most stories I've been reading in the last few days'' in newspapers. At the same time, Bush did not directly deny reports from the New York Times and other news organizations that Cheney and Bush had relayed the concerns of military officers about U.S. troop readiness. ``I'm not going to tell you what they said, but I'm going to tell you, don't believe these reports you're reading.'' ``It's under control. I've got total confidence in the chairman of the joint chiefs, and the secretary of defense and our commander out there to whom I talked over the holidays ... don't be misled by these rabbit trails running through the snow out there.'' He challenged reporters to ``show me the quotes'' from Cheney and Powell and dismissed the stories as ``rumors of what somebody is alleged to have told me.''. Told the stories were in the newspapers, he said, ``That doesn't make it right.'' Bush also expressed seeming irritation with the public comments made in recent days on the subject. ``I think it would be very useful if from the president and others there were fewer comments about readiness ... There's been enough said about readiness,'' Bush said. The president addressed the subject twice during the day - once in a hallway encounter with reporters and again before boarding his helicopter for a return trip to Camp David. Bush, a well-known workaholic, denied he had returned to the White House for the day because he was bored, as an official had said. ``Do I look bored?'' he said. Bush telephoned French President Francois Mitterrand and former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Monday from Camp David, said spokesman Doug Davidson. He told reporters today that while on vacation, he was ``staying in very close touch'' with the developments in the Gulf. Asked about prospects for the proposed meeting between Baker and Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, he said, ``There's nothing going on on that front.'' The two countries have been unable to agree on a date for the meeting to discuss the gulf situation. U.S. officials say the Iraqis insist on Jan. 12, while the administration wants the meeting no later than Jan. 3, contending that a later date would give Saddam Hussein time to stall on getting his troops out of Kuwait by the deadline.

DOC.HEAD: Menem Reluctantly Says He'll Turn Over Controversial Ferrari
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem weathered a month of criticism before reluctantly deciding he'll turn over the keys to a controversial red Ferrari - once he gets out of office. The luxury sports car, reported to be worth $100,000, became a political lemon for Menem after it was first seen parked at his official residence Nov. 20. Menem, an avid sportsman and amateur rally car driver, at first was thrilled by the gift from the Italian motorcycle company Ducati Meccanica. But last week he grudgingly told the weekly newsmagazine Gente: ``As I am very respectful of laws, I'm going to leave this car as property of the nation (when my term ends in 1995).'' Argentine law stipulates that any gift over a certain value belongs to the presidency, and must be handed over upon completion of office. By Menem's own admission, before the criticism he had no intention of turning over the keys. ``It's mine, mine, mine,'' the 60-year-old president told a nationally broadcast interview show. The car was a gift from Ducati chief G. Franco Castiglioni. In an accompanying letter, he said he felt honored by Menem's visit to Rome during the soccer World Cup matches last summer, and bestowed the Ferrari 348 TB on Menem ``So you don't forget Italy.'' But questions kept popping up in newspaper columns, magazine stories, radio talk shows and cocktail conversations. How could Menem, who is cracking down on tax evasion, accept a personal gift that bypassed customs duties of $170,000 and arrived apparently free of charge via the state airline? What kind of example was Menem, who has denounced corruption among public officials, setting by saying it was acceptable to accept a gift worth several times one's annual salary? And what did it say about a president who urges his countrymen to tighten their belts amid a recession as severe as any this century, but who doesn't appear willing to share their sacrifices? ``What is at issue is his reputation for political shrewdness,'' the English-language Buenos Aires Herald commented. ``His `mine, mine, mine' attitude ... suggests a dangerous lack of restraint or willful greed or a childish streak or a tragic flaw of some kind.'' In the Gente interview, Menem called suggestions he should have immediately donated the car to charity ``stupid hypocrisy.'' ``They (Ducati) gave it to me. Why should people be scandalized?'' he was quoted as saying. Argentine law stipulates that any gift over a certain value belongs to the presidency, and must be handed over upon completion of office. Menem, a touch grudgingly, said he will do just that. ``But meanwhile, I'm going to use it myself,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: OAS Calls Meeting on Suriname Coup
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States summoned member states to a special meeting Friday to discuss a Venezuelan request for prompt action to restore the constitutional government in Suriname. The president of the Washington-based OAS's permanent council, Juan Pablo Lohle of Argentina, on Thursday issued a formal communique calling the meeting at Venezuela's request. Venezuelan Ambassador Guido Grooscors said the Christmas Eve coup was a ``severe violation of the principles of the OAS charter'' and should not be sanctioned. Grooscors called for the OAS to convene in emergency session in Washington but said the meeting may have to be delayed because many ambassadors are away for the holidays. On Wednesday, the Venezuelan Foreign Ministry said it would refuse to recognize Suriname's new military government, and asked for a ``firm response'' to the bloodless coup that ousted President Ramsewak Shankar. Shankar had served two years of the term to which he was elected in November 1987. Shankar was ousted in an uprising led by acting army chief Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, who has pledged to hold elections within 100 days and relinquish power. The Bush administration has condemned the takeover and has advised Americans not to travel to the former Dutch colony. Brazil, which holds good trade relations with Suriname and is reportedly its largest South American creditor, Thursday did not appear to consider any special action necessary. A spokesman for the Brazilian embassy in Caracas said that Brazil viewed the coup as an ``internal affair,'' and said: ``The position of Brazil is not to intervene.''

DOC.HEAD: Laser Videodiscs Replace Textbooks in Some Science Classrooms
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A fourth grade class was studying electricity and the image of a lightning bolt was frozen on the TV screen. Then teacher Rodelle Tompkins touched the remote control and zapped the bolt to life, and her science class was off on an energetic discussion. It was just the sort of reaction educators hope videodisc textbooks will create, especially in once unapproachable subjects such as science. ``It's more funner than reading a book,'' said Nathan Young. ``It's easier - there's no reading and writing,'' said classmate Martin Maniha. Laser videodisc textbooks have been in use in an estimated 7,000 U.S. schools, but Texas is the first state to allow districts to use textbook money to buy them. The 12-inch discs, resembling the smaller compact disc used for music, can show still and moving pictures on a television screen, and without having to close window shades and turn out lights. The discs also provide higher quality sound and image than videotape, allow the use of freeze frame - like the lightning bolt - without loss of detail, and can hold information equivalent to 54,000 photographic slides on each side. Mrs. Tompkins, who says her former school district in the Rio Grande Valley ``was lucky to get a book, let alone videodiscs,'' says the videodiscs provide more information by exciting a greater portion of the class. And she says they're better than movies. ``When you turn off the lights (to show a movie), the bottom 3 percent of the class goes to sleep, and the top 5 percent have already seen it,'' she said. But a noisy minority of Mrs. Tompkins' pupils at Lamkin Elementary School prefer curling up with an old-fashioned book to watching their science project go by at MTV speed. ``It's better to learn when you read by yourself,'' said Colleen Wade. And Brian Bassi added: ``I don't like it that much. I think reading is better than just watching and listening.'' ``Reaching kids is an extra big problem in science teaching these days,'' said Phyllis Marcuccio, assistant executive director of the National Science Teachers Association in Washington. ``The volume of scientific information is so much greater these days, it's hard to get across in books,'' Ms. Marcuccio said, adding that videodiscs also allow children to see people working, which could ``open up career dimensions for them.'' The videodisc program Windows on Science, produced by Optical Data Corp. of Warren, N.J., comes with a suggested script for teachers and workbooks for the students. One laserdisc program costs about $1,000, but that's considered comparable to textbooks for a class because of the amount of data each one provides and that it can be used over and over. Although Optical Data's ``Windows on Science'' program, which teaches biology, geology and elementary physics, is the only approved electronic textbook in Texas, other programs in social studies and health are becoming popular, said Optical Data spokeswoman Pam Herber. Those programs include a history-through-geography program, similar to National Geographic television shows, and a program partly produced by ABC News on current events such as the Middle East, the 1988 presidential campaign and AIDS. Although some pupils may still prefer books, educators say that teaching science electronically can increase the number of video generation children turned on by once unapproachable subjects. ``Just because he can't read doesn't mean he can't think,'' Mrs. Tompkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Tapping from Capsized Barge Indicates Some Crew Alive
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers working Thursday in a snowstorm and heavy winds off the Finnish coast said they heard tapping inside a capsized barge, a sign that some of the 10 men aboard may be alive. Rescuers worked into the night, long after winter darkness fell over the Baltic Sea at mid-afternoon. Winds of 54 knots were expected to slow overnight but the water temperature was 36 degrees. The Finnish barge Finn-Baltic overturned at about 1 p.m. (6 a.m. EST) in rough waters off the southwestern port of Hanko. The 550-foot-long, 15,000-ton vessel was carrying iron ore between Finnish ports. Rescuers expressed concern that the coastal pilot and 9 crewmen aboard the pusher section of the craft had drowned. The barge was reported entirely submerged, several yards below the surface of the sea. Jan-Eric Dahlberg of FG Shipping, the barge owner, said divers who tapped on the hull heard answering taps from the men inside, all believed to be Finns. Finnish news media quoted Captain Lars Boxstrom of the Gulf of Finland Maritime Rescue Center as saying, ``If there are people in the vessel, it is completely possible they are still alive because inside the vessel there is an air pocket.'' Later, officials said the barge drifted into shallower water and that part of it was 13 feet above the surface, enabling rescuers to walk on the hull. They speculated that the craft became stuck on the seabed. Dahlberg said an attempt could be made to cut open the hull with an acetylene torch, if the water was not too rough. News reports said oxygen was being pumped into the upturned barge.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Tightens Smoking Rules for Employees
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency announced Thursday that employees may no longer routinely smoke inside EPA offices and facilities. The EPA directive, aimed at protecting nonsmokers from passive smoke, applies to 120 agency facilities nationwide. The agency said that employees will be provided with separate smoking lounges equipped with special ventilation systems. The previous EPA policy allowed smoking in other designated areas as well as in restrooms and sections of cafeterias. The new smoking policy comes as the EPA staff is considering a draft study that concludes there is considerable evidence that passive smoke causes lung cancer. A final report on the draft study, which has been widely distributed, is expected to be issued sometime next year.

DOC.HEAD: Unwanted Boulder Has a New Owner
DOC.TEXT: One of Alaska's most famous rocks - a cause celebre after a car wash owner sued city hall to move it - has a new owner. Mac Mackintosh lost his fight in small claims court last week when he tried to get $3,000 in back rent from the city of Homer for a boulder left in his car wash parking lot. But the saga of the unwanted rock had a happy ending Wednesday, when Shawn Kinney bought it for $1 and paid $125 to have it delivered by forklift as a Christmas present for her husband, Mark. ``He's one of those people who for years, at birthdays and Christmas, says, `Oh, I don't need anything,''' Shawn Kinney said. ``Then my son came home one afternoon and said, `I found out what Dad wants. He wants the rock at the car wash.''' Movers hoisted the boulder Wednesday with a 26-ton forklift used for unloading containers from ships. Even the forklift proved barely up to the task. It took all afternoon to pry the rock from the soil and carry it 100 yards uphill to the Kinneys' house. The boulder, which weighs between 25 tons and 35 tons and is the size of small sports car, became news after Mackintosh sue the city last October. He claimed the boulder was excavated during a city street-widening project and left in the lot when the car wash had a different owner. Mackintosh told the city that its boulder was blocking his efforts to expand his business. ``They were laughing me out of their office like it was a big joke,'' said the 45-year-old entrepreneur. ``It may seem like a joke to an outsider, but it's not a joke if you're stuck with a rock this size.'' City manager C.E. Swackhammer said the boulder wasn't the city's responsibility. He said he spent several thousand dollars in employee time fighting Mackintosh's lawsuit because he was concerned about a precedent putting the city in the boulder-moving business. ``It would have been cheaper for me to have moved the rock,'' Swackhammer said. ``But other people have rocks.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Ends Congress After Getting his Vice President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Yanayev is pronounced Yah-NEYE-yev.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto MOSB10,4,5,6,MOS15
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev turned defeat into victory Thursday by persuading lawmakers to approve his choice for the Soviet Union's first vice president, a new post in a reorganized federal government. The vote came on the last day of a stormy, 10-day session of the Congress of People's Deputies. It was representative of the entire legislative meeting, during which Gorbachev got much of what he wanted - but not without a struggle. The Congress had endorsed Gorbachev's draft of a treaty to hold together the crumbling union, and approved his proposals for national referendums on whether to allow private ownership of land and whether to preserve the union. It also accepted his plan to strengthen presidential power. Early Thursday, legislators handed Gorbachev what appeared to be his biggest defeat, rejecting his candidate for the vice presidency - Gennady I. Yanayev - by 31 votes. But Gorbachev insisted on his choice, requested a second vote, and Yanayev was approved. Yanayev, a relatively obscure 53-year-old Communist bureaucrat, said he saw the vote as a referendum on Gorbachev. ``The vote this afternoon relates not only to me, but the policies of the president,'' Yanayev told reporters. Yanayev was the only candidate for vice president, a post created as part of the reorganized federal government hierarchy that was adopted by legislators Wednesday. The vice president assists the chief executive and, under a constitutional amendment, ``replaces the president of the U.S.S.R. in case of his absence and inability to carry out his duties.'' Legislators at first balked at giving the relatively unknown Yanayev such a potentially powerful, visible job,. Some said they wanted a candidate who had more experience with the economy. The first vote Thursday by the country's highest legislative body was 1,089 for Yanayev and 583 against. He needed at least 1,120 votes, a simple majority of the 2,239 registered deputies. But Gorbachev, stone-faced, ignored calls from lawmakers to put forward a different candidate. He said it was important the vice president be someone in whom he had complete confidence. ``The fact that only 583 deputies or 25 percent of the Congress voted against Comrade Yanayev persuades me to ask the Congress to vote again,'' he said. Radical economist Oleg Bogomolov, a Congress delegate, said Yanayev lost the first vote because the bureaucrat is ``a representative of the party leadership and central committee apparatus. He's very obedient, very conformist.'' Yuri Golikh, chairman of the law enforcement committee of the Supreme Soviet legislature, said: ``I think he didn't win because the deputies didn't have a feel for him as a leader. ``He has not spoken on serious, philosophical, conceptual topics in either the Congress or the Supreme Soviet,'' Golikh said. Yuri Kalmykov, chairman of the jurisprudence committee, said many deputies wanted ``someone with experience in industry and economics.'' Nevertheless, after the renomination, several lawmakers rose to praise Yanayev and to urge support for Gorbachev. Marshall Sergei F. Akhromeyev, a presidential adviser and former armed forces chief of staff, urged all deputies to vote in the second round. On the second ballot, deputies voted 1,230-563 for Yanayev. The remaining ballots were not filled out or were declared invalid. After an official announced the result of the ballot, legislators, joined by Gorbachev sitting on the rostrum, applauded. Yanayev, sitting in a special section for party and government officials, stood to acknowledge the applause. Gorbachev had initially planned to nominate Eduard A. Shevardnadze for the job. But Shevardnadze resigned as foreign minister last week to protest what he said was a drift toward dictatorship. In comments to the legislature after being nominated Wednesday, Yanayev, an ethnic Russian, supported Gorbachev's reformist policies but also took a somewhat hard-line tack, calling for law and order. Yanayev belonged to the Communist Party youth organization, Komsomol. In the early 1970s he came to Moscow as chairman of the U.S.S.R. Committee of Youth Organizations. He wrote his dissertation on international youth movements. In the 1980s, he served for six years as deputy chairman of the Soviet Friendship Society, which maintains non-governmental contacts with foreigners. He later returned to party work, becoming a secretary of the policy-making Central Committee. He was elected to the party's ruling Politburo in July after a party shake-up that also significantly reduced its authority. Yanayev is leader in parliament of the 730-member Communist bloc.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item to CORRECT spelling to Morvan sted Norvam
DOC.TEXT: John Davis, one of the real voices behind the pop music facade Milli Vanilli, says he's finally getting some recognition. ``Everywhere I go now, when I'm getting on a plane, people wave and say, `There goes the Milli Vanilli guy,' '' Davis said during a holiday visit to his parents. Davis, 36, gained attention when German record producer Frank Farian revealed Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan did not sing a note of Milli Vanilli's mega-selling debut album. The real voices were Charles Shaw, Brad Howell and Davis, a 1972 graduate of Anderson's Westside High School. The group, minus Pilatus, Morvan, and the name ``Milli Vanilli,'' has an Arista Records album coming out Jan. 20, tentatively titled, ``Keep on Running.'' The pop duo was forced to give back their Grammy won for best new artist after it was revealed that they did not sing on their hit album ``Girl You Know It's True'' and were lip syncing the words in concert.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty in Drugged Spaghetti Case
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: A man pleaded guilty Thursday to felony sex charges for feeding drug-laced spaghetti to two women and then sexually assaulting them. Nicola Iannone, 35, who had fled to Italy, was ordered jailed without bail pending sentencing Jan. 24 on two counts of gross sexual imposition involving the women on Feb. 23, 1988. He could be sentenced to 1{ years in prison and fined $2,500 on each count. As part of a plea bargain, prosecutors dropped charges of rape and corrupting another with drugs. They also dropped similar charges involving an alleged victim in October 1987; the person in that case moved out of state and could not be found, said Chris Van Harlingen, an assistant prosecutor. Ms. Van Harlingen said the two women who were assaulted in 1988 did not object to the plea bargain. An arrest warrant was issued for Iannone after he failed to show up for arraignment in May 1988. The FBI announced in March 1989 that Iannone had been found in Milan, Italy. Iannone had lost an extradition proceeding in Italy and was appealing it when he decided to return to the United States and face the charges, said his lawyer, Martin Pinales. Iannone was jailed for 15 months in Italy while the extradition proceedings were pending. Iannone returned from Italy last week. ``It gets the entire matter behind him,'' Pinales told reporters after the hearing. ``He didn't want it hanging over his head.'' Iannone's victims alleged that after he fed them a pasta dinner at their Cincinnati apartment, they lost consciousness and woke up the next day with their clothes off. The charges Iannone pleaded guilty to alleged that he gave the women drugs, either by force or deception, and had sexual contact with both of them. Police said laboratory analysis found the leftover spaghetti contained codeine and the prescription sedatives Valium and Elavil. Iannone, an Italian-born naturalized U.S. citizen, worked as a restaurant consultant in Cincinnati and Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: General Extradited From U.S. To Be Pardoned
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem said Thursday he will pardon a general who was extradited from the United States to stand trial for murders committed during the 1976-83 dictatorship. The general, Carlos Suarez Mason, commanded an army corps responsible for the greater Buenos Aires area during the military's ``dirty war'' against suspected leftist subversives. More than half of the 8,960 people who the government said were arrested and presumed killed during the crackdown came from his area. Menem said the general will be included in a pardon that will also free from jail former generals and military presidents Jorge Videla and Roberto Viola, and Mario Eduardo Firmenich, co-founder of the leftist Montonero guerrillas. The presidential decree, due by year's end, is necessary for national reconciliation, Menem told reporters. ``The pardons are going to cancel a sad stage of the past that we have to overcome,'' said Menem, referring to four army insurrections since 1987 and other signs of unresolved emotions that stem from the military's ``dirty war'' against subversion. The pardon is opposed by religious and human rights groups, jurists, leftist political parties and, polls show, between 60 and 80 percent of all Argentines. Suarez Mason, 66, has been in jail since arriving in handcuffs from California in May 1988. However, his trial on 39 separate charges of murder was continually postponed, in part because of the political nature of the case. Suarez Mason led the First Army Corps following the March 1976 overthrow of President Isabel Peron. In 1978, he was promoted to chairman of the joint chiefs of staff. Upon retiring in 1981, he was named president of the state oil monopoly YPF, a post which he held until 1982. Raul Alfonsin, president from 1983-89, personally ordered Suarez Mason's trial. Prosecutors wanted to charge him with 635 human rights abuses, including 23 counts of kidnapping and 43 counts of murder; and misappropriating $2 million from YPF. However, under terms of the extradition, Suarez Mason may be prosecuted only for the 39 charges of murder, which allegedly were committed by troops under his command. For fleeing in 1984, when Videla, Viola and other junta leaders were about to go on trial, Suarez Mason was cashiered by his fellow generals. Suarez Mason eventually settled under an assumed name in Foster City, Calif., a suburb of San Francisco. He was arrested in January 1987. The Menem government, in power since July 1989, apparently first intended to exclude Suarez Mason from the pardon of the handful of officers and terrorists not already pardoned. However, Menem said the trial of Suarez Mason would only inflame public passions if he called officers to appear in his defense. Menem said such a trial would only renew public debate about the crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: FDA To Spot Check Milk For Antibiotics
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday it will test raw milk weekly around the nation to determine if it contains certain antibiotics. The agency said 250 locations across the country will be chosen for testing and raw milk samples will be collected each week from five of these sites, selected randomly. The samples will be tested for the presence of eight sulfa drugs and three tetracycline drugs. The FDA said that when residues are found, the states will be told and the agency will help track down the source. ``As newer analytical methods become available, milk will be monitored for additional drugs,'' the FDA said in a statement. ``The system will add another layer of protection for consumers.'' Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., attacked the plan as inadequate. ``Testing five milk samples per week means that each processing location in FDA's program will be visited only once a year,'' he said in a statement. ``FDA's attempt to describe this as a nationwide program is ludicrous. To even call it a modest proposal is a wild exaggeration.'' Weiss, who is chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on human resources, conducted hearings earlier this year on the FDA's milk-testing methods. He said more hearings may be needed ``to examine whether the agency purposely designed a plan that would not find any residues. ``FDA's paltry effort will tell the public virtually nothing about the true extent of animal drug residues in milk,'' said the congressman. In November, Weiss released a General Accounting Office study that recommended the FDA work with dairy states to improve screening tests for residues of drugs in milk. The GAO study said the agency should also test, on a random basis, the types and amounts of drug residues found in state screening samples. Raw and processed milk that is susceptible to interstate shipment is now tested by states for penicillin and penicillin-related drug products. The tests are not conducted routinely, however, for other antibiotic residues, such as sulfa and tetracycline drugs. Under the current program, the 50 states and the District of Columbia test milk samples from every U.S. dairy farm at least four times every six months. Antibiotics are often used by veterinarians to treat infections in dairy cattle. Testing is conducted to determine if residues from the drugs are present in the milk.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Grand Jury Investigates House Speaker
With AM-Ethics-Speakers
DOC.TEXT: Texas House Speaker Gib Lewis, who weathered charges of unethical conduct to win re-election last month, admits he went on a lobbyist-paid junket to Mexico. A topless dancer reportedly went along but Lewis says he doesn't remember. The trip is one of a variety of issues a grand jury apparently is examining as it investigates ties between Texas legislators and lobbyists. Since the grand jury convened in November, the investigation has spread into allegations of misconduct by up to 20 current and former lawmakers and lobbyists, according to Travis County District Attorney Ronnie Earle. ``The general subject has to do with the Legislature and its relationship to the lobby,'' Earle said. The grand jury's session was expanded for three months beyond its original Dec. 31 expiration date. Lewis, 54, is the best known legislator caught up in the investigation. He was invited to appear before the panel Thursday, but said he would decline the invitation unless Earle would say how he is connected to the investigation. Like Lewis, speakers in New York and California are under a cloud as the three states prepare for new legislative sessions. New York state Assembly Speaker Mel Miller has pleaded innocent to federal mail fraud charges stemming from an alleged real estate scam. Miller claims the charges, which are not connected to his legislative office, are politically motivated. California Assembly Speaker Willie Brown reportedly is being investigated about allegations that he was involved in legislation aimed at helping a regional garbage company get around local restrictions on landfills. Brown has not been charged with any crime and his spokesman has denied any impropriety on Brown's part. The Texas investigation reportedly has focused on trips taken by Lewis, one of the top three officials in state government, to Mexico and the Caribbean with members of the law firm of Heard Goggan Blair & Williams. During the past eight years, Heard Goggan has used a little-noticed revision in state law to become one of only a few firms that can collect delinquent taxes. The law allows a private firm hired by local governments to collect a 15 percent fee on top of overdue tax bills. County attorneys collecting taxes cannot add the fee, and legislative records show that numerous bills that would have diminished Heard Goggan's tax-collecting business died in House committees. Oliver Heard Jr., a spokesman for the San Antonio law firm, said he was not on the trip and had no personal knowledge of it. ``We're cooperating fully with the investigation,'' Heard added. Lewis, a Democrat from Fort Worth, has been speaker for eight years, controlling the House by assigning bills to committees, naming their chairmen and directing floor debate. He is seeking an unprecedented fifth term in January. Lewis' admitted trip to Mexico in April 1987 appears to have attracted most of the investigators' attention. Six women, including a topless dancer named Chrissee, accompanied Lewis, four partners in the law firm and an Austin lobbyist to a resort on the Pacific coast of Mexico, the Houston Chronicle has reported. Lewis denied any wrongdoing and said he doesn't remember a topless dancer or anyone named Chrissee on the trip. He said he welcomes the inquiry bu has accused Earle of ``spoonfeeding'' grand jurors selective evidence. ``I think they are pretty much on a rabbit chase,'' Lewis said. ``But I'm glad they're doing it. ... I want to cooperate with them, do everything I can, because I think the air needs to be cleared.'' The media have reported for two years about lavish spending by special interest lobbyists trying to influence the Legislature and other state officials. Gov.-elect Ann Richards and Lt. Gov.-elect Bob Bullock have promised that ethics reform will be a top priority when the Legislature convenes Jan. 8. Despite the grand jury investigation, Lewis' re-election as speaker appears secure. Lewis has been involved in such controversies before. He was fined for failing to disclose his business ties, criticized for taking other lobbyist-paid trips, embroiled in a scandal involving state stocking of deer, elk, turkey and black bass on his ranch, and accused of killing bills opposed by his lobbyist friends. He recently retained two former prosecutors who worked for Earle to represent him in the current ethics investigation. And he hired two former aides to Richards to handle relations with the media.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ethics Probe, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Legislative leaders in the three most populous states are under an ethical cloud as legislators prepare for the New Year. Here is a glance at the speakers and the problems they face:

California Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, a San Francisco Democrat, reportedly is being investigated by federal authorities for his alleged involvement in legislation aimed at helping a regional garbage company get around local restrictions on landfills during the mid- to late 1980s. The company was a client of Brown's at the time the various bills were moving through the Legislature, paying him at least $70,000 in legal fees. Some of the bills were approved, others vetoed by the governor. Brown, the second-most powerful state official in California, has not been charged with any crime. According to newspaper reports, witnesses who testified before a federal grand jury said that the panel's interests appeared to be focused on Brown. Brown's spokesman, Michael Reese, has denied any impropriety on Brown's part.

Assembly Speaker Mel Miller pleaded innocent Dec. 20 to federal mail fraud charges involving allegations of a real estate scam. Miller, a Democrat from New York City, and top aide and former law partner Jay Adolf were indicted on 19 counts of mail fraud, conspiracy and falsifying documents. The charges relate to Miller's private law practice and not his position as a legislator. Miller, 51, has been in the state Assembly since 1970 and was elected speaker in 1987. He is state government's second most powerful Democrat, behind Gov. Mario Cuomo. Miller has charged that the indictment amounted to a political witch hunt. ``The only thing I'm guilty of is being speaker of the New York state Assembly. I have done nothing,'' Miller said. ``We believe the crimes are being brought because I'm a very nice victim and it would be wonderful to put my scalp in someone's belt.''

House Speaker Gib Lewis is the most prominent name caught up in a state grand jury investigation into ties between lobbyists and legislators. The investigation has focused on trips taken by Lewis, a Democrat from Fort Worth, to Mexico and the Caribbean with members of a law firm that collects delinquent taxes. Lewis, 54, admits going on a trip to Mexico in April 1987, although he has disputed reports that one of six women along was a topless dancer from Houston. The controversy does not appear to weaken Lewis' chances next month at winning an unprecedented fifth two-year term as speaker.

DOC.HEAD: Albania's Communist Party Pledges to Give Up Monopoly On Power
DOC.TEXT: Albania's Communist president has pledged to relinquish the party's constitutionally guaranteed leading role in society, the state news agency reported Thursday. But the new opposition party said the Communists were not moving toward real democracy. It said it would continue to press for postponement of Feb. 10 elections so it has time to prepare, and suggested that a referendum be held to set the date for the first multiparty ballot since the Communists took power in 1944. President Ramiz Alia, facing mounting student protests and the threat of economic collapse, has sped up reform in this Stalinist nation. He legalized an opposition party this month for the first time since the country fell under Communist rule. Speaking at a national party conference Wednesday, Alia said officials must ``deviate from many principles of socialism'' as the nation dismantles its hard-line system. According a report Thursday from the official ATA news agency, Alia also said Parliament would begin action on constitutional amendments immediately after the Feb. 10 elections, in which the party will face opposition candidates for the first time. The Communist Party would demand ``upon its own initiative and free will ... changing the article in the constitution fixing juridically its leading role in the state system,'' Alia said. Until student protests earlier this month, Albania had refused to stray from Communist orthodoxy. In his speech Wednesday, Alia stressed that despite the reforms the party ``does not intend to abandon its Marxist ideology.'' He promised, however, to reform the party and, in a further sign of the country's emergence from decades of self-imposed isolation, to allow Albanians to work abroad. In the unusually frank speech, he acknowledged that the economic situation was ``grave'' because of a severe drought this past year, reduced exports and productivity, and a failure to fulfill centrally-planned targets. But a Democratic Party co-founder, Gramoz Pashko, said from Tirana Thursday that the Communists were ``not moving forward for realistic democratization of the country.'' He charged that Alia's pledges for economic reform ``were only on paper'' as long as the party continues to cling to Marxism. Pashko said that in the opposition's view, the Communists had to ``make a detailed analysis of the crisis. ... This is needed to figure out how to emerge from the situation.'' Alia has edged cautiously toward reform but the Communists still control virtually every sphere of public life. On Monday, the government rejected the opposition's request to postpone the elections for two or three months to allow it more time to prepare an effective campaign. In July, thousands of Albanians complaining of political repression and economic hardship streamed into foreign embassies and refused to leave until they were allowed to emigrate. Passports have been theoretically available to Albanians since May, but few of the backward nation's 3.2 million citizens have the hard currency needed for foreign travel.

DOC.HEAD: Court Throws Out Case Against Omni Magazine
DOC.TEXT: New York state's top court Thursday threw out a $30 million lawsuit filed against Omni magazine by a couple angered that their family photo illustrated an article about coffee's effect on fertility. The state Court of Appeals said in a unanimous decision it was reluctant to second-guess an editorial decision. Trial level and appellate courts also had rejected the family's lawsuit. Joseph and Ida Finger of Saugerties, N.Y., and their six children were pictured beside an article titled ``Caffeine and Fast Sperm'' in Omni's June 1988 issue. The article discussed medical research that indicated in vitro fertilization rates may be enhanced by exposing sperm to high concentrations of caffeine. ``Want a big family?'' the photograph's caption read. ``Maybe your sperm needs a cup of java in the morning. Tests reveal that caffeine-spritzed sperm swim faster, which may increase the chances for in vitro fertilization.'' The couple, who conceived their children naturally, had been photographed for an article in a Catholic publication, said their lawyer, Paul Gruner. They weren't aware that a photo service had given their picture to Omni until a friend showed Mrs. Finger the magazine, he said. ``When it became known in a small community, the children were the subject of some ridicule,'' Gruner said. The couple argued that their civil rights were violated because the picture was used without permission. State law prohibits the use of a photograph without consent for purposes of advertising or trade. Court of Appeals Judge Fritz Alexander noted that courts have consistently refused to apply the civil rights law to news articles, limiting those interpretations to advertising. ``Questions of `newsworthiness' are better left to reasonable editorial judgment and discretion,'' Alexander wrote. Alexander said the Fingers had a misperception about the theme of the article, which the judge said was more about increased fertility than in vitro or ``test tube'' fertilization. The judge said there's clearly a ``real relationship'' between the fertility theme and a picture of six healthy, attractive children who all bear a striking resemblance to their parents. Laura Handman, lawyer for Omni, said the article made it very clear that the medical findings are only in the laboratory stages. ``You have to assume a certain degree of common sense by the reader,'' Handman said. ``I don't think there's been any family created by six cases of in vitro fertilization - coffee or no coffee.'' But Gruner said the decision gives the press too much freedom to use pictures of people with articles that have nothing to do with them.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: `Don't Believe' US Forces Aren't Ready
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday sought to stem reports that U.S. forces aren't yet ready for offensive action in the Persian Gulf, saying he was ``very comfortable'' with the firepower on hand. However, he declined to directly deny reports that the troops will not be prepared to launch an attack by Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. At one point during questioning on the matter, Bush told reporters at the White House ``I've said all I want to say about readiness.'' ``I think it would be very useful if from the president and others there were fewer comments about readiness,'' he said. ``I feel that the situation is exactly where I was told it was going to be at this time,'' Bush said. ``Don't believe those reports you're reading,'' he said, referring to accounts that his military advisers have warned him that the U.S. force will not be suitably prepared for offensive action until mid-February. By then, more than 400,000 troops and much more armor will be deployed in the region. ``We're going to fully implement the United Nations resolutions,'' which authorize force to get Iraqi troops out of Kuwait, he said. ``The United States will do its part to fulfill every single one of them.'' He made the comments to reporters who encountered him in a White House hallway, and later to a group gathered to watch him fly off to resume his vacation at Camp David, Md., after returning to the White House for part of the day. Bush met Thursday morning with the Soviet ambassador, Alexander Bessmertnykh, who delivered a message from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Bush said the message contained ``friendly words of greeting from President Gorbachev, and I had a chance to ... ask the ambassador to give him our best wishes for a happy new year.'' He said he discussed with the Soviet envoy the current domestic turmoil in the Soviet Union, where Gorbachev is struggling to keep a lid on the explosive tug-of-war between reformers and conservatives, and the challenge to his own position. Bush said there had been ``no progress'' on setting a meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to discuss a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. Still, he said, he hopes for a peaceful solution. The Iraqis have insisted the Baghdad meeting be Jan. 12, but Bush said there will be ``no compromise'' on the U.S. position of scheduling it no later than Jan. 3. Referring to a meeting earlier this week with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, after their visit to the gulf, Bush said, ``I'm very comfortable with the briefing, and the briefing I had was quite different than most of the stories I'm reading in the last day or two.'' The New York Times and Washington Post both cited unidentified sources this week as saying the top military advisers warned him the troops would not be ready to launch an attack by Jan. 15. The president challenged reporters Thursday to ``show me the quotes'' from Cheney and Powell, and dismissed the stories as ``rumors of what somebody is alleged to have told me.''. Asked what they did tell him, Bush said, ``I'm not going to tell you what they said, but I'm going to tell you, don't believe these reports you're reading.'' ``It's under control,'' he said, adding he has ``total confidence'' in his Pentagon team. ``Don't be misled by these rabbit trails running through the snow out there.'' The president's comments were the latest in a series of mixed-message statements by officials on preparations for a Persian Gulf war. The administration has been casting about since last week to put a positive spin on statements by Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller in Saudi Arabia, who was the first to publicly state that he would recommend Bush wait until mid-February to attack, if that proves necessary. But Bush on Saturday said the allied forces ``are ready to respond vigorously'' within 10 minutes if provoked. Cheney said last week that U.S. forces would be in position to attack ``soon after Jan. 15,'' if necessary. Also on Thursday, 101 members of Congress wrote Bush urging him to hold off on a military strike to give international economic sanctions more time to take hold. The letter, drafted by Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., contends that the U.N. vote authorizing use of force in the Gulf ``does not commit, or authorize the use of the United States armed forces,'' in an armed conflict. That authorization ``lies solely with the Congress of the United States,'' the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Forms Arrive Early After IRS Promises Break
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service message about giving taxpayers a Christmas break apparently never reached all the people at the Postal Service. University of Florida student Gerald Rose had just finished reading a news account about an IRS decision to delay the mailing of tax forms from the day after Christmas to Friday when he found the IRS packet in his mailbox. ``I thought, `No, this isn't right,''' he said Wednesday after collecting the unwelcome mailing. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg had decided to postpone the annual mailing of 108 million tax packages to extend feelings of holiday cheer. But the plan backfired in this Broward County community. IRS spokeswoman Barbara Nichols explained the IRS delivers the forms to the Postal Service at least a week before Christmas to be held for delivery after the holiday rush. ``If some got delivered, it was by mistake,'' said Postal Service spokeswoman Cesta Ayers in Miami. ``Probably one or two stationmasters got antsy.'' Rose said the early delivery was ``not too nice - especially after they made a big thing out of it that they were going to mail them later.'' But he may have the last laugh. Rose expects a refund.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine President Against Death Penalty for Rebels
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem said Thursday he no longer supports the idea of executing by firing squad the leaders of the Dec. 3 army rebellion. ``Here, there won't be any executions,'' Menem told reporters over breakfast at Government House. He said his earlier statements in favor of the death penalty ``were the product of the moment and the indignation which the action of the insurgents provoked in me.'' More than 600 officers and troops face hearings before the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, the military's highest tribunal. Nearly all were expected to be drummed out of the military. At least 13 people - eight soldiers and five civilians - died in clashes when rebels seized the joint chiefs of staff headquarters, an infantry base and a tank factory in the Buenos Aires area and other installations elsewhere. The military prosecutor last week recommended the death penalty for retired Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, who also led a December 1988 barracks revolt, and four other rebel leaders. A decision by the council, which may be appealed in civilian court, was expected by next month. If the death penalty is upheld, Menem could commute it to life in prison or some other punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Russia Declares Jan. 7 Official Christmas
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic, voted Thursday to make the Jan. 7 Russian Orthodox Christmas an official holiday for the first time since the 1917 Revolution. Its decision came in response to an appeal by the Patriarch of Moscow and all-Russia, Alexy II, the national news agency Tass reported, and is effective only in Russia, which comprises two-thirds of all Soviet territory. Ruslan Khasbulatov, leader of the Russian Congress of People's Deputies, said other religious groups ``will be respectfully considered in the same spirit'' if they apply for recognition. The Orthodox church marks Jan. 7 as Jesus' birthday. Most other countries celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25. The Bolsheviks banned official religious celebrations after the Communist revolution. Since then, Jan. 7 has not been an official holiday, although many clandestine services were held. It wasn't known how the resolution would affect celebrations in other republics, particularly the predominantly Catholic Baltic states that have led the way in declaring sovereignty from the Kremlin. The national legislature has passed a law on freedom of religion but has not declared any official holidays on religious dates.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Legislator Charged with Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: A legislator has been charged with evading more than $12 million in taxes on stock profits, prosecutors announced Thursday, a day after he resigned from the governing party. The case represents a new blow to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democrats. The party was discredited last year by a separate scandal over political donations and bargain stock deals for dozens of influential politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen. Toshiyuki Inamura, 55, who served as a Liberal Democrat in the House of Representatives, was charged with evading $12.7 million in taxes on profits of $20.8 million from stock dealings from 1986 to 1988, according to the Tokyo Public Prosecutors Office. Inamura's personal physician, Akiyuki Yamaguchi, was also charged with evading $6.13 million in taxes in 1986-87, chief prosecutor Yusuke Yoshinaga said. The doctor allegedly provided insider information to Inamura from a third man now being tried on charges of manipulating stock prices. Inamura, a former director general of the Environment Agency, could be fined up to $23.7 million in back taxes and penalties, local news reports quoted tax officials as saying. Tax officials contacted by telephone refused to comment on the reports. Last year's scandal contributed to the resignations of two prime ministers. The Recruit Co., an information services conglomerate, was accused of trying to influence government policy with sweetheart stock deals and political donations. Kaifu, chosen for his clean reputation, was installed as prime minister in August 1989. He immediately vowed reform to restore public trust in politics. However, reforms are still under debate, and Kaifu is locked in a struggle with powerful party faction leaders to prevent politicians implicated in the Recruit scandal from gaining ministerial posts. In the Inamura case, the stock earnings were found to have been put to his personal use. The Prosecutors Office said Inamura used part of his stock profits to buy a luxury home in Tokyo. The remainder was reinvested in stocks, it said. The legislator, who resigned Wednesday from the Liberal Democratic Party, remains free because of a law prohibiting police from arresting legislators during a parliamentary session. He will face trial in Tokyo District Court.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Rules Indiana's Out-of-State Trash Law Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: Key provisions of Indiana's new law regulating out-of-state trash are unconstitutional because they inhibit commerce among states, a federal judge ruled Thursday. U.S. District Judge John D. Tinder permanently banned the state from enforcing three provisions, concluding they violate the Constitution's commerce clause allowing free trade among states. ``The same protection that the commerce clause gives to the citizens of other states who feel the need to import waste into Indiana protects Indiana citizens when they export hazardous waste to other states,'' Tinder wrote. ``Those provisions (in the Constitution) will protect future generations of Hoosiers should they find the need to export even solid municipal waste to another state,'' the opinion said. Tinder's ruling came five months after the end of a trial on a lawsuit filed by two Pennsylvania trash haulers. Theychallenged the law shortly after Gov. Evan Bayh signed it last spring. One provision struck down Thursday required a trash hauler to certify where the largest part of the waste in a shipment was generated. Another required an out-of-state hauler to receive a health officer's certification that the shipment contained no hazardous or infectious waste. A third provision imposed a dumping fee equal to the fee charged at the landfill closest to the shipment's point of origin. Bayh, vacationing in South Carolina, issued a statement saying he will meet with the state's congressional delegation and contact other governors to solicit help in getting federal law changed. ``We will not let down in the fight against the indiscriminate dumping of East Coast trash on Indiana,'' Bayh said. At the state level, Bayh said he has instructed the Indiana Department of Environmental Management to provide more inspections and tougher enforcement to stop illegal hazardous or infectious waste from entering Indiana. He said he also will meet with legislative leaders and consult with volunteer legal experts to consider new laws to stem the flow of out-of-state trash. Attorney General Linley E. Pearson said about a half-dozen other states had similar trash laws struck down on the commerce clause argument. The Indiana law was passed with bipartisan support after Bayh and legislators expressed alarm their state had become a dumping ground for trash from Eastern states. The ruling doesn't disturb other provisions of the law that require solid waste management plans within Indiana, impose a tipping fee on all waste deposited within the state and require haulers of waste within Indiana to certify the county of origin of the trash shipment, Tinder said. Those provisions are in effect. The trash shippers' attorney, Bruce L. Thall, said the same provisions that made the law politically popular undermined its chances to withstand legal challenge. ``This was a palpably unconstitutional attempt just to stop out-of-state trash at the borders,'' said Thall, who represented Government Suppliers Consolidating Services Inc. and Jack Castenova Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Declares General Amnesty for Pigs
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro declared ``a general amnesty for pigs,'' meaning Cubans will forgo their traditional holiday meal of pork because of hard times, Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina said Thursday. ``About 200,000 pigs will survive the New Year festivities in Cuba as part of the official strategy to protect livestock,'' it said in a dispatch from Havana, monitored in Mexico City. Castro personally defended the porkless holiday when questioned by lawmakers during the yearend parliamentary session on farm production. ``People asked why there was no pork in the markets,'' Prensa Latina said. ``It was necessary to explain the reasons.'' Castro said massive holiday slaughter would have cost the lives of young pigs in the prime of their reproductive lives and made pork scare in January, February and March. ``We have decreed a general amnesty for pigs,'' he said as parliament burst into laughter and applause. Communist Cuba is in the grip of its most serious economic crisis since Castro took power 32 years ago. The president has been bracing his island nation for even tougher times when Soviet aid is sharply reduced. Castro says he is putting Cuba on the sort of austerity footing that would come in wartime. Oxen are replacing tractors, city dwellers are being sent to the countryside to work in the fields, and food, fuel and manufactured goods are being rationed. Cuba now relies on the Soviet Union for 90 percent of its oil and 70 percent of its trade. But the Soviets will stop paying Cuba above-market prices for sugar next year and will start charging market prices for oil.

DOC.HEAD: Snow From Missouri To Appalachians, Rain Over South
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell Thursday on the central Appalachians and across the Ohio Valley, and rain dampened the Southeast and South, including areas plagued by flooding last week. At midday, snow fell in portions of Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana, Illinois and Missouri. In Missouri, snow sent workers home early, canceled airline flights and high school basketball tournaments, and prompted several hospitals to issue pleas for four-wheel-drive vehicles to drive doctors and nurses to work. The St. Louis area received about 4 to 6 inches of snow and other parts of southeastern Missouri were hit with up to 8 inches, the National Weather Service said. Bollinger County Sheriff Januare Peters said about 8 inches of snow fell there and roads were just about impassable with anything but a four-wheel-drive vehicle. ``It's snowing so hard no one can get out of the house. And I'm glad about that,'' Peters said. Freezing rain was scattered over northern Arkansas, western and north-central Kentucky, northern Georgia and northern North Carolina. Rain extended over southeastern Virginia, much of the remainder of North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, northern Alabama, Mississippi, the remainder of Arkansas, Louisiana and eastern Texas. Snow and rain across Tennessee raised water levels that were already swelled by persistent precipitation. In Obion, Tenn., about 70 people remained evacuated from their 30 homes following the worst flooding in the town of 1,300 in decades. The Obion River was at 24.8 feet Thursday morning near Bogota - almost 3 feet above flood stage. A slow fall was forecast despite additional rain Thursday. Pre-Christmas floods that claimed one life receded in northern Alabama but downstream the draining water pushed some rivers above flood stage in largely rural southwestern regions of the state, where some residents traveled from home to home by boat. In the Northwest, rain fell over western Washington state and northwestern Oregon, and snow was scattered over the Washington mountains, the Idaho Panhandle, western Montana, eastern Idaho and west-central Wyoming. At midday, Washington's Stampede Pass had a 41-inch cover of snow. Blizzard warnings were posted through Friday over nrthern Montana, with winter storm warnings in effect into Friday across southern Montana. Wind gusted to 77 mph at Livingston, Mont., during Thursday morning. Winter storm warnings also were posted through Friday across the northwestern interior section of Washington state, with a winter storm watch over the southwest interior area. Elsewhere, snow fell from central Minnesota into northwestern Wisconsin. The heaviest snowfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST was 4 inches at Kalispell, Mont., and 2 inches at Joplin and Springfield, Mo. Record lows Thursday were 23 below zero at Alamosa, Colo., and 9 below at Marquette, Mich. Sacramento, Calif., tied its record of 26 and Winslow, Ariz., tied its record of 3 below. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 below at Alamosa and International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from zero at Cut Bank, Mont., to 83 in Florida at Naples and Tampa.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Finance Minister Says He `Bought' Coalition Partners
DOC.TEXT: Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, in remarks broadcast Thursday, said he has used public funds to buy the support of coalition partners and keep the right-wing government's Cabinet from collapsing. Modai's remarks follow reports that some ultra-Orthodox parties in the Cabinet were demanding more government money for their religious schools and other institutions as a price for support. On Wednesday, State Comptroller Miriam Ben-Porat issued an unusually harsh report accusing the ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians faction of concealing records of transactions with state funds. Israeli reports said the money amounts to hundreds of thousands of dollars. The faction's support is crucial to maintaining Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's narrow majority of 62 in the 120-member Parliament. In his remarks broadcast on army radio, Modai said the government was in danger of collapse. He was speaking Wednesday night to supporters in the coastal city of Netanya. ``If you only knew how many government crises I have bought off in the past few months, not with jobs as Cabinet ministers, but with money,'' he said. ``There is no other way of preserving this structure.'' ``We have lost the component of personal example in leadership. Our government doesn't project stability,'' Modai was quoted as saying. The finance minister, who heads a breakaway faction of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, did not elaborate. His spokesman could not be reached immediately for comment. The reports of demands for funds by orthodox parties have stirred controversay bcause they come at a time when the government is increasing income taxes to finance an unprecedented wave of Soviet immigration. Nearly 200,000 Soviet immigrants are expected this year. In her comments Wednesday, Ben-Porat, the state comptroller, said on Israel television that parliamentary financial records kept by Communications Minister Rafael Pinchasi of the Torah Guardians Party, were ``intentionally hidden from me.'' Reading from her report, Ben-Porat added that evidence suggests ``the main reason for hiding the listings'' is that much of the money went to religious seminary students who worked in the party's election campaign. ``Exposure of their names was liable to hurt them ... in terms of army recruitment and taxes,'' she added. Many religious youths are exempted from compulsory military duty if they can prove their time is being devoted to study of the scriptures. She also sent a copy of her inquiry to State Attorney General Yosef Harish, a step usually taken when a criminal suit is being considered, Israeli reports said. Police have been investigating the issue for three months after evidence of graft surfaced during a separate inquiry centering on Interior Minister Aryeh Deri, a prominent member of the Torah Guardians, Israel radio said. Deri has denied any wrongdoing. The investigation is reportedly still under way.

DOC.HEAD: Count Criticized by States, Cities That Could Lose Federal Bucks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 16th graf ``Ralph Munro'' to fix Munro spelling
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau's day-old population count came under swift criticism Thursday from a key congressman and some state and local officials who argued it had missed many urban Americans and would cost large cities federal funds. The Bush administration official in charge of the census, Michael Darby, defended it as ``full, fair and accurate.'' Rep. Tom Sawyer, D-Ohio, chairman of the House census subcommittee, said the ppulation count ``may be the first one to be less accurate than its predecessor.'' He noted the total was 4.7 million people below an estimate made in October, and added, ``We're saying the apparent discrepancy is cause for concern.'' The count released on Wednesday pegged population in the United States - excluding nearly 1 million Americans living abroad - at 248.7 million, an increase of nearly 10 percent from a decade ago. In general, it showed large population gains in California, Arizona, Florida and other Sun Belt states, and far smaller increases in the industrial northern states and the agricultural heartland. The governor of New York and the mayor of Meridian, Miss., called separately for continued legal challenges to the count. The census process has been criticized throughout the year by municipal and state officials, who say it skips people in urban areas, particularly the poor. The census numbers are important to those officials because they determine how many representatives each state sends to Congress and how much federal aid states, counties and cities will get. An area that's undercounted, for example, will have less political clout and will get less federal money. ``New York will continue to make every effort both in the courts and elsewhere to have all New Yorkers counted, so that we can maintain our vital and important voice in Washington and ensure our fair share of federal dollars,'' said New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. ``We know where those 5 million folks are,'' Jimmy Kemp, mayor of Meridian, Miss., said of the difference between the October estimate and this week's count. ``You're going to find them in your cities where you have the most economically disadvantaged folks.'' Rep. Thomas Ridge, R-Pa. and senior Republican on the census and population subcommittee, said it was wrong to call the difference between the October ``guesstimate'' and this week's count a discrepancy. ``The fact that you couldn't hit the projection, in my view, is not legitimate grounds for criticizing the enumeration process itself,'' Ridge said. The Census Bureau said this week that there were in fact 249.6 million Americans. But it isn't accurate to compare that figure to the 1980 tally because it includes 1 million Americans living abroad, who weren't counted ten years earlier. Darby, the under secretary of commerce in charge of the Census Bureau, said he believed the 1990 census was ``full, fair and accurate,'' but he added no one now can say how accurate. ``Right now we don't know just how good the census is'' and won't know until statistical checks have been completed this summer, Darby said. ``Certainly there's no valid basis for making a judgment about an undercount or overcount at this point.'' More than 6,000 local governments - including the nation's 51 largest cities - filed challenges against preliminary figures with the Census Bureau. The resolution of those local challenges will help determine the final census totals. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, under whose direction the Census Bureau operates, has until July 15 to decide whether to add people that the local officials say were not counted. Ralph Munro, secretary of state of Washington state, expressed concern that eastern cities challenging the census results might prevail. ``We're thinking of intervening on the other side to argue that the numbers should stand,'' he said. New York City Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was ``mad as hell'' with the census figures. ``We will fight it to the hilt, because it means to us about a billion dollars over 10 years and of course a loss of representation, which is tremendously important,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambican Students Riot in Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Masked and armed with knives, students from Mozambique staged a riot in Cuba that left one person dead and another hospitalized, the Cuban government news service Prensa Latina said Thursday.
