The rioters vandalized buildings and vehicles on Wednesday and threatened to destroy their dormitories and classrooms in Isla de la Juventud, an international student community in southern Havana province, it said. Prensa Latina, based in Havana and monitored in Mexico City, quoted the official Agencia de Informacion Nacional as saying the students demanded that the government of Mozambique pay them dollar stipends for their grant studies program. They brawled among themselves and leveled threats at other students in an attempt to force them to join in the rowdy protest, the agency said. It said Mozambican Ambassador Ammur Zacaria Kupela asked Cuban authorities to subdue the rioters after negotiation attempts failed. Cuba reaffirmed its support for continued diplomatic ties with the southeast African nation and promised to maintain an atmosphere for continued studies by international students in the Communist island nation, Prensa Latina said.

DOC.HEAD: State Puts Off Decision On Whether To Continue Killing Bison
DOC.TEXT: State wildlife officials put off a decision Thursday on a temporary plan to kill wandering bison from Yllowstone National Park to ensure they don't spread disease to cattle. The plan, which was the subject of a hearing, includes a provision to have federal rangers help state wardens kill the cows that wander outside the park. Officials say cows are more likely to carry the disease brucellosis than bulls, and putting the responsibility for their killing in the hands of wardens and rangers should reduce the chances of their spreading disease. About half of the 2,500 to 3,000 bison in the 2-million-acre park are believed to carry brucellosis, a disease that causes cattle to abort. Montana spent millions of dollars over a decade to eradicate brucellosis in its cattle. Hunters would continue killing bulls outside the park and calves would be captured, sterilized and sold at auction. Animal rights groups are lined up solidly against killing the animals, contending the threat of passing brucellosis from bison to domestic cattle is minimal or non-existent. The Montana Department of Livestock and the Montana Stockgrowers' Association are equally adamant in demanding the invading bison not be allowed even the slightest chance to contaminate public and private rangeland abutting the park's northern and western boundaries. The plan has caused a furor this winter, with critics - including some sport hunters - complaining that killing the bison has wounded Montana's reputation as a refuge for wildlife. ``Let's get hunters out of the business of shooting bison,'' Brian Kahn of Helena said during Thursday's hearing. He characterized himself as a life-long hunter and supporter of hunting, and said state officials must take a serious look ``at what this bison hunt is doing to the image of hunting.'' Knute Hereim, a rancher from Martinsdale representing the stockgrowers' association, said livestock producers support the state's attempt to keep infected bison from possibly reinfecting Montana herds. He said officials in Yellowstone have not taken steps to control the animal health risk. ``Immediate action must be taken,'' he said. Pat Graham, associate director of the state Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks, said all comment submitted at Thursday's hearing, a previous hearing Dec. 14 and written comment would be assessed before a final decision is made, probably next week. A decision had been scheduled for Friday. Graham said there is no immediate threat of hundreds of bison moving from the park into Montana, giving the department longer than originally anticipated to make its decision. During both public hearings this month and in much of the written comment, the National Park Service has been criticized for not controlling bison movements or cleansing the herds of brucellosis. Yellowstone Superintendent Robert Barbee said earlier that the park is cooperating fully with attempts to find a long-term solution to the bison problem. He also said the call by Montana officials for the U.S. Department of Agriculture to issue a quarantine order for the park was inappropriate. The Fund for Animals, based in New York City, filed suit in federal court against the bison control plan. It contends the plan reflects a ``shoot-anything-that-moves'' mentality by state wildlife officials. In written testimony, the fund contended the plan is biased in favor of ``the self-serving interests'' of Montana's livestock industry. It called for non-lethal means of controlling the infected animals. So far this winter, only hunters have been used to kill bison wandering across the park's border in the region near West Yellowstone. Eleven bulls have been killed. Two seasons ago, 569 bison were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Characters to be Restricted in Naming Korean Babies
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese characters that can be used to name babies in South Korea will be legally restricted starting next year to make it easier for the government to keep computer records of its citizens. In a ruling published Thursday, the Supreme Court said 2,731 Chinese characters will be legally recognized beginning in April, eliminating thousands of others. The court said the ruling is meant to facilitate computerization of family registers and avoid the confusion that often arises from having to transliterate complicated Chinese characters. Fewer and fewer Koreans read Chinese and many prefer the simpler Korean Hangul alphabet for naming children. Critics of the decision say the number of strokes in a name is a crucial determinant of fate, and claim that the restriction infringes on their right to choose their child's name. In 20 to 30 years, when babies born after 1991 are adults, the use of Chinese characters will have declined to such an extent that nobody but the name-carriers themselves may be able to read such names, the court said. Unlike China, Hong Kong and Japan, which belong to the same language group as Korea, Korea has not transfigured or simplified the Chinese characters it uses.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi's Remarks Anger Secular Israelis, Holocaust Survivors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS rabbi name to Schach sted Shach throughout. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A leading rabbi has outraged Holocaust survivors and secular Israelis by claiming that the Nazi genocide was God's punishment for sins such as violating the Jewish Sabbath and eating pork. Hundreds of Israelis called a radio talk show Thursday to let off steam about the remarks of Rabbi Eliezer Schach, 97, an ultra-Orthodox rabbinical sage who, by a quirk of the electoral system, also happens to be the kingmaker of Israeli governments. About 6 million Jews perished in the Holocaust, and tens of thousands of survivors live in Israel. The uproar over Schach's remarks reflected the deep sensitivity still felt in this country over the Holocaust, 45 years after the last death camp was liberated. ``Not for a long time has any single remark caused such an emotional reaction,'' said Razi Barkai, the host of the Israel radio talk show. He said calls ran about 3-2 against the rabbi. At one level, Schach was simply repeating a theme common in the Bible: of divine retribution against the Jewish people for straying from the path of their religious law. But at another level, many took his remarks to mean that the Jews somehow were to blame for the Nazis' behavior. ``The Almighty keeps a balance sheet of the world, and when the sins become too many, he brings destruction. We don't know how long his patience holds out, sometimes 20 years, sometimes 10, and sometimes only a year,'' Schach told Jewish seminary students earlier this week. ``The last time he brought destruction, it was the Holocaust. ... Because of the sins, the Almighty may bring another Holocaust upon us, and it may already be tomorrow,'' he warned. These sins, according to Schach, include violating the sanctity of the Sabbath and eating pork, which is banned by Jewish dietary law. Some of Schach's sharpest critics were Holocaust survivors. Menahem Russak, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp and a former commander of the Israeli police unit investigating Nazi war crimes, said Schach ``shamed and humiliated'' millions of Holocaust victims. His voice shaking, Russak told listeners that Schach ``not only exonerated the Nazi murderers, but turned them into messengers of God who were sent to punish the people of Israel for not observing the Torah.'' But another caller, an ultra-Orthodox woman who lost relatives in the Holocaust, defended the rabbi. ``With all the pain I have, I can understand his words. We believe in the link between sin and punishment,'' said the woman, who did not give her name. Sociologist Menachem Friedman, an expert on religious communities, said Schach's views reflect ultra-Orthodox thinking prevalent since the 1950s. But secular Israelis only began listening after the ultra-Orthodox left their self-chosen isolation and entered Israeli politics in the 1980s, Friedman said. ``Rabbi Schach today is one of the most powerful men in Israeli politics and each one of his words creates a lot of noise,'' Friedman said in an interview. Earlier this year, Schach in effect made Yitzhak Shamir prime minister by ordering his political supporters to join Shamir's coalition. Five percent of Israel's Jewish residents are ultra-Orthodox, another 5 percent are sympathizers, and 20 percent are observant but not fundamentalist. Another 70 percent define themselves as secular, according to Friedman. The secular public tends to stereotype ultra-Orthodox Jews like Schach as throwbacks to the Jews' ghetto years who never embraced the Zionist cause. For one thing, they speak Yiddish, the language of the ghetto in Europe, rather than Hebrew, the symbol of reborn Israel. Indeed, Schach delivered his controversial remarks in Yiddish, and Israel radio had to give listeners a translation into Hebrew. ``The visibility of the ultra-orthodox, those speeches, are creating a harsh antagonism,'' Friedman said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Abstract Artist Harold Town Dies
DOC.TEXT: Abstract artist Harold Town, a founding member of Painters Eleven, a group of 1950s modernists who marked a new direction for art in Canada and brought Canadian painting into the international mainstream, died Thursday. He was 66. Town, who had been battling cancer, died at his farm near Peterborough, authorities said. A graduate of the Ontario College of Art, Town for a while dropped painting altogether, after working on 40 canvasses at a time, and turned to lithography, drawing, collage, etching and sculpture. For years he was unsuccessful at selling his abstract work, which was received with contempt and shock by a conservative art community. By the late 1950s, he was becoming a name artist in the national and international art circuit. Painters Eleven had its first exhibition in 1954. It drew large crowds and served as a springboard for the artists involved. Town created a stir with his articulate, witty and outrageous personality as much as with his art. He lampooned other artists, picketed against pop art, marketed one of his paintings as a jigsaw puzzle, and illustrated books that sold for $150 a copy. Funeral arrangements were incomplete, and survivors were not immediately divulged.

DOC.HEAD: Video Retail Giant Has No Plans to Sell Customer Lists
DOC.TEXT: Video retail giant Blockbuster Entertainment Corp. on Thursday denied a newspaper report that it plans to sell mailing lists of customers' rental selections. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that Blockbuster plans to sell customer lists next year to direct mail companies. The customers' names would be organized by the type of movie rented, the newspaper said. A 2-year-old federal law bars video stores from disclsing the actual titles of movies rented, but the subject matter of the videotapes is not protected. Blockbuster separates its videotapes into 37 categories by subject matter. The company has an estimated 30 million customers who have rented videotapes. The Journal story quoted Allan Caplan, the Blockbuster vice president overseeing the database record-keeping project, as saying: ``I can turn around and promote all the John Wayne names to the national Republican Party.'' Wally Knief, Blockbuster's corporate communications manager, said the story was the result of ``miscommunication.'' He said the company has no intention of disclosing its customer lists. ``That does not represent company policy,'' Knief said. ``Blockbuster will not rent or sell its mailing lists. The only use will be to provide value-added services to clients that our customers can benefit from.'' Caplan referred calls from The Associated Press on Thursday to Knief's office.

DOC.HEAD: Freeze Leads to Layoffs; Prices Expected to Climb
DOC.TEXT: A cold wave that ruined California's navel orange crop, which could make the fruit scarce and pricy, is robbing thousands of citrus workers of their jobs, agriculture experts say. About 450 people were fired Wednesday at LoBue Bros. one of the biggest packing houses in the San Joaquin Valley. ``It was with deep regret that we had to discharge that many people the day after Christmas,'' said general manager G.A. Wollenman. ``That's no kind of Christmas present.'' Joel Nelsen, manager of California Citrus Mutual, a growers organization, estimated 15,000 people will be out of work; the state's estimated 70 citrus packing houses will have nothing for them to do. An undetermined number of harvest workers will also have to look elsewhere for jobs, he said. The damage to crops inflicted by the sustained freeze that gripped much of the country before Christmas occurred mostly in California, said a report by the federal Joint Agricultural Facility in Washington. Hardest hit was the California navel orange crop, which comprises nearly 2 percent of the state's annual $16.5 billion agricultural yield. About 80 percent of the current crop remained unpicked when the freeze hit and thus was destroyed. ``I do not believe there is a lemon or orange in the San Joaquin Valley,'' said farmer Don Laux. ``We basically don't have anything left. It's over.'' California navels generally are sold fresh, in contrast to Florida's $1.3 billion orange crop, which mainly becomes juice. The dollar loss to California's navel orange crop was estimated Thursday at $286 million to $288 million by agriculture officials in the three San Joaquin Valley counties where they are grown commercially. Industry observers said the frost caused the worst damage anyone can remember. ``Prices could double because of the severe damage in the Central Valley,'' said Claire Peters of Sunkist Growers, marketing cooperative for about 6,000 California and Arizona growers. ``The fruit will be well-tested, so the quality should be fine, but there won't be as much and it will be more expensive,'' Peters said. No price increases were found at several major Southern California supermarket chains checked Thursday. But produce department managers for the Vons and Ralphs chains said they expected a rise in the current price of 69 cents per pound. Meanwhile, some growers and packers are seeking federal relief and workers are lining up at unemployment offices. Brad Stark said he would have to lay off between 200 and 300 people at his packing shed. In a normal year, his plants pack more than 3 million cartons of oranges. This year, less than 5 percent of the fruit can be salvaged and Stark expects his losses to approach $30 million. As citrus farmers are trying to reckon the damage wrought by the pre-Christmas freeze, others are concerned about a second cold snap headed their way. Third-generation farmer Gary Cavilia knows he's already lost this year's crop of oranges, but so far his trees have withstood the cold. Another freeze, predicted for the weekend, could cause tree splits. Extensive tree splits could set farmers back up to five years. That's how long it would take to have trees fully producing crops again. ``Most farmers, myself included, are not quitters,'' said Dave Daguerre, who owns a 30-acre orchard. ``But the thing that is really scary is this next storm. If it drops rain and freezes, I don't think anyone has any hope.'' Cavilia has invested about $1,100 an acre on his 150-acre orchard this season. ``It's going to be a belt-tightening year,'' he said. ``I'm just struggling to keep my trees alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Bus, Park Fees to Soar in Beijing on Jan. 1
DOC.TEXT: Beginning Jan. 1, residents of Beijing will have to pay double the regular fare for bus and subway tickets and up to 10 times as much to stroll in a park as the city tries to reduce price subsidies, an official report said Thursday. The new rates still fail to cover the city's costs to run the public transit and parks systems, the Beijing Evening News said. But it did not indicate whether further increases were likely soon. Even for Chinese, the new rates remain relatively low. A bus ride across the central city will cost 3 cents, for example, or less than 3 percent of the average worker's daily wages. Most city parks have charged less than 1 cent for entry and now will charge 9 cents. For years, governments at all levels in Communist China have heavily subsidized virtually every public service and product sold to urban residents, from housing to rice, at a cost of billions of dollars annually. Prices have been increased selectively the past decade in an effort to reduce the burden of subsidies. But authorities have failed to overhaul the entire price system, as economists have urged, for fear of causing social unrest that might threaten the Communist Party's rule. After striving through most of 1989 and 1990 to hold prices down, officials said recently that the public is ready to accept a new round of increases. In November, sugar prices went up about 45 percent nationwide, and cotton cloth prices rose about 25 percent. In Beijing, the price of coal briquettes used by most families in cooking stoves more than doubled. None of these increases prompted public complaints.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Fundamentalists Appeal Deportation Order
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with three Arabs shot in the West Bank. Picks up graf 14 pvs, `Defense attorney...'
DOC.TEXT: Four Moslem fundamentalists on Thursday appealed to Israel's Supreme Court to overturn an army order deporting them from the occupied Gaza Strip. In the occupied West Bank, three Arabs were wounded by shots fired into their car. An anonymous caller said Jewish extremists were responsible for the attack. The U.N. Security Council condemned the expulsion order last week in a resolution that also urged more protection for the 1.7 million Palestinians living under Israeli occupation in the West Bank and Gaza. Three high court judges will hear the appeal, but no hearing date has been set, Israel radio reported. The high court has never overturned an expulsion order. The deportation order, issued earlier this month, was the first in 16 months and came despite a plea by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for Israel not to expel Palestinians. Also Thursday, the Supreme Court upheld a police decision banning Israeli and Palestinian women from holding a joint peace march this weekend along the ``Green Line,'' which separated Arab east Jerusalem from the Jewish western sector until 1967. The court accepted the police argument that public demonstrations should be banned this week and next to prevent any disturbances connected with Tuesday's 26th anniversary of the founding of Fatah, Yasser Arafat's mainstream PLO faction. After the three Arabs were wounded, an anonymous caller told Israel army radio: ``We are Zionist Jews, and we attacked three Arabs near the Gush Etzion junction.'' The army command said the Arabs were wounded near the Jewish settlement Efrat. It said no soldiers were involved. In the West Bank, a 30-year-old Palestinian died Thursday of a bullet wound suffered in a clash with Israeli troops on March 15, 1988, Arab reports said. He had been hit in the back and paralyzed from the waist down. The Arab was identified as Khiary Mahmoud of the village of Anza. Doctors said he had been treated in Jordan before being returned to Al-Ittihad Hospital in Nablus this week. Mahmoud's death raised to 781 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 3-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation. An additional 332 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Fifty-seven Israelis have died in the violence. The army issued its deportation order on Dec. 15, a day after three Israelis were stabbed to death in a suburb of Tel Aviv and slogans painted at the murder scene claimed responsibility for Hamas, an outlawed Moslem fundamentalist organization. The army blamed the four men for inciting the murders, not for the crime itself. The two suspects in the slaying have not been caught. On Tuesday, a military appeals panel upheld the deportation order, saying the four incited anti-Israeli violence as ``senior activists'' in Hamas, Arabic for Zeal. Defense attorney Abdul Malek Dahamshe, who filed the high court appeal, said Thursday the hearing before the military panel violated proper legal procedures. ``We had no chance to bring witnesses, we couldn't consult with them (our clients) and we couldn't consult with other attorneys,'' Dahamshe told Israel radio. The men facing expulsion are Fadel Khadel Zaabut, 34, a college instructor in Gaza City; Emad Khaled el Alami, 34, a civil engineer; Mustafa Youssef Abdul el Lidawi, 26; and Mustafa Ahmed el Qnuih, 45. Israel has expelled 60 Palestinians from the occupied territories to neighboring countries since the beginning of the uprising. Western nations, including the United States, have deplored the practice as a violation of the Fourth Geneva Convention, which bars expulsions from occupied lands. Also Thursday, police blocked a handful of Jewish zealots from going up to Jerusalem's Temple Mount, saying their planned demonstration was raising tension in the Moslem community. A planned march by the Temple Mount Faithful group on Oct. 8 initiated a riot in which at least 17 Palestinians died in police gunfire. The group's goal is to rebuild the ancient Jewish temple on the Temple Mount, which is known to Moslems as Haram es-Sharif or Noble Sanctuary and is the site of two historic mosques.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Soviet Premier Says Criticism Caused His Heart Attack
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The wife of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov on Thursday blamed ``deliberate'' criticism of her 61-year-old husband for his suffering a heart attack after a session of the Congress of People's Deputies this week. Ryzhkov, felled Tuesday, was reported in serious condition Thursday but his wife Ludmilla said he could smile again and that he wants to return to work after his recovery. She also told Tass in what the state news agency called a tearful interview that the prime minister disagrees with some government changes, but she gave no details. ``We failed to take a leave and Nikolai was nearly exhausted,'' she said. ``But his fatigue resulted not so much from work, which he liked very much, and not from critical remarks, but from excessive attacks that were clearly exaggerated, persistent and deliberate.'' Earlier Thursday, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told parliament Ryzhkov's condition ``is serious but is not worsening.'' Mrs. Ryzhkov said her husband suffered a myocardic infarction ``of medium gravity. ... The pain has somewhat subsided, but some time will be needed to stabilize his emotional state. ``Thousands of letters and telegrams have arrived wishing Nikolai a speedy recovery.'' She said he never had heart problems before. He felt pains Tuesday morning during parliament debate, but said nothing ``hoping it would pass by itself.'' The Congress on Tuesday began debate on constitutional amendments. One will replace Ryzhkov's Council of Ministers with a smaller Cabinet under presidential control. A prime minister will head it, but nobody has been named to the job yet. His wife said Ryzhkov wanted to remain in government ``to work not for individual politicians but for the state.'' Ryzhkov was assailed by reformists after a political battle last fall over an economic reform plan to create a market economy in the Soviet Union. His announcement of price increases over the summer set off a rush on stores until the government canceled the plans. Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin repeatedly demanded Ryzhkov's removal as prime minister and called his economic proposals too conservative. Tass paraphrased Mrs. Ryzhkov as saying her husband's address to the Congress on its third day last week was ``too heavy a load.'' Ryzhkov delivered a gloomy report on the Soviet economy while defending Gorbachev and himself against criticism from both right and left. The heart attack followed a long day of parliamentary debate. Ryzhkov returned home about midnight, but could not sleep and woke Mrs. Ryzhkov up at 3 a.m., she said. ``He was very pale, and his forehead was covered in cold perspiration,'' she said. She called a doctor and he was taken to a hospital at 4 a.m., she said. ``They told me that on the way to the clinic, he tried to keep up the doctors' spirit by attempting to joke,'' Mrs. Ryzhkov said.

DOC.HEAD: Isreali Labor Court Overrules Paper's Dismissals
DOC.TEXT: A Tel Aviv court on Thursday reversed the dismissals of 57 Jerusalem Post employees, saying the action violated a labor-management accord. The dispute began with the company's announcement in November it would lay off the employees in economic cutbacks. On Dec. 3rd, 27 journalists were dismissed. About 70 staffers walked out, demanding that management uphold an October agreement. The accord outlines specific procedures for dismissing workers. It also limits the number of private contracts the company may sign with workers. In response to the walkout, management told some journalists to sign private contracts or leave within 48 hours, staffers said. ``This was an attempt to break the union as well as a flagrant violation of the agreement,'' said Dan Izenberg, a member of the staff committee. An additional 30 journalists were dismissed following the walkout. The labor court ruled Thursday in favor of the staff committee, which filed the complaints. It said the company must operate in keeping with the October agreement. The Post, Israel's only English-language daily, has a daily circulation of about 25,000 nationally. It prints an overseas edition with a circulation of 50,000.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Minister of Russian Federation Quits in Frustration
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boris Fyodorov, Russia's 33-year-old finance minister who led efforts to create a market economy in the vast republic, has resigned in frustration over stalled progress on his plan. He said in an interview published Thursday with Rossiiskaya Gazeta, the official newspaper of the Russian Supreme Soviet legislature, that Russian lawmakers have been unwilling to take necessary but unpopular measures such as lifting artificial price controls and allowing private ownership. ``Regrettably, there is nothing like progress toward the market,'' Fyodorov was quoted as saying. The impact of Fyodorov's resignation Wednesday could not immediately be gauged, but it was certain to raise questions by fledgling investors and entrepreneurs in the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin, Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and other reformers have been trying to attract foreign investors and cultivate Russian businesses to stimulate the economy. Two stock exchanges recently have been founded in Moscow, although with few stocks or bonds to be traded. Hundreds of joint-venture companies and independent ``cooperative'' businesses already are operating in the republic despite a maze of government ministries, laws and red tape. Fyodorov told the newspaper that decisions such as forming private companies, setting up a stock market and bringing Russian accounting practices in line with international norms ``get bogged down in the depths of the apparatus ... of the Russian Council of Ministers for months on end.'' The chairman of the Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, is Ivan Silayev, a former minister under Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev who was elected to the job over Yeltsin's objections. Silayev criticized Fyodorov in the Russian republic parliament on Thursday and proposed Deputy Finance Minister Igor Lazarev as a replacement. But after a ``heated debate,'' a final decision was put off until the next session, the state news agency Tass reported. Parliament made Lazarev acting finance minister until a replacement is found, it said. ``Cabinet ministers seem to believe in all seriousness that they can run the economy as they would run a factory,'' Fyodorov was quoted as saying. ``Populist measures involving ever new outlays are taken one after another, while the revenue base is being curtailed. ``This is a shortcut to financial bankruptcy for the republic and for the (Soviet) Union as a whole.'' On Nov. 1, the Russian Federation began a program to switch from a centrally planned, command economy to a free market within 500 days. Russian lawmakers said they wanted to move faster than the national government, but their policies often conflict and create confusion rather than reform. Fyodorov is credited with helping draft Russia's version of the 500-day plan and was a member of the joint Russian-Soviet committee that tried to merge the governments' divergent plans. A devotee of British economic policies under former Prime Minister Magaret Thatcher, Fyodorov holds a doctorate in economics from the Moscow Institute of Finance. He has worked for the huge Soviet economic planning agency, Gosplan, and the prestigious Institute for Economics and International Relations. A serious dispute between the Russian Federation and the central government threatens the nation's solvency. Gorbachev told the Congress of People's Deputies that Russian lawmakers agreed to provide only $37.4 billion toward the national budget for next year, $190 billion less than the republic's contribution this year. The Russians complain they don't get enough back from the national budget to justify their contribution. Gorbachev said that if other republics follow Russia's lead and cut their contributions, the result would be ``a collapse not only of the economy, but of the union.'' He urged the Russian parliament to suspend its decision.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-President Chun May End Exile Soon
DOC.TEXT: Disgraced former President Chun Doo-hwan has decided to en his two-year rural exile and may return to the capital over the weekend or next Monday, news reports said Thursday. Yonhap, the national news agency, said Chun accepted President Roh Tae-woo's request to leave a 14th-century Buddhist temple in the remote eastern mountains before New Year's Day. Kim Young-iel, one of Roh's senior secretaries, visited the temple Thursday for talks with Chun, who went into exile in November 1988 after apologizing for his authoritarian rule. Roh now says the former president should be allowed to live in his old house. When Chun left Seoul, he said the house and other properties would be turned over to the government to atone for his wrongdoing. Chun and his wife, Lee Soon-ja, have lived in the Paektam-sa temple for two years, isolated from the public and protected by guards. A dozen of Chun's associates and relatives have been convicted of corruption and imprisoned.

DOC.HEAD: Most Say They Want to Volunteer But Are Too Busy
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-five percent of adults in a survey say Americans should volunteer to help the less fortunate, but few follow through and many shy away from helping the homeless, poor and ill, the study found. Three-quarters of the 1,000 people who responded to the random telephone survey said they would like to volunteer to help the less fortunate, but are too busy, said Donald E. Banker, a vice president at Lions Club International, which commissioned the study. The Lions Club claims to be the world's largest service organization, with nearly 1.4 million members in 171 countries. ``We're concerned about the lack of participation in our association by the younger generation,'' Banker said Thursday in a telephone interview from California. ``There seems to be a hesitancy to get involved.'' Forty-one percent of the respondents said they would rather donate money than volunteer their time. The survey, conducted last spring, questioned people ages 25 to 40, and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The survey found that among the respondents who said they had performed any volunteer work, including helping at church or school, many shied away from long-term commitments. Eighteen percent of volunteers said they spent time with children, compared to 5 percent with the homeless and 4 percent with people with mental disabilities or cancer. Twelve percent of volunteers said they worked with people with physical disabilities. ``Children are always No. 1 because volunteers can make an immediate difference there,'' said Jean Davis, a spokeswoman for the Midwest regional office of the Salvation Army in Chicago. ``With the homeless it takes a monumental effort to make a change. Sometimes you can't solve the problem and it's frustrating,'' she said. John Donahue, executive director of the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless, said Americans should give more time to volunteer efforts. ``To really resolve the problem nationally people have to make the commitment, rearrange their priorities,'' Donahue said. The Washington, D.C.-based National Coalition for the Homeless estimates 3 million homeless people live in the United States, Donahue said. Davis said the Salvation Army takes any help it can get and designs its volunteer programs to accommodate people's hectic schedules. ``We don't really have any problems getting people to volunteer so long as we keep it short-term,'' Davis said. ``We have always had short-term projects where a person does not need to commit for a year or two years. They can take on one family or visit one home.''

DOC.HEAD: Algerians Protest Language Law
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 Algerians marched through the capital and past the presidential palace Thursday to protest plans to ban use of foreign languages in all official business. Protesters said the proposal stems from political and religious intolerance and from excessively rapid Arabization of this NorthAfrican country. Hocine Ait-Ahmed, leader of the opposition Front of Socialist Forces, accused the government of ``complicity'' with Islamic forces who he said championed the law. He was not specific, but the Moslem fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front has emerged as the main opposition party. After winning local elections last summer, it tried to enforce the Islamic dress code in several towns. The language restriction would impact most on French speakers. French is the working language for many residents of this former French colony, but is considered elitist. It competes with Berber, spoken by nearly a third of Algeria's 27 million people. In his comments during the protest Thursday, Ait-Ahmed spoke Arabic and Berber. Under the proposed law, Arabic must be used in all official transactions and schools by 1997, with fines of up to $10,000 for violators. The Algerian Constitution cites Arabic as the national language, but does not forbid use of foreign languages. The national legislature passed the measure, 173-8. It must be signed by President Chadli Bendjedid before it can take effect.

DOC.HEAD: Ed McMahon Cancels Third Wedding
DOC.TEXT: Ed McMahon called off his marriage to restaurant hostess Joanna Ford, his publicist said Thursday. McMahon, 67, was to have wed Miss Ford on Jan. 12 at his Los Angeles home, publicist Charlie Barrett said. He gave no reason for the cancellation. It would have been the third marriage for McMahon and the second for Miss Ford, Barrett said. McMahon is Johnny Carson's sidekick on ``The Tonight Show'' and hosts the syndicated series ``Star Search.''

DOC.HEAD: Suriname Military: President's Ouster Was Legal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Graanoogst is not the military leader, but No. 2 man. Picks up 3rd graf, `The assembly . ..'
DOC.TEXT: The acting army chief of Suriname said Thursday the armed forces had acted legally in ousting the elected president and pledged that legislators will elect a new chief executive this week. Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst said the military's overthrow of President Ramsewak Shankar was constitutional because the National Assembly had been left in power. He denied the takeover was a military coup. The assembly convened Thursday morning for the first time since Shankar was overthrown. The constitution requires it to elect a new president and vice president when their posts are vacant. Graanoogst said Shankar and Vice President Henck Arron would present their resignations to the assembly. It will elect new chief executives to be installed Saturday, and they will set the date for elections to be held within 100 days, Graanoogst said. The assembly will also pick a new Cabinet, he said. ``There is no coup at all,'' Graanoogst said on television. ``The United States, the Netherlands, France and others who have protested are premature.'' Surinamese returned to work after the traditional two-day Christmas holiday. There was no unusual military presence in the streets of the capital of Paramaribo or any sign of protest. However, the U.S. State Department advised Americans not to travel to Suriname and for those living there to remain indoors. Suriname, a former Dutch colony, is an ethnically diverse country of 400,000 people on South America's northeastern coast. The Organization of American States summoned member states to a special meeting Friday to discuss a Venezuelan request for prompt action to restore the constitutional government in Suriname. Venezuela announced a day earlier it would not recognize the new government and demanded a ``firm response'' to the bloodless ouster. However, neighboring Brazil, a major power in South America, said through its embassy in Venezuela that it was opposes intervention. In defense of the military action, Graanoogst referred to two articles in the constitution that give the armed forces authority to ensure ``a peaceful transition to a democratic and socially just society.'' Graanoogst is No. 2 in the five-member Military Authority headed by Cmdr. Desi Bouterse, who is believed to be a key power behind the scenes. Bouterse ruled as dictator from 1982-87 and resigned as military chief just before the takeover. Graanoogst, head of the military police, stepped in as acting military head. A journalist who asked not to be identified for fear of reprisals said Shankar and Arron were resigning ``at gunpoint.'' Shankar was quoted by the newspaper De Ware Tijd as saying he is allowed to move freely but is staying home ``to prevent any escalations.'' Shankar was elected by the assembly in 1988 after his three-party coalition, the Front for Democracy and Development, won parliamentary elections a year earlier by a landslide. Shankar's ouster coincided with growing popular discontent over Suriname's deepening economic crisis. High inflation and unemployment have made it difficult for most Surinamese to pay for their basic needs. The government has a monthly trade deficit of $10 million. The downward spiral began during Bouterse's rule. Major factors were the military's inexperience in managing the economy; a drop in the world price of bauxite, the country's major export; and guerrilla warfare that disrupted production.

DOC.HEAD: American Plans to Reduce Schedule, Lay Off Employees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with American planning to cut flights, lay off some employees, details. No pick up. Version also moved on financial wire. Allied Pilots Association is cq.
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc. said Thursday it will reduce its schedule by about 4 percent and lay off an unspecified number of employees because it can't count on pilots showing up for work. The Fort Worth-based carrier, the nation's second largest, claims pilots have been staging sickouts, taxiing slowly to waste fuel and filing frivolous requests for equipment maintenance. The Allied Pilots Association, which represents the carrier's 8,700 pilots, have been in contract talks since October 1989. The old contract expired Jan. 1. The carrier won a temporary restraining order late Wednesday barring pilots from actions designed to influence contract negotiations, which have grown increasingly tense. But even with the court order ``we cannot count on all of our pilots coming to work,'' American spokesman Tim Smith said Thursday. By late Thursday, 24 flights were canceled, 13 of them crew-related, Smith said. Since Sunday, 352 flights have been canceled, including 78 that were crew-related. The airline handles about 2,300 flights per day. In a letter to cockpit crews sent Dec. 26 and released Thursday, Robert W. Baker, American's executive vice president for operations, said the job action will force the carrier to reduce its schedule. ``Unhappily, that will cause us to issue layoff notices to a number of employees in various categories and to increase the number and percentage of pilots on reserve,'' Baker said. Placing a pilot on reserve effectively reduces pay to a guaranteed minimum number of hours. A Jan. 3 hearing date has been set by U.S. District Judge John McBryde to determine whether the temporary injunction should be made permanent. The Allied Pilots Association called the temporary restraining order a ``rush to judgment'' and said it would challenge the ruling later. American spokesman Marty Heires said about 60 pilots called in sick shortly after the injunction was announced, but other pilots apparently decided to obey the court order. ``It's difficult to tell, but I would say that last night we saw a pretty substantial spike in the number of pilots who were calling in sick,'' Heires said. ``However, as the evening wore on, that number was offset by the number of pilots reporting back to work.'' Under the Railway Labor Act, airline employees cannot strike unless a federal judge declares talks to be at an impasse and sets a 30-day ``cooling off'' period. American's complaint alleged pilot actions also are prohibited under the act. Since last April, American Airlines officials said, there has been a marked increase in pilots' sick leave. Pilot sick hours peaked at 28,082 for November, compared with 19,319 pilot sick hours in November 1989. On Nov. 27, 386 American Airlines pilots were out sick, tying the company record for most out in one day. American said daily flight delays attributable to pilot actions have run as high as 215 on Dec. 19, compared with an average of 89 delays per day in 1989. The chief issue in the talks is money. The pilots say they want to eliminate the so-called B-scale salary schedule, or narrow the differences. Under the scale, pilots hired after 1983 are paid less and advance at a slower rate, compared with pilots hired before 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Skeptics Say Psychics' 1990 Predictions Flopped
DOC.TEXT: As predicted, the nation's most famous psychics failed to accurately forecast 1990 news events and in most cases were just plain wrong, the San Francisco Bay Area Skeptics said Thursday. Predictions that fizzled included a Jackie Onassis marriage to rock star Jon Bon Jovi and a tidal wave flooding New York City. Did you hear the one about the meteorite landing in the White House Rose Garden? Or the Japanese finding a cure for the common cold? ``These predictions can prove harmful, even dangerous,'' said Robert Steiner, the skeptics' spokesman. ``It becomes dangerous when you let other people control your lives with them.'' Each year the skeptics ``dig up the predictions made the year before to the embarrassment of those who made them,'' Steiner said. Steiner said no psychic predicted the genuinely surprising news stories of 1990, including the stunning electoral defeat of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. The year's top stories were ``so unanticipated that someone would have had to be really psychic to have predicted them,'' the group said in a statement. The skeptics describe themselves as ``a group of people from all walks of life who support the critical examination of paranormal claims.'' Psychic Jeane Dixon predicted that President Bush's greatest challenge would come over the summer when he would be forced to make ``life and-death decisions about troubles in Latin America and China.'' While those regions were relatively quiet over the summer ``Dixon somehow failed to foresee Bush having trouble with Iraq,'' the skeptics said. In a supermarket tabloid in July, Irene Hughes predicted Jacqueline Onassis would marry Bon Jovi and Bryant Gumbel would be fired from the ``Today'' show after a barroom brawl. In the same article, Marie Graciette of Los Angeles said the largest earthquake on record would hit the sea bed near New York City, producing a tidal wave that would flood Manhattan. She's also the psychic who predicted the meteorite in the Rose Garden and the cure for the common cold. ``Not one prediction which was both specific and surprising came true,'' the skeptics scoffed.

DOC.NOTE: EDs; INSERTS 5th graf: ``The extra,'' to specify additional motion less than a foot.
DOC.HEAD: Unusual Tides Expected Next Week
DOC.TEXT: A rare alignment of the sun, moon and Earth will produce higher and lower tides than usual from Sunday through Wednesday, raising the chances of coastal flooding, government forecasters said Thursday. It will be the second round this month of unusual tides. A similar astronomical arrangement Dec. 1 through Dec. 4. caused local flooding on the coast of the Gulf of Maine. Forecasters from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Thursday they expect the turn-of-the-year tides to be more pronounced on the West Coast than the East Coast. The Weather Service forecast no major storms on either coast, but onshore winds are possible on the New England coast on Tuesday and the mid-Atlantic coast Tuesday and Wednesday. The extra tidal displacement should amount to less than a foot, higher at high tide or lower at low tide, the forecasts said. But that could be enough to make a difference in some places. Heavy rain, snow or onshore winds could bring localized flooding, NOAA said. Extremely low tides could expose mariners to low-water hazards but could reduce the threat of flooding during a storm. People living and working in coastal areas were urged to consult tide tables and to be alert to weather forecasts. The positions of the sun, moon and earth which produce the unusual tides occur about once a year, like so: -Sunday, tropic tides, where the moon is at its maximum northern point above the equator during its monthly trip around the earth. -Monday, a full moon, or syzygy condition, in which the moon is on the opposite side of the earth from the sun. -Monday, perigee, where the moon is closer to the earth than at any other time in its monthly path. -Wednesday, perihelion, where the earth is closer to the sun than at any other time of the year. In addition, on Dec. 22 the sun passed the winter solstice, its maximum point south of the equator during the year.

DOC.HEAD: Children Essayists Say Love, Togetherness are Important for Families
DOC.TEXT: Divorce, drugs and child abuse are taking a toll on the American family, but a national essay contest asking children to define kinship showed they still believe family values are important. ``A family is like a stack of bricks, one depends on each other and that main brick is love,'' wrote one of about 1,800 children who submitted entries. ``A family is like a field of mice, they stick together. They don't wander alone,'' wrote another child. The winner of the contest for fifth-graders in 43 states was Courtney Whetstine of Mount Shasta, Calif. She wrote about her parents' divorce when she was 4. ``I was ready for the worst, but it worked out better than I thought it would,'' wrote Courtney, who is 10. She said she appreciated her parents' efforts not to fight in front of their children and their friendly relations after the divorce. A recurring theme in the entries was that love was more important than legal ties. The Springfield-based Mass Mutual Life Insurance Co. sponsored the contest through its American Family Values Program. The winner was announced earlier this month. The contest was advertised through Scholastic Magazine, a publication for children. Entries ranged from ``the brightest and most articulate to those who spoke from the heart,'' said Eva Dion, the project's director. Entries were mainly from middle-class students, including some who wrote as part of class projects, said Dr. Albert Solnit, senior research scientist with the Yale Child Study Center and a contest judge. ``It's important for people to realize that this was not an effort to create an epidemiological sample, it was an effort to get an articulate sample of what we might call the ideals in practice in the United States,'' Solnit said. In many cases, students wrote to impress judges with the warmth of their families. Solnit said the essays of about 170 finalists showed how families handled adversity. A panel of judges winnowed the finalists for Solnit's review, Ms. Dion said. ``We really were looking for something that we felt got to the heart of what they considered a family,'' she said. Sticking together seemed to be true measure of family for many contestants. ``Where do you go when your heart is broken?'' queried a Portland, Ore., girl. ``The Family Doctor. Your mother, father, sister even your brother no matter how rude weird or disgusting he is.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bomb Blasts Airport in Angolan Capital
DOC.TEXT: An explosion damaged the passenger terminal at the international airport in the Angolan capital of Luanda on Thursday, but caused no casualties, Portuguese television reported. It quoted Angolan government officials as saying the blast was caused by a bomb planted by UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola -the U.S.-backed rebel group fighting a 15-year-old civil war against Angola's leftist government. The explosion destroyed the VIP lounge, according to the late-night report on state-run RTP network. UNITA officials are scheduled to meet a government delegation in Portugal next month for peace talks. The two sides have met five times this year under Portuguese mediation. The civil war has raged since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. According to Angolan government figures, it has killed 350,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Urges Equatorial Guinea To Free Detainees
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Thursday it has urged Equatorial Guinea to release Antonio Ebang Mbele, a leading member of that African country's parliament arrested for advocating multiparty democracy. It said it received reports Mbele was under house arrest for proposing that parliament debate introducing multiparty democracy in the former Spanish colony. Mbele is vice president of the Chamber of People's Representatives, the national assembly. He reportedly was stripped of parliamentary privileges last month and placed under house arrest in Micomeseng, his home village. Amnesty, a world human rights group with headquarters in London, said 30 other people, including senior officials, have been arrested since Dec. 6 for their political views. It sent a letter Dec. 20 urging their release, the text of which was released Thursday. It expressed concern over reports that some of those held were ill-treated in custody. Equatorial Guinea, on the Atlantic coast between Gabon and Cameroon, is ruled by the sole legal party, the Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party, led by President Teodoro Obiang Nguema.

DOC.HEAD: Girls from Soweto Salvation Army Home Reported Seized, Raped
DOC.TEXT: An armed gang abducted and raped teen-aged girls from a Salvation Army home in a Christmas attack, news reports said Thursday. Salvation Army official June Dwyer said nine girls were abducted and six of them raped by 16 attackers who broke into the Salvation Army Girl's Home after midnight on Christmas, according to the independent South African Press Association. The news agency quoted her as saying the attackers forced open a rear security door to enter the building that housed 72 girls. ``They smashed the windows, damaged beds, took the presents we had for the girls, destroyed clothes and abducted nine girls,'' it quoted Ms. Dwyer as saying. ``Six of the girls were raped. All but one of them made it back to the home by (Wednesday) night.'' A police spokesman told the news agency the girls were raped near a Soweto train station. Police launched a search for the missing girl and the attackers, a local radio station reported. All the girls were moved from the home after the attack, media reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jewish Influx Breaking Records in Israel
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 Soviet Jews are arriving in Israel daily, setting a record pace that could push the number of immigrants from all countries to more than 200,000 this year, officials and news reports said Thursday. On Thursday, 2,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants poured into Israel, surpassing last weekend's high rate of 1,500 a day, said Yehuda Weinrab, a spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency. The organization helps resettle immigrants. Israeli officials have attributed the surge this month to increasing uncertainty about the political climate in the Soviet Union and better Israeli-sponsored transportation arrangements. Israel army radio said the latest surge likely would push the overall December immigration total to 35,000 and the year-end figure to 205,000. The totals include Ethiopians and other nationals, but Soviets make up about 90 percent. About 1 million Soviets are expected by the end of 1992. While Israeli officials encourage the immigration, it is causing major housing shortages and unemployment problems.

DOC.HEAD: Two Bombs Explode in Bank Holdup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT and CLARIFY sequence of events, customer chasing robber into parking lot. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: A robber put a sizzling pipe bomb on a bank counter Thursday, sending workers and customers running for cover and fleeing with a bag of cash before the device exploded. The masked man walked into the bank with the lighted bomb in one hand and a black gym bag in the other. He placed the pipe on a counter and ordered a teller to, ``Fill it up,'' said police Capt. Randy Johnson. The robber threw a second, simliar bomb at a customer who chased him into the parking lot of the First Union National Bank branch. That bomb also exploded but caused no damage. No one was injured in the holdup. The robber counted backward from 10 as the teller gave him the money, then he fled. About 10 people in the bank ran out about 45 seconds before the bomb made of a 7- to 10-inch pipe exploded inside, said Paul Daly, an FBI special agent. ``It sounded like thunder,'' said Brent Peters, a salesman at Pep Boys Auto Parts next door. ``It got real quiet, then it happened again.'' The inside blast shattered a window and created a large hole in the counter. Debris was strewn on the floor. Police said the robber ran behind the bank and through woods to a white four-wheel drive vehicle. No arrests were made by late Thursday. ``I saw all the bank employees running out of the bank and into our store,'' said Beth Allen, manager of Camera World next to the bank. ``They weren't screaming, but they were in a hurry to get here,'' she said. The holdup was taped by bank surveillance cameras.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prime Minister To Visit Korea
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will visit in January to discuss prospects for Korean unification and other issues with President Roh Tae-woo, South Korean officials said. Presidential spokesman Lee Soo-jung said the two men will hold talks Jan. 9-10 on cooperation between their nations and ways of promoting Korean unification through inter-Korean exchanges and reduced tension. Roh and Kaifu also will exchange views on changes in U.S.-Soviet relations, developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and efforts for peace and cooperation in Asia and the Pacific, Lee said. He said Kaifu's visit will also touch on improving the legal status of Koreans living in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Drug Money Goes Unspent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 11th graf: ``Hawaii's attorney,'' with explanation of state attorney general
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Drug Grants-States
DOC.TEXT: States have spent only about two-thirds of the anti-drug money provided by the federal government in the past four years, according to figures released Thursday by the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Of the $5.0 billion given out through three major block grant programs from the first quarter of 1987 through the third quarter of 1990, only $3.4 billion, or 68 percent, has been distributed by state and territorial governments to anti-drug programs, the figures show. Even top-ranked Arizona had spent only 83.4 percent of the $77.7 million it had received. Ranked second was Nevada, which had spent 79 percent of $26.7 million, followed by the U.S. territories, which had spent 77 percent of the $63.3 million they received. Coming in last was Puerto Rico, which had spent only 34.2 percent of the $31.7 million it had received. Next was Hawaii, spending 52 percent of $27.4 million, and Wyoming, spending 55 percent of $14.1 million. ``I think what's bringing the spending level down is the law enforcement grant, because there were such enormous increases in that in the last two years,'' said Bruce Carnes, director of planning, budget and administration for the drug control policy office. Justice Department anti-drug block grants jumped from $119 million in fiscal year 1989 to $395 million last year. They rise to $423 million this year. ``Some states have gone ahead and spent it pretty aggressively, some haven't,'' he said. Grants distributed by Health and Human Services for drug treatment and prevention are being spent at a much higher level - 82 percent - than those for education - 46 percent - and law enforcement - 40 percent, Carnes said. Carnes said of the overall spending level: ``Obviously I'd like to see it higher, but I'm not prepared to say they're not doing their jobs.'' However, he added, ``States that have low spendout rates, it would be desirable for them to step sharply on this.'' Hawaii's attorney general, Warren Price, said his state's fiscal procedures made the spending percentage misleadingly low. Eighty percent of the money is used by county prosecutors and police departments, but those agencies do not spend the federal dollars directly - they spend their own funds and later claim reimbursement from the federal money, which makes it seem as if the federal dollars are not being spent quickly, Price said. Though states and territorial governments have not distributed as much of the grant money as the drug control policy office would like, a report issued by the drug policy office Thursday said giving the grants directly to cities would unnecessarily delay delivery of the money to those who need it. The sum involved is substantial: $1.4 billion in the current fiscal year, provided under three programs run by the departments of Justice, Health and Human Services and Education. These grants go to the states for disbursement. Other federal anti-drug grants bring the total to $2.6 billion this year, or one-fourth of the total budget for the war against drugs. The report said the time it takes the federal government to distribute the money to the states has been reduced in the past few years. For example, the federal government's review process dropped from 46 days last year to 28 days this year. But cities complain they're not getting what they need to combat the severe drug problems they face, and they have argued for direct federal funding to local governments. The report, however, said that trying to speed up the process by having direct federal funding of city programs would put a tremendous burden on the federal government, which would have to review thousands of applications from local governments. This would sow the process considerably, the report said. Patrick V. Murphy, former New York City police commissioner who now directs the U.S. Conference of Mayors' police policy board, argued that the time lag isn't the point. ``The mayors feel that although the drug problem is being driven by recreational users ... and many of them are in the suburbs, the worst problems - the murder and violence among the kids who get into the traffic and the delays for treatment for low-income people who don't have health insurance - are in the cities,'' Murphy said. The drug control office's report acknowledges such criticisms but asserts: ``States are closer to the problem than federal administrators and can more quickly react to changes in local requirements.'' Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics, said: ``The administration can claim credit if it wants to for quickly dispatching these billions of dollars to the states, but the fact is, they are not reaching the right people.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pentagon Plans to Vaccinate U.S. Troops in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon plans to begin vaccinating U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf against possible germ warfare, according to a published report. The New York Times reported in its Friday editions that senior administration officials have recommended proceeding with the inoculation program. The plan is part of an effort to protect military personnel from biological weapons, including the use of masks and other protective garments. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has repeatedly denied having biological weapons although Iraq used chemical weapons against some rebellious Kurds in its own country and against Iran during its war with that country. Army Lt. Col. Steve Roy, a spokesman for the Department of Defense, declined comment Thursday night about the report of inoculations of Desert Shield troops. ``We wouldn't comment on anything that might be an operational matter,'' he said. Administration officials told the Times the plan was prompted by CIA reports that Iraq had stockpiled chemical and biological weapons. The Times said it was unclear how many troops might be vaccinated but said officials believe it will be those Americans who are most likely to be threatened by biological weapons, such as anthrax. Unlike chemical weapons, biological weapons are based on living agents like viruses and bacteria. They can be used to spread diseases like typhoid, cholera and bacteria. The Times said the inoculations could begin ``in a matter of weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Denture Adhesives Recalled After Carcinogen Found
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, background. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: The makers of three denture adhesives recalled the products Thursday because traces of cancer-causing benzene were detected, authorities said. The adhesives are Orafix Special, Brace and Cushion Grip. Richard Kessel, chairman of the state Consumer Protection Board, said the agency found benzene in the adhesives after receiving a tip from ``someone in the industry.'' The adhesives pose no immediate health threat and the Food and Drug Administration is testing all denture adhesives as a precaution, Kessel said. The FDA encouraged consumers to stop using the three products that were voluntarily recalled nationwide. ``While this is not believed to be an acute health hazard, it could pose a danger to denture adhesive users over many years, the FDA and state agree,'' Kessel said. Tests of Orafix Special showed it contained 191 parts of benzene per million, the FDA said in a statement. Brace contained 190 ppm and Cushion Grip contained 65 ppm. Benzene, a naturally occurring chemical used in solvents, was also detected in Fasteeth at 29 parts per billion and Fixodent at 12 ppb. ``These benzene levels, although detectable in the laboratory, are considered by the agency to present a negligible risk,'' the FDA said. FDA officials consider any benzene exposure above 5 ppb to have possible adverse health effects. No benzene was found in five other denture adhesives: Super Poli Grip, Orafix Original, Effergrip, CVS and Confident. Smithkline Beecham Consumer Brands of Pittsburgh, Pa. recalled Orafix Special and Brace. Cushion Grip was recalled by Plough Inc. of Memphis, Tenn., a subsidiary of Schering-Plough Corp. of Madison, N.J. Smithkline said in a statement that it recalled the two brands ``due to minute amounts of benzene in the products.'' Schering-Plough spokesman Lewis Nowlan said the company ``believes the trace concentration do not pose a health hazard. However, in accordance with long-standing corporate policy, the company suspended all manufacturing of the product.'' Benzene forced a recall this year for French mineral water giant Perrier. The company withdrew 160 million bottles worldwide, including 72 million bottles in the United States and Canada. Perrier officials said benzene entered their water in trace amounts when workers failed to change a pipe filter at the company's plant in southern France, where water from a natural spring is mixed with naturally-occurring carbon dioxide gas.

The nation grew to 249.6 million people in the 1980s as more Americans left the industrial and agricultural heartlands for the South and West. The Census Bureau's first ``final'' figures from the 1990 census, released Wednesday, showed the pull of the Sun Belt remained strong, despite efforts by the industrial North to promote growth and the collapse during the 1980s of the oil and savings and loan industries - two mainstays of the Southern and Western states. The census figures are used to adjust the number of representatives each state sends to Congress so that political clout is in line with population. The figures also determine the division of federal money among states and localities. The numbers could change next summer when the Commerce Department decides whether to adjust the count. Some states and cities are likely to challenge the tallies, whichever way the adjustment decision goes. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Most Americans have not planned for critical medical decisions they some day may have no control over, but Nancy Cruzan's ``right-to-die'' struggle made them more aware of their options, experts say. The publicity surrounding Ms. Cruzan's case, said Doron Weber, a spokesman for the Society for the Right to Die, ``generated a 500 percent increase in the requests we receive.'' Weber said his New York-based organization has filled 800,000 requests for sample living wills and similar documents since the Supreme Court's decision in the Cruzan case last June. ``The volume from all over the country, which we tracked directly from the Cruzan case, was incredible. We had to start a night shift,'' he said. ---= LYON, France (AP) - For Garry Kasparov, it was the world chess title and something more. It was the ultimate vindication of him and his flamboyant style over the surgical precision of his introspective rival, Anatoly Karpov. Kasparov defeated Karpov, a fellow Soviet, for the fourth time in a world chess championship on Wednesday by playing him to a draw in the 22nd game. The half point each player received put Kasparov ahead 12-10 and let him retain the crown. He had won four games to Karpov's two. The rest were draws. At age 22 in 1985, Kasparov won the title from Karpov to become the youngest champion in history. He defended the crown by beating Karpov in 1986 and 1987. ---= VATICAN CITY (AP) - She sent Christopher Columbus on his voyage and opened up the New World for the spread of Catholicism, but did Queen Isabella I of Spain have the stuff of saints? Jews and Moslems are outraged by the idea. The Vatican is studying a petition that supporters hope will put the queen on the road to possible sainthood in time for 1992, when the church plans to celebrate 500 years of Christianity in the Americas. One of the most significant figures in Spanish history, Isabella commissioned the voyage of Columbus in 1492 to the New World. Isabella is also remembered as the queen who expelled the Jews and Moslems from Spain and for the dreaded Inquisition that began during her rule with her husband, Ferdinand II. Samuel Toledano, head of the Federation of Spanish Jewish Communities, calls Isabella ``a symbol of intolerance.'' The Vatican petition, he said, ``would reopen old wounds that we thought were closed forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Correspondents and Masterpiece Theater
DOC.TEXT: English writer Evelyn Waugh hated television. He called it ``insufferable.'' London Weekend Television adapted Waugh's classic novel ``Scoop'' for the small screen. British TV critics called it ``disappointing.'' If you're a British journalist, there's plenty to be disappointed about in this 1937 book that pillories the boozing, lying and lazy meanderings of His Majesty's supposedly noble and learned overseas press corps. But if you're not a British reporter, or if you actually know a foreign correspondent, ``Scoop'' is hilarious. And right on the mark. Americans will have a chance to see it Sunday on PBS' ``Masterpiece Theater,'' the 20-year-old epitome of good taste hosted by Alistair Cooke. This version, made three years ago by London Weekend Television, was roundly criticized when shown on British television for leaving out some of the book's more biting anecdotes. The two-hour movie is a little long on spectacle, having been filmed in London and Morocco and populated by long, wide sets boasting staircases that rival the Tower of Babel. It is, however, far from shallow. Waugh's humor stings like gin poured over a paper cut. In keeping with that, the British television movie is true not only to the book's details, but to its tone as well. It stars Donald Pleasence as Lord Copper, the megalomaniac publisher of The Beast, owned by Megapolitan Newspaper Corp.; Denholm Elliott as Salter, his fawning, felicitous foreign editor, and Michael Maloney as William Boot, the dimwitted garden columnist whose prose is so dense only a hand grenade can dislodge its cumbersome sentences. How Boot is sent overseas as a foreign correspondent is such a ridiculous instance of mistaken identity it qualifies as a Marx Brothers routine. Trouble is, in the time in which ``Scoop'' is set, such absurdities were only too possible. Written more than 50 years ago, Waugh's story skewers Fleet Street's popular press and its warring newspaper correspondents who invented quotes and even entire battles to titillate readers and tweak competitors. Waugh knew of which he wrote. In 1935, as a correspondent for London's Daily Mail, he covered Benito Mussolini's war with Abyssinia (now Ethiopia). Waugh's journalistic credentials for this foreign posting? He had previously visited Abyssinia. In ``Scoop,'' Boot is sent by The Beast to the make-believe African country of Ishmaelia, where war has broken out. Boot arrives, collapsible canoe and full Christmas dinner in hand, to find a horde of tight-knit, whiskey-filled correspondents. No one, however, can find the war. They don't call it pack journalism for nothing. Former Waugh colleagues have recently written that ``Scoop's'' portrayals are infinitely closer to fact than fiction. During the Abyssinian war, one British journalist came equipped with a camel. When his paper questioned the purchase submitted on his expense account, the intrepid correspondent cabled back ``Glad you reminded me - cremation of one camel, 10 pounds.'' Waugh himself, despite his sense of humor and the absurd, was anything but a happy soul. He abhorred television and driving. He loved to drink. Shortly before his death in 1966 at age 62, he described his daily routine thusly: ``I get up late. I try to read my letters. I try to read the paper. I have some gin. I try to read the paper again. I have some more gin.'' He hung out with Oxford grads in a men's club that included Graham Greene, Anthony Powell, Cyril Connolly, Harold Acton and John Betjeman. ``Masterpiece Theater'' has had good luck with Waugh's works. Its adaptation of Waugh's ``Brideshead Revisted'' was a programming milestone. ``Scoop,'' despite bad reviews from its British debut, is well worth the attention of American viewers - if for no other reason than its delivery of things not frequently seen on the U.S. telly: Very witty dialogue and a script that provokes thought. --- Elsewhere in television... Doogie's girlfriend must cope with the accidental death of her mother.

DOC.HEAD: Mega-Musical Producer Offers One Hit ``Moe''
DOC.TEXT: Cameron Mackintosh, Britain's leading producer of the mega-musical, has an unexpected hit in a small-scale production that leaves its audience shouting for ``Moe.'' ``It's a marvelous accident; the pieces fell in together,'' Mackintosh said of ``Five Guys Named Moe.'' The musical revue of American jazzman Louis Jordan opened Dec. 14 at the Lyric Theater. Its West End arrival follows a sellout run at the ``fringe'' Theater Royal, Stratford East, in east London. Mackintosh saw the show there in October and decided during the intermission to fund a commercial transfer. ``I literally went for a fun night out at the theater; I was bowled over,'' the producer recalled in an interview, before hopping a plane to Madrid to tend to that city's staging of ``Les Miserables.'' The most successful producer in the theater today, the 44-year-old Mackintosh, has ``Cats,'' ``Les Miserables'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera'' running in London, on Broadway and around the world. His current London smash ``Miss Saigon'' opens April 11 in New York, where the advance sale exceeds $31 million. ``Five Guys Named Moe'' has a budget of about $770,000, less than two weeks running costs for ``Phantom of the Opera'' on Broadway. ``In the end, I never get hooked on scale,'' Mackintosh said. ``I do a show because I like it.'' Others like it, too. Kate Kellaway in The Observer said this ``tremendous show comes closer to a party than anything I have seen on stage before.'' If attendance continues at present capacity levels, the show will recoup in 10-12 weeks, Mackintosh said. The show pays exuberant tribute to Jordan, the alto saxophonist who died in 1975 at the age of 66. Its two hours of calypso, swing and bebop embrace such songs as ``There Ain't Nobody Here But Us Chickens,'' ``Messy Bessy,'' ``Saturday Night Fish Fry'' and the title song. The audience chimes in, too, joining the cast in a conga line and singing to the words ``push ka pi shi pie - eh eh'' printed on pieces of paper which the ushers distribute. The six singer-dancers - three Britons and three Ameicans - include the musical's creator, Clarke Peters, an American based in London on and off since 1973. The director-choreographer is fellow American Charles Augins. Peters has had his share of previous successes, starring in the London companies of ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and August Wilson's ``Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.'' The 38-year-old Peters is reaping the benefits of five years work on ``Five Guys,'' which began when he was appearing in ``Carmen Jones'' in 1985 at the Crucible Theater in Sheffield, south Yorkshire. ``We were doing an evening of good company, and I had this idea of five guys coming out of this guy's bed just as he was about to crash out after a depressing evening with his lady,'' Peter said. In the current version, Nomax (Dig Wayne) is a depressed radio deejay taken by surprise early one morning when five song-and-dance men leap out of his radio to offer advice to the lovelorn of the most rollicking and bluesy sort. Mackintosh said the musical found ``exactly the right weight: It's not a compilation show, but it's not striving to be a biopic.'' ``It treads that line so wonderfully cleverly,'' he said. ``Five Guys Named Moe'' is rare for Mackintosh in that he tends to produce his musicals from scratch, spending years getting them in shape. In November, he opened another small musical, ``Just So,'' at northwest London's Tricycle Theater, where it runs through Jan. 12. Has ``Five Guys'' put him in the market for other shows, once ``Miss Saigon'' is up and running on Broadway? ``Absolutely not,'' Mackintosh said. ``Look, this is a very extraordinary circumstance; this sort of show doesn't happen very often.'' And what about the future of ``Five Guys''? ``I think this is a Broadway show myself,'' he said. ``It will be a nice problem to worry about whilst I'm hopefully in New York with `Saigon.'''
