DOC.HEAD: New Freedom To Worship in Eastern Europe Top Religion Story
DOC.TEXT: The wave of religious freedom sweeping over Eastern Europe and the efforts of Western religious groups to bring the church in from the cold was the top religion news story of 1990, according to a poll. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, who won the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in introducing democratic changes in Eastern Europe and easing East-West conflicts, also was selected as religion newsmaker of the year for the second year in a row in the voting by 45 members of the Religion Newswriters Association. Evangelist Billy Graham finished second. In the Soviet Union, official tolerance for religion has increased greatly since Gorbachev came to power in 1985. In the last two years, many churches have been reconsecrated and Soviet citizens have flocked to services in record numbers. The Soviet legislature this fall approved a freedom of conscience bill promised by Gorbachev when he met with Pope John Paul II at the Vatican last December. The law forbids the government from interfering in the practice of religion, formally ending decades of repression. With the door to evangelism opened, many Western churches are sponsoring missionary efforts in Eastern Europe, bringing in teachers, preachers, equipment, building funds and Bibles. Organizations from the United Methodist Church to the Southern Baptist Convention have planned projects in Eastern Europe. U.S. Roman Catholic bishops have established a special committee on ways to aid Eastern Europe, and Jewish groups concerned about the dangers of a renewal of anti-Semitism have jumped in to help long-dormant churches realize the fruits of decades of ecumenical advances in the West. Sex scandals took second place in the poll. Roman Catholic Archbishop Eugene A. Marino resigned July 10 after revelations of an ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman, and the Rev. Allen Boesak resigned Aug. 10 as president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches after admitting an extramarital affair with a married television producer. The Rev. Bruce Ritter left the Covenant House organization he founded amid accusations by male youths of sexual affairs. He has denied wrongdoing. The continuing conflict in the nation's largest Protestant denomination, the Southern Baptist Convention, ranked third. Conservatives elected a fundamentalist to the presidency and fired the two top editors of the denomination's press service, and moderates withheld some funds from convention agencies. In fourth place was the suspension of two Lutheran congregations in San Francisco by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America for ordaining and installing acknowledged homosexuals. Presiding Episcopal Bishop Edmond L. Browning reprimanded Bishop John Spong of Newark, N.J., for ordaining a declared homosexual, the Rev. Robert Williams. Spong later suspended Williams for making public remarks disparaging monogamy and the celibacy of Mother Teresa. A historic conference of South African black and white churches condemning the policy of racial separation known as apartheid ranked fifth. Anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela, released from prison Feb. 11, received financial and moral support from U.S. religious leaders on a summer tour. A Supreme Court ruling upholding the denial of unemployment benefits to two drug counselors fired for using peyote, an illegal, hallucinogenic drug, in an American Indian religious ceremony ranked sixth. Religious leaders expressed concern the ruling overturned past precedent that the governent must show a ``compelling state interest'' to force compliance with a law that conflicts with a religious practice. In seventh place was the efforts of U.S. religious leaders to urge non-military solutions to the Persian Gulf crisis. The National Council of Churches has urged the administration to halt its military buildup in the Persian Gulf and begin withdrawing troops, and the National Conference of Catholic Bishops has repeatedly expressed reservations about the possibility of a U.S. offensive. The assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane, an anti-Arab militant, ranked eighth. Many considered Kahane a bigot and a demagogue for calling Arabs dogs and advocating their expulsion from Israel, but some considered him a freedom fighter determined to avoid another Holocaust. In ninth place were Catholic guidelines on theologians and church-affiliated universities. The Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith ordered theologians to refrain from publicly challenging church teaching, and Pope John Paul instructed Catholic universities to uphold official doctrine but rejected a proposal to give bishops wide powers over the schools. The decision by U.S. Catholic bishops to hire a public relations firm to oppose abortion rounded out the top 10. Some groups favoring legalized abortion criticized the decision as being politically motivated and a waste of money, but church leaders defended the decision. ``We believe that the most critical issue in the United States is the problem of abortion, and if we believe that, then we should try to use the best possible means to communicate,'' Cardinal John J. O'Connor of New York said.

DOC.TEXT: A booklet issued by the American Jewish Committee contends that a ``new activism'' by pro-Palestinians within Christian churches seeks to undermine sympathy for Israel and is putting Israel at risk. Advocacy in the churches of Palestinian Arab political goals has taken an increasingly anti-Israel tilt ``in that failure to achieve either peace or stability in the Middle East is laid almost entirely at Israel's door,'' the booklet says. Called ``Israel at Risk, the Campaign to Erode Christian Support,'' the booklet says the anti-Israel campaign ``projects a negative and hostile view of Israel's motives, combined with a frequently uncritical endorsement of Palestinian claims.'' --- FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) - A United Methodist bishop says the next missionary challenge for U.S. Christians is not overseas, but among teen-agers and young adults in American communities. Bishop Leroy C. Hodapp of Indianapolis, president of the denomination's 100-member Council of Bishops, attributed the church's membership decline in recent years to its failure to involve the young. Unless it finds ways to do so, the denomination could ``die in one generation,'' he said at a news conference. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Gillian Martin Sorensen, who from 1978 until this year served as the city's liaison officer with foreign diplomats posted in New York, has been elected president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. She succeeds Jacqueline Greenan Wexler, who headed the organization for eight years in its work to promote religious, racial and ethnic harmony in American society. --- LYNCHBURG, Va. (AP) - Lutheran, Episcopal and Roman Catholic bishops in Virginia have entered into a covenant billed as one of the closest such working partnerships in the country. The agreement was signed by bishops and 160 other representatives at the close of the state's annual LARC (Lutheran, Anglican, Roman Catholic) Conference. Bishops of the three denominations committed themselves to various programs and actions to strengthen unity, ranging from praying for each other to developing cooperation in institutions, chaplaincies and campus ministries to working together in evangelism and social justice. In a related move in Minnesota, a Lutheran-Catholic covenant was signed between Catholic Archbishop John R. Roach of St. Paul-Minneapolis and bishops of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America in those two cities. This was believed to be the second Lutheran-Catholic covenant, an earlier one being signed in Chicago. Catholics and Lutherans are reported working toward such accords in North Carolina and New England.

DOC.TEXT: MISSISSIPPI: The call-up of Mississippi National Guardsmen and reservists as a result of Operation Desert Shield. Nearly every community, large and small, across the state was affected as 50 units were activated for military service. MISSOURI: The earthquake that didn't happen. Climatologist Iben Browning shook up people living along the New Madrid fault in southeastern Missouri and nearby states when he said there was a 50 percent chance of a major earthquake on or about Dec. 3. The comment caused school closings and prompted some people to leave their homes temporarily. MONTANA: Violence on college campuses. On May 15, two freshmen at Montana State University were killed in their dormitory with a shotgun. Police said another freshman apparently believed the pair had vandalized his truck. Three days later, a man shot at a group of Carroll College employees, killing one and wounding another. Police said the man offered no motive. NEBRASKA: Democrat Ben Nelson's narrow election as governor over Republican incumbent Kay Orr. Nelson, a lawyer, had to wait 48 days after the May primary before being declared winner of the Democratic nomination by 42 votes. He defeated Orr in November by about 4,000 votes. NEVADA: A compromise agreement in Congress on allocating water from Lake Tahoe and the Truckee and Carson rivers. The deal sets shares for the states of California and Nevada and the cities, utilities, farmers and Indian tribes in Nevada who have dueled over water rights for more than 80 years. NEW HAMPSHIRE: The woes of New Hampshire's once-thriving economy, battered lately by a slumping real estate market and by layoffs at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard and the state capital. The state ranks first in growth of welfare cases and bankruptcy filings, and second in business failures. NEW JERSEY: Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package and school finance reform program. Florio pushed the program through the Legislature in June, touching off a storm among voters already distressed about high property taxes and a weakening economy. NEW MEXICO: The disappearance of a 6-year-old Clovis boy in May and the discovery of his body about two weeks later in a storage compartment of a station wagon in the family driveway. The search for Matthew Roberts drew up to 8,000 volunteers in a community of about 35,000. The asphyxiation death was ruled accidental. NORTH CAROLINA: Republican Jesse Helms' re-election to the U.S. Senate in a campaign marked by charges of racism. Television ads for Helms in the final week of the campaign tied the Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, to racial quotas for hiring, a charge Gantt vehemently denied. OKLAHOMA: The state's hotly debated education reform and tax package. The law includes $223 million in new taxes and teacher pay raises, school consolidation and a plan to close schools not meeting certain accreditation requirements. OREGON: Protections for the northern spotted owl and the impact on logging. The federal government put the bird on the threatened species list in June, forcing a cutback in logging to preserve the owl's habitat. Mills across Oregon shut down as they were caught in a squeeze between a national downturn in construction and high prices for raw materials. PENNSYLVANIA: Passage of the nation's most stringent abortion control law. In August, a federal judge threw out key provisions of the law, including notification of the father before an abortion could be performed, a 24-hour waiting period and parental permission for minors. RHODE ISLAND: A listless economy that deteriorated into recession. Rhode Island's real estate industry collapsed and problems spread to overextended banks. The economy also was hit by layoffs at the state's largest private employer, the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics Corp. SOUTH CAROLINA: Bribery and corruption at the Statehouse. The scandal broke in July when the FBI subpoenaed campaign records of all 170 legislators. Ten legislators and one lobbyist were indicted. Seven have pleaded guilty and one was convicted at trial; three await a trial. SOUTH DAKOTA: The activation of almost 1,000 South Dakota National Guard and reserve members because of Operation Desert Shield. As the year's end neared, two Guard and one Army Reserve unit were on duty in the Persian Gulf and five units were at U.S. camps awaiting further assignment. TENNESSEE: The call-up of Tennessee National Guardsmen and other military reservists to bolster the U.S. military preparations for Operation Desert Shield. Approximately 3,000 Tennessee residents were called to service. TEXAS: A long and loud gubernatorial campaign. Democrat Ann Richards overcame a 15-point deficit in the polls six weeks before the election and upset gaffe-prone millionaire Clayton Williams in a contest of big spending and mudslinging. UTAH: The role of Utah National Guard and reserve units in the U.S. buildup for Operation Desert Shield. Some Utah hospitals were left shorthanded when the Guard's 114th Evacuation Hospital and the Army Reserve's 328th General Hospital were activated. VERMONT: The election of socialist independent Bernard Sanders to the U.S. House. Sanders rode a wave of discontent with Congress to oust first-term incumbent Peter Smith, a Republican. He will be the only member of Congress not affiliated with the Republican or Democratic caucuses. VIRGINIA: The inauguration of Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. The Democratic official made history when he took the oath of office on Jan. 13 as the nation's first elected black governor. WASHINGTON: Problems in the timber industry. Loggers were hit by habtitat protections for the northern spotted owl and by a congressional ban on exporting logs from government forests. Timber product sales also slowed from the national downturn in construction. WEST VIRGINIA: The imprisonment of former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. Fifteen months after losing a re-election bid, the Republican who dominated politics in a largely Democratic state pleaded guilty May 8 to extortion, obstruction of justice, mail fraud and two counts of tax fraud. WISCONSIN: The Lawrencia Bembenek case. The 32-year-old former Playboy club waitress and policewoman became a folk hero after her July escape from prison, where she was serving a life sentence for the 1981 killing of her husband's ex-wife. She and her lover were captured in Canada in October. WYOMING: The latest delay in the execution of Mark Hopkinson for murder. On death row since 1979, Hopkinson, who maintains his innocence, came within two days of being executed in September when a federal judge stayed the execution so he could consider defense motions challenging the sentence.

DOC.HEAD: For Rlease PMs Friday, Dec. 28
Reflecting On the Big Economic Expansion
DOC.TEXT: In its early years it was robust, but by the mid-1980s it was bogging down in excesses and inconsistencies, and for the past few years it has just been stumbling along. Now it is over, the great economic expansion that began in the fall of 1982, the longest since the end of World War II, and by some measures the mightiest ever generated. There are those who disagree about that, of course, and they have good reasons. Federal budget deficits are uncontrolled. Debt, much of it never to be repaid, permeates and undermines the foundation. Those weaknesses are obvious. Less evident are defects that emerge only after scrutiny, such as that real earnings of workers in the non-farm economy have declined for most of the past 20 years. It's seldom referred to. Perhaps the most fundamental defects of all, the violations of old standards and the corruption of values, rate very little attention. But they are there, right at the base of most of the problems. Volumes are written about fixing up the system, but will it do much good if the same wild breaches of business decorum erupt again? Such as: - So-called victimless, white-collar securities crimes. One defense of convicted inside traders, stock manipulators and other securities law violators of the 1980s is that their crimes caused no deaths. Maybe not, but they caused lost jobs and distressed companies. - Bankers who made loans of other people's money to borrowers they knew were reckless and undeserving. They placed billions of dollars at risk, sometimes while turning down more deserving, more productive corporate citizens. Those were so-called business decisions, and so long as the letter of the law, if not its spirit, was observed, nobody will go to jail. Some perpetrators will escape without even a tarnished reputation. Some might get bonuses. - Members of corporate boards of directors who didn't do their jobs. The director's job is to protect interests of the shareholders, to be their agent, and to see that the company is properly run in their interest. Clearly, hundreds of boards failed in this reponsibility. Some directors didn't know what was going on, some didn't care, and judging by events, some appear to have acquiesced in activities they should have prevented. One of the most common violations of trust involved repeated raises to managers who failed to handle their duties properly. Some directors, for example, agreed to bonuses for inferior performance. - Executives who lived off their companies rather than contributed to them, seemingly more interested in perks than profits. - The departure from old standards that caused people we like to consider most astute to make the most stupendous blunders. Who made those blunders? Bankers, brokers, attorneys, accountants, members of Congress. - The Congress, which repeatedly told America it was cutting spending, but which raised spending and deficits to levels that a decade ago would have been incomprehensible, by quietly seeking and getting funds for pet projects. The list could go on. Almost anyone can make a different one, but they can demonstrate the same point: Yes, there was an erosion of standards and values during the great expansion of the past eight years, and it too has to be fixed.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday, Dec. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Somewhere Over the Rainbow-Colored Bridge
DOC.TEXT: For Stan Edmister, bridges are a canvas. Where an engineer sees a mass of concrete and steel, he sees a potential masterpiece. ``If paint is going to be put on a bridge to sustain its life, why should it be brown or gray or pastel green, when it could be a lively combination of colors?'' says the 51-year-old artist. Two years ago, Edmister won a $10,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts to design a color scheme for the Guilford Avenue bridge in Baltimore. The result was so pleasing, one NEA official said, that Edmister was awarded a second $10,000 grant to select colors for 15 other bridges that cross Interstate 83. As the bridges are rehabilitated, they will be painted according to Edmister's design. Jeff Soule, special project manager at the NEA in Washington, said the award committee hopes Edmister's work will spur other cities to treat their public works as art. ``We felt it would be a national model in improving the appearance of ordinary structural elements in the urban environment. It is a very, very pragmatic application of art. It elevates public works and at the same time, it makes art accessible,'' Soule said. He's uncomfortable with muted hues that allow behemoths to settle anonymously into the background. So he experiments with vibrant greens, yellows, oranges and foil appliques that change color. He selects colors to highlight the design of a bridge and its setting, he says. He wants to treat the bridges over Interstate 83 as a continuum - related, yet each with its own temperament. ``Driving under and through the city, there is a series of tunnel arches or bridge covers that sets up a natural rhythm. There should be some sort of color theme uniting them, but there should not be a bland blanket similarity from one to another,'' he said. The arches of the Guilford Avenue bridge are bright green, gray and henna. Vertical yellow bands link arch to deck. Girders on the underside are green and yellow. Iridescent green stripes along the bridge's gray fence appear to change color when the sun strikes them. The painting was part of a $3.8 million bridge rehabilitation. City officials say they don't know whether the special treatment cost more than if a single color had been used. Harry McCullough, chief of Baltimore's interstate bridge division, said the city sought just one contract and didn't seek a comparison bid. The cost of cleaning and painting the bridge was $137,000, well below the engineer's estimate of $210,000, he said. The federal government provided 85 percent of the rehabilitation money. Porter Barrows, division administrator of the Federal Highway Administration in Maryland, said the government allowed the special painting after determining the additional cost would be minimal. ``I don't want to say that the cost isn't important, because it is,'' he said. ``But we felt the proposal was legitimate and interesting. It resulted in some interesting comments, I think.'' The federal government must approve Edmister's colors, which include the vibrant green used for road signs and the bright yellow used for center lines. Foils must be used in moderation. The government toned down Edmister's initial idea for the Guilford Avenue bridge, fearing it would be too distracting to motorists. Not everyone approves of his concepts, Edmister said, although the Guilford bridge has converted some skeptics. ``I remember a few engineers who said they disliked an artist tampering in their arena and certainly didn't like a carnival-like color scheme being used,'' he said. ``Now that the bridge is done, and the newness is starting to settle in, or the familiarity is becoming apparent, these same engineers are accepting it.''

DOC.TEXT: On the stage where one expects the great plays of Shakespeare, Chekhov and Arthur Miller, audiences instead are finding a mole, a rat, a badger and a toad. ``The Wind in the Willows,'' adapted by Alan Bennett from the much-loved Kenneth Grahame book, has provided the National Theater with the kind of smash usually associated with big West End musicals. Set alongside Grahame's famous River Bank, the play charts the burgeoning friendships of four variously furry and scaly creatures whose lessons for humanity are clear. Toad, the mansion-owning braggart, learns modesty, even as Rat and Mole cross social and class barriers to strike up an enduring friendship. The play ends with a garden party celebrating the best traits of Englishness: restraint, humility and gentility which the characters collectively embody. DOC.HEAD: Elections, Politicians Were Top Stories in Many States This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with North Dakota's top story. Also moved for Friday PMs. There either was no polls in Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Hawaii, Maryland, New York and Ohio.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Top 10 Stories
DOC.TEXT:
Hard-fought election campaigns, statehouse scandals and other political developments were the top stories in many states in 1990, according to polls of Associated Press newpaper editors and broadcast journalists. In several states, the call-up of military reservists as a result of Operation Desert Shield was voted the top story. Here is a look at the top story in the 43 states where the AP polled editors about a state's important news in 1990:
ALABAMA: The Alabama National Guard's leading role in the Persian Gulf callup. Guard officials say more guardsmen were called into service from Alabama than from any other state following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some 4,600 men and women were activated from Alabama's Army and Air National Guard, and the Pentagon also called up 884 from the Army Reserve and 400 from the Marine and Navy reserves. ALASKA: Wally Hickel's political comeback to the governor's mansion on a third-party ticket almost a quarter-century after he first served there. Hickel jumped into the race in September, upsetting the Republican Party by pulling Jack Coghill, then the GOP candidate for lieutenant governor, onto his Alaskan Independence Party ticket. ARIZONA: The Senate Ethics Committee investigation of Arizona's two U.S. senators, John McCain and Dennis DeConcini, and the rest of the ``Keating Five.'' It was the second straight year that the saga of Charles Keating Jr.'s crumbling financial empire topped the news in Arizona. ARKANSAS: Attorney General Steve Clark's conviction on charges related to use of his state credit card to wine and dine friends, girlfriends, political supporters and family. Clark, who was fined $10,000 and resigned his office, is appealing the verdict. He had been considered the top candidate for governor when 1990 began, but he was forced to quit the race. CALIFORNIA: Republican Pete Wilson's victory in the governor's race against Democrat Dianne Feinstein, who was the state's first major female contender for the job. The campaign was the most expensive state race in the nation's history, ultimately totaling nearly $50 million for all candidates in the primary and general elections. COLORADO: A tornado that devastated the farming community of Limon the night of June 6. The tornado tore an S-shape path through the community of 1,800, destroying 117 homes and 23 businesses and causing $12.4 million in damage. More than 150 people were left homeless, but the town was spared any deaths or serious injuries. FLORIDA: The grisly murders of five college students in Gainesville. The slayings of four women and a young man at the beginning of the school year terrorized the university town. No killer has been caught. IDAHO: The fight over abortion. Legislators passed what would have been the nation's most restrictive abortion law in March, but Gov. Cecil Andrus vetoed it a half-hour after the Legislature adjourned. In the November election, two pro-choice Democrats defeated two incumbent anti-abortion Republicans to throw the Senate into a 21-21 tie. ILLINOIS: The activation of Illinois National Guard and Army reserve units for Operation Desert Shield. Most of the hundreds of men and women called went willingly, including Air Force Reserve Sgt. Lorain Kuryla, 63, whose grandchildren called her ``Grambo.'' More publicized was the case of Spec. 4 Stephanie Atkinson, 23, who refused to join her unit, saying she had become a conscientious objector. She was arrested and later discharged ``under other than honorable conditions.'' INDIANA: The story of a child ripped from his mother's arms by fierce winds and killed as 20 tornadoes killed 10 people in southern Indiana in June. Hardest hit was Petersburg, a community of 3,000 people where six died and about two-thirds of the town's buildings were destroyed or severely damaged just two weeks after a flood. IOWA: The re-election of Gov. Terry Branstad and Sen. Tom Harkin, both of whom had begun the year facing what appeared to be strong challenges. Brandstad, a Republican, easily beat House Speaker Don Avenson, while Harkin, a Democrat, defeated Rep. Tom Tauke in a race that cost the candidates $11 million - the most ever in an Iowa election campaign. KANSAS: The upset victory in the governor's race by Joan Finney, the state treasurer who will become Kansas' first woman governor. She beat former Gov. John Carlin in the Democratic primary and then defeated Gov. Mike Hayden in the general election. KENTUCKY: The revamping of Kentucky's public school system, in response to a state Supreme Court ruling that the previous system was unconstitutional. The reform law set more equitable financing for school districts and created teacher-parent councils to set curricula and make other local decisions. A $1.3 billion tax increase, biggest in state history, was passed to help finance the reforms. LOUISIANA: The second-place finish of David Duke in the U.S. Senate race. Duke, a Republican state representative whom state and national party leaders repeatedly repudiated because of his past connections with the Ku Klux Klan and American Nazi Party, got 44 percent of the vote in a four-man race against incumbent Democrat Bennett Johnston, who got 54 percent. MAINE: The acquittal of a deer hunter who accidentally killed a woman in woods behind her suburban home. The case of Donald Rogerson, charged with manslaughter in the 1988 death of Karen Wood, focused unprecedented attention on the rights of hunters and non-hunters as the state's fields and woods give way to housin subdivisions. MASSACHUSETTS: The public unraveling of the Stuart murder case after Charles Stuart's fatal plunge from a bridge Jan. 4. Stuart received nationwide publicity after telling police a black mugger kidnapped, robbed and shot him and his wife, Carol. The truth did not become known until Stuart was implicated Jan. 3 by his brother in the fatal shooting of his wife, and he apparently committed suicide the next day. MICHIGAN: Republican state Sen. John Engler's upset victory in the governor's race with two-term, Democratic incumbent James Blanchard. Blanchard was hit with negative publicity when he dropped his two-term running mate, Martha Griffiths, from the ticket, saying she was too old. MINNESOTA: The turbulent gubernatorial campaign that ended with the election of late-comer Arne Carlson. Jon Grunseth had defeated Carlson in the Republican primary, but Grunseth was forced to withdraw from the race nine days before the election after allegations of sexual impropriety. Carlson was named the new nominee and defeated three-term Democratic incumbent Rudy Perpich. MINNESOTA: The turbulent gubernatorial campaign that ended with the election of late-comer Arne Carlson. DOC.HEAD: You Probably Recognize the Voice, But Not the Person Behind It
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Joan Kenley sometimes talks to herself, but that's understandable. After all, millions of people listen to her. Among other things, Kenley is the ubiquitous voice of Voice Mail, Pacific Bell's computerized answering service that more businesses are turning to instead of human operators. She might also tell you how much to drop in a pay phone. When you pick up the phone at a hotel, Kenley could be on the other end. She's the voice of Guest Messenger, a Sheraton Hotel chain service similar to Voice Mail. Or you might hear her rattling off the prices at computerized grocery store checkout counters. ``I guess I have made hundreds of thousands of them,'' said Kenley, whose voice is becoming familiar to even more people. PacBell in October brought the Voice Mail service to home phones under the name ``The Message Center.'' ``I'm even the English-speaking voice on pay phones in Japan,'' said Kenley, who is also the voice on software designer Northern Telecom's Meridian Mail and the interstate long distance voice for several companies, including Michigan and Ohio Bell. ``I think people who work with my voice would be sick of it, but they actually love it,'' said Kenley, who lives in Oakland. One reason her voice is so popular is that the melody ``tends not to go away'' and so allows sound technicians to mix old tapes with new ones, Kenley said in an interview. If there is a criticism of her voice, it's that ``it's too real.'' ``People can easily start talking to it, but that's a compliment as well.'' She even does it herself. Kenley said she was checking into a hotel recently ``and when I picked up the house phone I ended up talking to myself. It's kind of spooky.'' Kenley has done price-voicing for 50 grocery store chains. The automated service sounds out the cost of an item when it is passed over the checkout machine. ``My uncle in Cleveland was leaving a checkout where I say `thank you' and he answered, `You're welcome, Joan,''' she said. Kenley's career includes voice coaching and acting, with guest parts in shows that have ranged from ``The Honeymooners'' to a revival of ``Call Me Madam'' with Ethel Merman. She is also a voice-over artist who has narrated ads for several leading corporations, including Coca-Cola Co. and General Motors Corp.'s Chevrolet division. But don't get the idea that Kenley is just another pretty voice. She earned a Ph.D in psychology and is the author of ``Voice Power,'' an $18.95 hardcover described by the publisher, Aslan Publishing of Boulder Creek, Calif., as ``a breakthrough method to enhance your speaking voice.'' Kenley said her big break came 10 years ago when she was contacted by University of California professor Forrest Mozer, who developed a way to put the human voice on a computer chip. Mozer felt the best way for humans to ``interface'' with computers would be vocally. ``He said he wanted a voice that was warm, but not too sexy,'' Kenley recalled. ``Now my voice is everywhere - elevators, airplanes, even talking alarm clocks.'' National Semiconductor Corp., a computer electronics company that pioneered the talking checkout counter, had high standards for its device. ``They wanted a voice that wasn't too perky or too saccharine or too monotonous,'' Kenley said. ``They didn't want a voice that was threatening, or that clerks would go crazy listening to.'' Kenley says her work is ``a kind of immortality.'' ``A hundred years from now, I'll be long gone. But my voice will still be going out into the stratosphere saying, `Two dollars and fifty cents, please.''' End Adv for Sunday, Dec 31

DOC.HEAD: War or Peace? That's What Waits for Congress on Thursday
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For the new Congress convening on Thursday, the questions of peace and war are waiting, with added urgency as the days dwindle toward the Jan. 15 for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Five months of intermittent debate and a dozen House and Senate hearings have produced no answers and scant guidance to define the role of the Democratic Congress in a crisis under Republican management. At this point, it's a crisis on hold for the holidays. At a quiet Capitol, recorded telephone messages report some offices closed until after the New Year. President Bush is at Camp David, Md., on an 11-day break. There's little traffic and less tension in the capital, even as reinforcements are deployed in the Persian Gulf and the Saudi Arabian desert, building to the troop strength that could deliver on the U.S. threat to take the offensive after mid-January. That's when the United Nations has authorized the use of force if necessary. According to the Democratic leaders of Congress, U.S. forces cannot be sent to fight without congressional approval. According to the Republican administration, Bush already has all the authority he needs to act. That debate will resume when Congress does. It won't be conclusive. The answer has been elusive for two centuries under a constitutional system that makes the president the commander in chief and empowers only Congress to declare war. There were demands during the fall that Congress be summoned back to declare war. There were calls for a resolution of approval for Bush's policy of threatening military action against Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. There were proposals to invoke the creaky machinery of the war powers system, under which a president can't send troops into danger unless Congress approves. None of that happened, and none of it is likely to happen now. But in one form or another, the 102nd Congress is going to have to come to clear, majority decisions on the Persian Gulf, possibly but not necessarily on direct questions of policy, certainly on the money and manpower to back up that policy. The administration will need a supplemental appropriation of up to $20 billion early this year to finance Operation Desert Shield. Call-up authority for some support units summoned to active duty will begin expiring in March unless Congress extends it or Bush declares a national emergency. And there may have to be action later in the year to change the timetable for cutbacks that are supposed to reduce active duty military forces by at least 80,000 before next Sept. 30. An attempt to write a policy resolution and get it through House and Senate would be risky for both Congress and the White House. Bush has been quoted as telling members of Congress that he would welcome a resolution of support, along the lines of the United Nations resolution authorizing force after Jan. 15, but ``if you're going to debate this for months and not reach a conclusion and argue about it, then that may not be helpful ... '' Resolutions endorsing his policy were adopted by overwhelming votes in the House and Senate early in October, backing ``continued action by the president ... to deter Iraqi aggression and protect American lives and vital interests.'' But the authors of those measures said they covered only what had been done to that point, and did not authorize the use of force. When those measures passed, the strategy for forcing Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait was built around economic sanctions against Iraq, with the United States assigned to defend Saudi Arabia against any attack by Saddam Hussein's forces. On Nov. 8, Bush ordered U.S. forces doubled, to create the capability and raise the possibility of military action to retake Kuwait. Democratic leaders were told of the decision shortly before Bush announced it. And support that had been almost unanimous began to fray, with Democrats urging patience, to give economic sanctions more time to work. But Democrats can't risk becoming the party of dissent while American forces are at risk. That could weaken the U.S. position in the current confrontation, at a time when Bush says the best way to avoid war is to convince Saddam Hussein that he faces war unless he relents. And it could do them lasting political damage. Vice President Dan Quayle produced a preview of a Republican counterattack, saying earlier this month that ``patience at any price'' would amount to appeasement of Saddam Hussein. As the debate resumes, Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, says whatever the differences on timing and tactics, the United States is united on the goal of getting Iraq out of Kuwait. The question is how. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Dotting the West With Sheep-Guarding Dogs
LaserPhoto, Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: In a sunlit New England meadow, Kolya stretches out among his sheep for a snooze. Even in dozy repose, he investigates anyone approaching the flock. And when eyes meet, there is little doubt who's in charge - it's the Shar Planinetz, a huge, lion-like dog with majestic blue mane bred to protect the flocks in the mountains of Yugoslavia from wolves. Kolya is one of the first of the breed to be used successfully against coyotes by a pair of Hampshire College biologists. Nearly 15 years after Ray and Lorna Coppinger began experimenting with rare breeds from remote corners of Europe, thousands of the big dogs are watching over flocks in the American West. And like good shepherds, the Coppingers are keeping an eye on the big, deceptively placid breeds. ``They are still the best non-lethal method we've got to protect sheep against coyotes and other predators on the open range,'' Coppinger said. ``We thought we'd place out and follow 100 dogs and that would be the end of the research, but we're up to 1,221 now and still at it,'' Mrs. Coppinger said. ``The sheep producers wouldn't let us stop.'' She estimates that with offspring of dogs and the work of other groups, there are 4,000 to 5,000 guard dogs protecting flocks. ``They are an answer to all of us,'' said Sandy Petersen, a rancher in Sidney, Mont., who leaves her two guard dogs alone with her flock of 350 purebred sheep. ``They eat a lot, but it's nothing compared to the cost of losing the lambs to coyotes and you don't have to get involved in poison. They keep us in business.'' Initially skeptical, the U.S. Department of Agriculture is now promoting sheep-guarding dogs with pamphlets and videos. In some areas of the West, the dogs have significantly changed the way ranchers manage flocks, said Tom MacDonald of the American Sheep Producers Association. They are particularly effective on desert range, where a pair of dogs can protect 1,000 ewes, he said. Some Colorado ranchers have told the association their losses have been cut from 450 sheep a year to a dozen or so. And not just from coyotes. At the Coppingers' farm recently a student was training a pair of beguiling, white Maremma pups headed for the area around Yellowstone Park, where ranchers are nervous about plans to reintroduce wolves. In a test in Minnesota, a single dog kept a small wolf pack from a bait station for 30 nights, until the wolves finally combined forces to drive off the dog, Coppinger said. ``We put him back the next night with a second dog and it went back to a standoff,'' he said. Despite nightly confrontations, the two dogs deterred the wolves until the experiment was ended 30 nights later. Typically, the dogs chase away, rather than kill. ``One of the primary aims of any predator is to keep itself healthy, because it can't hunt for food when it's hurt. So they will back off in the face of the threat of likely harm,'' Mrs. Coppinger said. Supported by a newly created association of guard dog users, Mrs. Coppinger is compiling a computerized registry of dogs on American farms and ranches, their working characteristics and blood lines. Although some crossbreeds have been successful, and the Tibetan mastiff also is used, most of the sheep-guarding dogs in the United States are European breeds. Some, such as the Great Pyrenees from the mountains along the French-Spanish border and the Komondor and Kuvasz from Hungary, had also become popular as pets. But others - the Anatolian shepherd, the Akbash dog from Turkey, the Maremma from Italy, the Shar Planinetz of Yugoslavia and the Polish Tatra - were little known outside the sheep-raising areas of the Old World. The only American entry is a smaller strain, developed by the Navahos in Arizona to defend flocks against coyotes, Mrs. Coppinger said. Little research had been done linking dogs' personality traits to genetics when the Coppingers first began their studies in the 1970s. They found that through years of breeding, the guard dogs' psychological development had been arrested in the beguiling stage f puppyhood when little animals affectionately lick and touch their litter mates. They stay close to the nest and are suspicious of anything new, reacting to an intrusion with a panicked bark or snap. The dogs also lack good species recognition patterns and when raised with sheep or other animals are ``unclear about who or what is and isn't a dog,'' Coppinger said. ``They may think of sheep as dogs, or llamas as dogs or people as dogs.'' So a Shar Planinetz will lie down peacefully with its lambs but will stand menacingly between its flock and danger. ``They seem to be able to set up limits and lines that are not to be crossed,'' Mrs. Coppinger said. ``And once they have bonded with the sheep, that's really the only training they need to guard. '' Roger Woodruff, a researcher at the University of Oregon, and Jeffrey Green of the University of Idaho also began importing guard dogs in the 1970s in a separate program. Woodruff, now with the USDA, said their basic behavioral findings were similar. ``We were more oriented to immediate application and let it go after placing 60 dogs,'' he said. ``The Coppingers have done a lot of real in-depth behavioral and basic scientific research.'' The dogs only watch and protect; they won't herd sheep. ``They don't see sheep as prey as a border collie does, but as another dog,'' Coppinger said. ``You can't even get them to chase a ball. It's just not in their makeup.''

DOC.HEAD: Sports Physicians Say Hormone Opens Way to Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Physicians and scientists who consult sports groups on steroid use say a new male contraceptive opens the door to abuse by young athletes. A study done for the World Health Organization said weekly injections of 200 milligrams of testosterone enanthate were a ``safe, stable, effective and reversible'' contraceptive administered to males. But testosterone enanthate is an anabolic steroid banned by the governing bodies of most sports. The hormone adds muscle mass and strength to those who use it. ``Two-hundred milligrams will make me bigger and it will make any man bigger,'' said Charles Yesalis, a consultant to the NCAA, high schools and the National Football League Players Association. ``I can see guys saying, `You don't need to take the pill, honey. I'll gladly take these shots,''' Yesalis said. A Seattle researcher who directed a part of the WHO study said the dosage to induce infertility is too low to cause any problems, but conceded that many of the 157 men who completed the study reported weight gain. ``Some men who had been chronically underweight gained, and they liked that. It was muscle. It wasn't flabby fat,'' said Dr. C. Alvin Paulsen of the University of Washington Medical Center. Yesalis and Steve Courson, who played for the Pittsburgh Steelers and Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the National Football League, fear athletes will arrange to receive shots from several doctors a week. ``For many athletes, their sports are just as important as contraception,'' said Yesalis, a health and human development professor at Penn State University who in the 1980s studied steroid use among high school athletes. Courson, who started out using 35 milligrams of steroids a week and once was up to 1,300 milligrams weekly, said: ``You can get mighty big on 200 millgrams. It can be used as a performance enducer at that level.'' And if an athlete begins using steroids at too young an age, his muscles can outgrow his still-growing bones, Courson said. ``Kids aspire to be what the superstars are, so they try to use the drugs they perceive the athletes are using,'' he said. Courson was interviewed from a Pittsburgh hospital, awaiting a heart transplant for a degenerative heart disease. He said his doctors aren't sure whether his heavy steroid use contributed to his health problems. Testosterone occurs naturally, but is on the NCAA's list of banned substances with other anabolic, or strength-enducing, steroids. Players can lose eligibility if levels of the hormone are six times the level of epitestosterone. Steroid use also is banned by the International Olympic Committee and state and local high school sports federations. ``It opens the door to abuse because testosterone is the granddaddy of all the anabolic steroids,'' said Dr. Richard Strauss, a professor of medicine at Ohio State University and editor of the monthly journal Physician and Sportsmedicine. The WHO study was reported in a recent issue of the medical journal Lancet in London. The study said men had to be injected for an average of four months before enough hormone built up in their bodies to stop sperm production. Of the 157 men tested, only one fathered a child. After the injections were stopped, normal sperm production resumed in an average of 6.7 months, the report said. If the male contraceptive comes into wide use, and Strauss and Paulsen think it will, sports agencies either will have to change their rules to allow its use by athletes or tell athletes to use other methods while in competition. ``In the past, some asthma medications used were actually stimulants and athletes made the argument they needed to take them,'' Strauss said. ``They were told to use other medications.'' Frank Uryasz, the director of sports sciences and drug testing for the NCAA, said there now appears no way around the testosterone ban. ``To make exceptions in this area would create a tremendous loophole,'' he said. ``Right now, there are no legitimate uses,'' Uryasz said. ``If you have to use them (now), you're going to be so sick you're not going to be competing in intercollegiate athletics.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Vows To Search for Cure to Son's Rare Disease
DOC.TEXT: Lisa Livingston stands over her son's crib and strokes his hair as a lullaby plays softly in the background. It's nap time for Brett Livingston Seber. Except the little boy spends his life in a perpetual state of half sleep, the victim of a disease so rare that doctors knew almost nothing about it until a decade ago. Brett was born with 4-hydroxybutyric aciduria, a hereditary disease in which a missing enzyme in the brain causes severe brain damage and loss of muscle control. ``For reasons that we don't fully understand, missing this enzyme interferes with normal early brain growth and development,'' said Dr. Darryl De Vivo, chief of pediatric neurology at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. ``He really is kind of in a chronic stage of sleep.'' Fewer than two dozen children in the world have been diagnosed with the disease, De Vivo said. Brett, who just turned 4, has the most severe case of the disease ever seen, De Vivo said. At an age when he should be running, playing and learning new words, Brett lies motionless in a stainless steel crib with a feeding tube in his nose. Round-the-clock nurses monitor his every breath. He cannot move any part of his body without help except his eyelids. The disease has robbed him of his eyesight, although no one knows if he is totally blind. He has never spoken a word. He hasn't been outside in more than a year. His only response to the outside world is the soft humming sound he makes when his mother talks to him. Doctors don't know how to treat the disease. So few people suffer from it that they don't know the long-term prognosis - the oldest victim is now 6 years old - and little research is being done. Livingston, who is divorced from Brett's father, recently set out to change that. In November, she established a foundation to raise money for research into 4-hydroxybutyric aciduria and other rare childhood diseases. Her goal is to find a corporate sponsor to donate money for research. But for now, all she has is a post office box, and the dream of a cure. ``I will do anything humanly possible so tat no other child and parent have to go through this,'' she said. Livingston spends hours reading, singing and talking to Brett. Her 6-year-old daughter, Courtney, performs plays for her brother and scampers back and forth into his room. To an observer, Brett seems awake because his eyes are always open. In fact, his brain does not go through all the normal sleep cycles, and a nurse must give him a sedative so he can rest. Brett was born a seemingly normal child. The only hint that something was wrong was his inability to crawl, but doctors said he was just slow to develop because he was a big baby. When he was 11 months old, he slumped over in his high chair and fell into a coma. Livingston found topnotch pediatric neurologists at Columbia-Presbyterian. There she met De Vivo, who has since become an authority on Brett's disease. The medical bills have been in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, Livingston said. She has insurance, but that runs out in July and she is having trouble finding another carrier. ``I'm totally wiped out,'' said Livingston, a part-time elementary school teacher. She receives alimony from her former husband, and the Colleen Giblin Memorial Foundation, a private charity that provides money for research in pediatric neurology, also has helped. Livingston kicked off her own fund-raising effort at a local card and gift store, where the manager offered to put a jar on the counter to collect money. Within a week, more than $350 was deposited in the jar, said Lillian Tyska, manager of Miller's Hallmark Shop in Stamford. ``One man stood there and cried,'' Tyska said. ``And I said, `Are you related?' He said, `No, but this breaks my heart.''' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: The address of the Brett Livingston Seber Foundation is PO Box 1644, New Canaan, Conn. 06840.

DOC.HEAD: Pros Try Psychiatry for Sports Stress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version on sports wires as BC-Lifestyle Sports.
DOC.TEXT: It's tough being a major leaguer, what with the huge paychecks, fans who idolize you, and a job that lets you do what you've loved since you were a kid. You don't think that's tough? Then talk with Dr. Herndon P. Harding Jr., psychiatrist to the Los Angeles Dodgers. ``The degree of the pressure they experience is much more heightened than for most people,'' said Harding, who quit as director of Ohio's Department of Mental Health to become the Dodger organization's first psychiatrist. Not that being a Dodger is harmful to your mental health. Harding figures that if you can make it to the pros, you've probably learned to handle stress fairly well. But the way he sees it, counseling can make you even better. For instance, he said, a pitcher may concentrate on ``I gotta throw this fastball'' instead of ``I'm gonna burn this thing down the middle.'' The ``gotta'' is a negative thought that shows fear of failure - and, if you concentrate on failure, you'll find it, Harding said. On the other hand, he said, the ``gonna'' assumes you'll like doing it and encourages success. He and other experts say, however, that their focus is on more than improving concentration. They say relieving long-term problems from on and off the field can free an athlete to play his best. ``My role has been a preventative one, to see no talent's lost for psychological reasons,'' said Bruce C. Ogilvie, a professor emeritus at San Jose State University in California and a longtime sports psychologist. There are plenty of chances for talent to be lost. Those huge paychecks, for instance, can come with a mental-health deduction, said Dr. Richard G. Rappaport, a sports psychiatrist in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., a suburb of San Diego. ``Who's got the biggest income becomes the way they compete,'' Rappaport said. And, the experts say, competing is what athletes may do too much of, against their own goals or each other. Non-pros also may carry their own excess pressures, driving themselves constantly and never forgiving failure, but the pros do it in the public eye, Rappaport said. ``The requirements are so total and absolute,'' said Ogilvie. ``You really are denied a private existence, not permitted to have failures as a human being.'' A player who's losing playing time finds himself facing ``one of the most traumatic realities he has to confront,'' Ogilvie added. Without help, the athlete might turn to substance abuse, he said. And if a player succeeds, he can get the big head. ``Who's ever prepared for that sudden rush of exaltation?'' Ogilvie asked. It's no wonder that a lot of elite athletes seem to love themselves a lot, Harding said. They've been told how good they are since they were kids. By giving them breaks on everything from homework to chores, their supporters limit athletes' understanding of the real worl, Harding said. ``It's not their fault. They've been given this life and they don't know anything else.'' Star athletes also attract women, which can mean trouble for marriages - or, as Ogilvie put it, ``They have special problems in maintaining a primary relationship.'' Long, repeated road trips away from family create a loneliness that can make things worse, he said. The pressure can come to bear on performance, Harding said. ``That's the first line of intervention - to find out what's interfering with the specific performance - and then explore what kind of things might be occurring outside of playing the game.'' Long-term treatment might not be needed, but rather short-term therapy might do it, Rappaport said. A lot of athletes just lack the maturity to figure out where their lives are going, he said. ``I would try to reorient them, to look at things in perspective.''

DOC.HEAD: Realistic Resolutions To Eat Better in 1991
DOC.TEXT: Resolving to go on a diet is probably one of the most common resolutions any year, but doing it all at once is too hard for many people to sustain past the New Year's Day football game halftime. ``It's very difficult, particularly if you love good food,'' said chef Julia Child. But she and a few others who pay close attention to what Americans eat offered a few specific resolutions to make the task easier: - Jane Brody, author of ``Jane Brody's Good Food Gourmet'': ``Change one meal a week to be lower in fat, higher in fiber, and richer in the health-promoting complex carbohydrates, like potatoes, rice, pasta and beans.'' Every other week, she suggested, change one more meal. ``By the end of the year, you will have a far more nutritious diet and probably have lost a considerable amount of weight.'' - Bonnie Liebman, nutrition specialist, Center for Science in the Public Interest: ``Eat red meat no more three times a week.'' ``Use 1 percent or skim milk,'' rather than whole milk or 2 percent milk. ``Eat five to nine fruits or vegetables a day. People have heard, `Eat more vegetables,' since they were 2. It goes in one ear and out the other. But if people have a number, it helps.'' - Julia Child: ``Unfortunately, cocktails and wine and liquor add an awful lot of empty calories. So I think, when you're having a sparkling soda, put in some lime, pretend it's a cocktail. Put it in a nice stem glass and sit back.'' On toast, use marmelade instead of butter, she said. Butter has about 100 calories per tablespoon, around twice that of marmelade. ``Be conscious of everything you eat,'' she said. ``Eat a lot of filling things so you feel satisfied.'' - Ruth Lahmayer, registered dietitian from Atlanta and spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association: ``A lot of people cut out starches. I would encourage four to six starch servings a day, even if you're trying to lose weight,'' Lahmayer said. A serving, she said, is a half bagel, a slice of bread, or a half-cup pasta, rice or cereal. ``And the good old basic one is be sure to have a good breakfast every day, consisting of one to two starches, one fruit, either fresh or half-cup of juice, and one cup of low-fat yogurt or skim or low-fat milk,'' she said. Lahmayer also said to cut meat to two small protein servings a day, two to three ounces, which is about the size of a deck of cards or cassette tape case. - Katherine Eakin, editor of Cooking Light magazine: ``Don't say, `I'm never going to eat a specific food again.' Be realistic. Just say I'm going to eat less,'' she said. ``If you say never, you'll only want it more.'' Eat at home more often and cook more. ``If you're trying to eat a moderate, balanced and varied diet, if you have more control, you have more confidence,'' Eakin said. - Clark Wolf, New York restaurant consultant: ``I travel a lot and I eat a lot. It's my job to eat a lot. And I'm pushing 40 and am trying to keep in shape,'' Wolf said. ``My secret weapon is popcorn. I buy it in airports. I go into movie theaters and buy popcorn'' - without butter - even when he's not going to the movies. It tastes good and is filling, Wolf said. Eating some before a big dinner leaves him with a reasonable appetite, he said. ``The good news is in train stations and airports, they're serving popcorn,'' usually fresh and usually popped in vegetable oil, he said. And Wolf has a trick not available to most people: ``My other secret for keeping thin is I'm allergic to chocolate.''

DOC.HEAD: School Staff Should Be Trained for Emergencies, Panel Says
DOC.TEXT: At least two non-medical members of a school's staff should be trained to handle medical emergencies, a committee of pediatricians says. Training should include first aid, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and treatment of anaphylaxis, a serious allergic reaction, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on School Health. Trained staff members should be able to handle emergencies until the school nurse or physician or other emergency personnel can be reached, the committee says in the December issue of the journal Pediatrics. Emergencies related to athletics could be handled by a trainer or athletic staff member trained in sports medicine and emergency care, the committee suggested. ---
DOC.HEAD: Farmers Shouldn't Try To Eradicate Fire Ants, Just Manage Them
DOC.TEXT: There's no way to wipe out fire ants permanently, so it's more economic to work on keeping infestations manageable, a Texas entomologist says. ``We're still hoping for a magic bullet,'' said Bastiaan ``Bart'' Drees of Texas A&M University's agricultural extension service. He said the best hope for fire ant control appears to be in using fungi and insects that prey on fire ants in South America, the ants' original home. Florida researchers have patented one kind of South American fungi for use against fire ants, but it is likely to be years before enough organisms are available to keep down the numbers of fire ants, he said while in town to speak to the Entomological Society of America. When fire ants showed up in this country in the 1920s, farmers tried to wipe them out with chemicals, Drees said. DDT and similar chemicals kept the numbers down only temporarily, and killed or threatened many animals higher up the food chain. The chemicals also eradicated many of the native ants now recognized as the best defense against fire ants. ``They competed with fire ants for resources. And they mated with fire ant queens,'' he said. The safer pesticides now available offer only a one-year respite and are too expensive to spread on every field, he said. ``The cheapest chemicals are $10 per acre per year. That may not provide an economic return,'' said Drees. ``So ... the management goal becomes to solve the problems caused by ants without necessarily eliminating the fire ant from the ecosystem.'' Fire ants can be helpful, too, Drees said. ``The ants feed on pests that eat cotton - the boll weevil, the fleahopper, boll worms. They reduce the need for chemical treatment of those pests.'' And although fire ants attack calves during birth, they also eat pests that live on cattle, such as the lone star tick, horn flies, house flies and stable flies. ``Instead of treating a 600-acre cattle ranch, people are just treating the calving pasture,'' Drees said.

DOC.HEAD: A Roll of Those Who Departed in 1990
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS December section to change description of Armand Hammer's father to more accurate ``socialist,'' sted ``communist,'' and ADD entry for Nancy Cruzan.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: They trod a multitude of paths to make their contributions to our world, the paths of letters and the arts, of government and religion, of business and labor, of Hollywood and Broadway, of war and peace, of science and medicine, of law and the struggle for civil rights. For good or bad, they played their parts, and then were gone. Here is a roll of notables who died in 1990:
DOC.HEAD: JANUARY
DOC.TEXT: LAURENCE J. PETER, whose ``Peter Principle'' held that bureaucratic problems often occur because employees routinely are promoted beyond their level of competence. Age 70. ARTHUR J. GOLDBERG, who solidified a liberal majority on the Supreme Court in the early 1960s before reluctantly resigning to become U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. Age 81. MYLES F. HORTON, who in 1932 helped found the Highlander Folk School in Tennessee, often called the backbone of the civil rights movement for educating impoverished workers, labor leaders and activists. Age 84. BHAGWAN SHREE RAJNEESH, the Rolls-Royce guru who turned a central Oregon town into a tumultuous commune of free love, hedonism and alleged murder plots before being deported. Age 58, of heart failure. BARBARA STANWYCK, whose roles ranged from evil temptress in the film classic ``Double Indemnity'' to iron-willed matriarch of television's ``The Big Valley'' and won her three Emmys and an honorary Oscar. Age 82. AVA GARDNER, an Academy Award nominee who appeared in 60 movies and lived a Hollywood siren's life of fast cars, failed marriages and heated affairs but failed to find happiness in love. Age 67. LEWIS MUMFORD, a philosopher and critic who warned of the dehumanizing effect of technology. Best known for his studies of cities, culture and architecture, including ``The City in History.'' Age 94.

MICHAEL POWELL, innovative British film director whose 32 movies included ``The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp'' and ``The Red Shoes.'' Age 84. VICTOR LASKY, a journalist known for his vitriolic anti-communism. Helped write a Pultizer Prize-winning newspaper series on Communist infiltration of American institutions. Age 72. JOSE NAPOLEON DUARTE, the former president of El Salvador whose quest for democracy in a society ruled by the privileged few was thwarted by a disastrous civil war. Age 64. JAMES M. GAVIN, who served with the 82nd Airborne Division throughout World War II and at age 37 became one of the U.S. Army's youngest major generals ever. Age 82. MALCOLM FORBES, the colorful publisher of the business magazine that bears his family's name. An unabashed proponent of capitalism in all its forms who traveled the world by motorcycle, hot-air balloon and huge yacht. Age 70. JOHNNIE RAY, the '50s balladeer whose vocal histrionics blended rhythm and blues, country and gospel punctuated with real-sounding sobs. Credited by some with opening the door to music that evolved into rock 'n' roll. Age 63.

WALTER ORR ROBERTS, founder of the National Center for Atmospheric Research. Long before most other scientists, he predicted pollution and other environmental risks would become major issues in global politics. Age 74. BRUNO BETTELHEIM, a psychoanalyst who was a pioneer in working with emotionally disturbed children and who taught that violent fantasies and fairy tales were part of a healthy child's psychology. Age 86, suicide. GRAHAM A. MARTIN, who as the last U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam directed the chaotic evacuation of tens of thousands of Americans and Vietnamese from Saigon. Age 78. WALTER S. MACK, who rescued a largely unknown Pepsi-Cola Co. during the Depression and turned it into the country's No. 2 soft-drink maker. Age 94. AN WANG, a shy Chinese-born inventor with more than 40 patents who built a one-man shop above a Boston hardware store into a billion-dollar competitor in the world computer market. Age 70. RAY GOULDING, half of the Bob and Ray comedy team whose gentle satire on radio and TV featured such wacky characters as newsman Wally Ballou, the befuddled Mr. Science and Mary Backstage, Noble Wife. Age 68. ROY HALSTON FROWICK, the high-fashion designer Halston, known for his signature black-and-red attire, the Ultrasuede shirtdress and the pillbox hat worn by Jacqueline Kennedy at the 1961 presidential inauguration. Age 57, of AIDS-related cancer. HARRY BRIDGES, the labor leader who led San Francisco into a three-day general strike in 1934 and organized waterfront unions on the West Coast. Age 88.

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Months of Tragedy, Tumult, Achievement

DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of news events in 1990: --- JAN. 3 - Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Noriega surrenders to U.S. forces. JAN. 20 - Soviet troops storm restive capital of Azerbaijan republic, leaving dozens dead and wounded. JAN. 25 - Avianca airliner crashes on Long Island, killing 73. FEB. 2 - South African President F.W. De Klerk legalizes black nationalist African National Congress. FEB. 7 - Soviet Communist Party Central Committee votes to give up constitutional guarantee to power. FEB. 10 - U.S. space probe Galileo flies by Venus. FEB. 11 - South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela is freed after 27 years in prison. Buster Douglas knocks out heavyweight champion Mike Tyson. FEB. 15 - President Bush attends drug summit in Colombia. FEB. 26 - Violeta Chamorro upsets ruling Sandinistas in Nicaraguan presidential election; anti-Sandinista Contras later lay down arms, ending civil war. MARCH 2 - Greyhound's 6,300 bus drivers go on strike. MARCH 11 - Lithuania tries to assert independence from Soviet Union; other Soviet republics take similar steps in following months. Patricio Aylwin takes over presidency of Chile from Gen. Augusto Pinochet. MARCH 18 - Conservative alliance wins first free elections in East Germany. Thieves steal priceless art from Boston's Gardner Museum. Players-owners dispute that delayed baseball spring training is settled. MARCH 22 - Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood convicted of misdemeanor in Alaska oil spill. MARCH 25 - Arson fire in illegal nightclub in Bronx kills 87. APRIL 7 - At sea between Norway and Denmark, ferry Scandinavian Star catches fire, killing 158 people. John Poindexter, former White House security adviser, convicted of conspiracy in Iran-Contra case; is later sentenced to six months in prison. APRIL 8 - Conservative Democratic Forum wins Hungarian election, ending four decades of Communist rule. APRIL 22 - American hostage Robert Polhill released by pro-Iranian group in Lebanon. 20th Earth Day draws millions around globe. APRIL 24 - Shuttle carries Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Michael Milken pleads guilty in Wall Street fraud case, agrees to pay $600 million fine, and later is sentenced to 10 years in prison. APRIL 30 - American hostage Frank Reed released in Lebanon. MAY 16 - Van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' sold for record $82.5 million. MAY 29 - Boris Yeltsin wins presidency of Russian republic; he later quits Communist Party.

DOC.TEXT: Sales of existing homes showed a modest 3 percent increase in November, a real estate trade group said. Some analysts took the report as a possible harbinger of better days ahead for the slumping housing industry. The National Association of Realtors said Wednesday that sales of existing single-family homes last month posted their first increase since a 5.1 percent advance in August. Sales had fallen 9.4 percent in September and 3.8 percent in October, pushing the annual sales rate to its lowest level in almost six years. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Brokendown merger talks between TWA and Pan Am reached a standoff Wednesday as the two struggling airlines bickered over whether TWA should give Pan Am documents detailing its offer. In a letter to TWA Chairman Carl C. Icahn, a top Pan Am official said his company believes TWA is not willing to go through with its offer to pay an estimated $375 million for Pan Am. In response, Icahn wrote that the buyout offer stands as long as Pan Am does not go into bankruptcy. An aide to Icahn said TWA does not intend to give Pan Am the term sheet now. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Crude oil futures posted their biggest gains in three weeks, rising above $27 a barrel on increasing fears of a Middle East war. Oil market strategists said rising tension between the United States and Iraq since the U.S. market closed last Friday gave prices a boost. Light sweet crude oil for February delivery increased $1.30 to $27.22 per 42-gallon barrel on Wednesday. It was the biggest single-day gain since a $1.51 per barrel jump Dec. 4. ---

Orange juice futures prices spurted higher on the New York Cotton Exchange, reflecting worries that heavy frostdamage to the California orange crop will hurt juice supplies. The rally Wendesday marked the fifth straight trading day of gains for most orange juice futures. Extremely cold temperatures on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights damaged most of the California navel orange crop, the nation's main source of fresh oranges. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Despite some high-profile deals like the planned $7.4 billion buyout of MCA Inc., merger activity fell by nearly half this year as the U.S. takeover market cooled following the hectic pace of the 1980s. Merger activity fell 47 percent in 1990 to 4,486 deals valued at $199.9 billion from the 4,763 deals valued at $377.9 billion for all of 1989, Securities Data Co., a financial research firm based in Newark, N.J., reported Wednesday. The figures include deals announced during each year. The 1990 total includes Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s planned acquisition of MCA and the $6.2 billion stock-swap merger between GTE Corp. and Contel Corp. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A bankruptcy judge has barred the New York Stock Exchange from seeking a record $50 million fine from Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., saying the firm's securities law violations had been punished adequately. The ruling by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Francis Conrad means the stock exchange can't proceed with disciplinary action against Drexel related to the investment firm's 1989 guilty plea to six felony counts related to illegal trading. The NYSE had planned to seek $25 million each from the parent company and the securities subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Sales of beer, by far the most popular alcoholic beverage in the nation, are projected to rise 2.3 percent for a record 190 million barrels this year, a trade journal reported. As usual, Anheuser-Busch Inc., the world's largest brewer, leads the domestic market. With projected shipments of 84 million 31-gallon barrels this year, Budweiser and its A-B siblings will post 43.7 percent of market share, Impact, a wine, spirits and beer industries tracker, said Wednesday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Standard & Poor's Corp. and the Chicago Board Options Exchange said they had settled a lawsuit in which S&P charged the exchange with violating a 1983 licensing agreement. The two sides said Wednesday they had signed an agreement extending the CBOE's exclusive license to trade options on the S&P 500 Index and the S&P 100 Index, two important measures of stock market activity. S&P, a subsidiary of McGraw-Hill Inc., last minth charged the CBOE with wrongly asserting an exclusive right to use the indexes on financial products other than options contracts traded on the exchange. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., says he will remain as chairman of the Senate Banking Committee despite suggestions at home that he step aside in the wake of ethical questions raised in the savings and loan scandal. Riegle said he intends to convene hearings early next year on providing money for the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency selling off assets of defunct thrifts, and he has prepared legislation to rescue the government fund that guarantees bank customers' deposits. ---

The stock market rang up a moderate gain in slow trading Wednesday as traders straggled back from the Christmas holiday. The Dow Jones industrial average, down 12.37 points on Monday, climbed 15.84 to 2,637.13. The dollar drifted lower. Bond prices were higher. Orange juice futures prices were higher on frost fears; precious metal futures surged; livestock and meat futures were mostly higher; and grains and soybeans advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Deals in US Dropped By Nearly Half in 1990
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Despite some high-profile deals like the planned $7.4 billion buyout of MCA Inc., merger activity fell by nearly half this year as the U.S. takeover market cooled following the hectic pace of the 1980s. Merger activity fell 47 percent in 1990 to 4,486 deals valued at $199.9 billion from the 4,763 deals valued at $377.9 billion for all of 1989, Securities Data Co., a financial research firm based in Newark, N.J., reported Wednesday. The figures include deals announced during each year. The 1990 total includes Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.'s planned acquisition of MCA, the $6.2 billion stock-swap merger between GTE Corp. and Contel Corp. and Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s $3.6 billion hostile takeover of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. The planned MCA-Matsushita marriage - the most recent of the big deals - and American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s pending $6.1 billion hostile bid for NCR Corp. has led to some speculation that the merger boom of the mid-to-late 1980s might be reviving. However, said Bernard Black, a corporate finance professor at Columbia Law School, ``It's a mistake to assume that an overall trend has changed because there happens to be a couple of big deals announced.'' ``It's very hard to do a highly leveraged deal, and neither the Matsushita nor the AT&T deal is inconsistent with that,'' he said. ``They're both one big company buying another and there's no reason to think that kind of deal is going to disappear.'' Black referred to the scarcity of financing - particularly debt financing - that has slowed the merger business to a crawl over the past year. Mergers and takeovers peaked in late 1988 with the record $24.53 billion debt-financed takeover of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Activity declined early in 1989 and then skidded sharply after the failure of several big buyouts, most notably the $6.6 billion takeover of Federated Department Stores Inc. by Campeau Corp. The Federated deal foundered in September 1989 after Campeau was unable to meet payments on junk bonds used to finance that takeover and the earlier $3.6 billion buyout of Allied Stores Corp. The market for the risky high-yield bonds crashed after Campeau's troubles became known, and financing for mergers and acquisitions was suddenly hard to come by. Most of the mergers and buyouts done these days are known as strategic deals, undertaken by companies looking to expand or build market share. The MCA-Matsushita deal, GTE-Contel merger and the Georgia-Pacific-Great Northern takeover are all examples of such transactions. While this trend remains in place, Black predicted another kind of strategic deal would become more commonplace: mergers or buyouts involving companies in trouble because of the difficult economy and in need of help to compete. He pointed to the proposed merger between Trans World Airlines and Pan Am Corp. as a deal based on such concerns, and added, ``I'm sure we're going to see a whole lot of bank acquisition activity related to competitive pressures.'' On Friday, Pan Am said it was receptive toward a buyout offer from TWA that values Pan Am at about $375 million, but the two companies are haggling over an interim loan for Pan Am. Both are considered among the weakest U.S. airlines. While the U.S. merger market shrank considerably in 1990, Securities Data reported a boom in deals involving European firms. The company reported 667 transactions with European partners with a total value of $61.1 billion, up 109 percent from 717 deals worth $29.1 billion in 1989. But the surge was confined to the continent, the company said. Worldwide merger activity was down 31 percent this year, as 8,157 deals worth $441.6 billion were announced, compared with 8,822 transactions valued at $643.6 billion last year. In compiling its figures, Securities Data said it considered mergers, acquisitions, share repurchases, offers to exchange stock, spinoffs, self-tenders of stock, minority stake purchases and leveraged recapitalizations.
