DOC.HEAD: Pan Am, TWA Merger Talks Reach Standoff, Two Sides Bicker Over Documents
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (P) - Merger talks between Pan Am and TWA have broken down over Pan Am's request that TWA put details of its offer in writing. Executives of the struggling airlines exchanged letters Wednesday blaming each other for the standoff. Richard H. Francis, Pan Am chief financial officer, wrote to TWA Chairman Carl C. Icahn complaining that TWA has not provided a term sheet with details of its offer. ``If you wish to send us a term sheet spelling out in detail any TWA current proposal, ... we would be pleased to consider it and meet with you if it provides an acceptable basis for further discussion,'' Francis, wrote in the letter to Icahn Wednesday. TWA officials responded that Pan Am executives would have gotten the details if they hadn't called off a meeting scheduled for Monday. ``We're not going to give them the documents and have them go shop them around,'' Mark Buckstein, TWA general counsel, said in a telephone interview. ``Or quote portions of it out of context. We'll only go over it with them if they are serious.'' Buckstein said the details have been given to Pan Am orally. Icahn's letter responding to Francis said the buyout offer stands as long as Pan Am does not go into bankruptcy, sell assets for less than fair value, default on major debts or make similar moves. Icahn also raised the possibility that Pan Am may see an imminent bankruptcy filing and is concerned whether the offer would remain in place. He repeated his proposal to provide a bridge loan as long as TWA was classified as a debtor-in-possession, which would put the airline first in line for repayment if Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection. ``When you are ready to discuss that proposal, or the shareholder proposal ... we are ready to meet,'' Icahn wrote in his response to Francis. Icahn launched his offer for Pan Am Dec. 16 as he announced plans to sell all of TWA's London routes and some other assets to a healthier rival, American Airlines, in a package worth $625 million. Pan Am agreed to sell key London routes and other assets to UAL subsidiary United Airlines in a $400 million deal. That deal has been held up as U.S. and British officials negotiate over whether United will be able to use London's Heathrow Airport, as Pan Am does, or be switched to the less-desirable Gatwick. UAL officials have said the deal depends on approval to use Heathrow.

DOC.HEAD: Day-After Shoppers Getting Ready For Next Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Cut-rate ornaments, Christmas cards and other Yule paraphernalia attracted the affections of shoppers, but retail analysts were skeptical that an after Christmas buying spree would rescue the season. ``Cards half price, wrapping half price; the bargains are good. It's all for next Christmas,'' shopper Sandy Runte said as she pushed her young son and a half-dozen bags in a stroller around the Grand Avenue Mall in Milwaukee. The day after Christmas historically is one of the busiest shopping days of the year and retailers are hoping a late surge that began just before the holiday will continue, boosting retail sales undercut by a slumping economy and worries over the Persian Gulf situation. A spot check of stores by AP staff around the country showed one of the biggest draws for shoppers on the first day after Christmas was in marked-down decorations. ``It's incredible. It's a shopping frenzy,'' said Liz Gillespie, marketing director at Park Plaza Mall in Little Rock, Ark. ``I mean, the stores are just jammed, especially the ones with seasonal products.'' Karen Moody, of New York, visiting family for the holidays, headed to Marshall Fields and Co. in downtown Chicago to buy cards and wrap for next year. ``I've never paid full price for my Christmas cards yet,'' Moody said. ``It's pandemonium up on the 6th floor (where seasonal items are sold). I was so glad to get out of there.'' ``We're bargain hunting for crystal,'' said Stacia Van Heuklon, of Rochester, Minn., visiting family in Indiana. She, her two brothers, two sisters and mother came to Chicago for an annual tradition. ``It's early Christmas shopping for next year. We do this every year. Everything is 50 percent off.'' Even for those stores that show gains of a few percentage points in sales over a year ago, those gains translate into declines when the effect of inflation is taken into account. For the first 11 months of the year, inflation at the retail level averaged 6.4 percent, government figures show. ``The cake was baked for this season in August and September. The ingredients for failure were there early on. This season was like a souffle that never rose,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of Fashion Network Report, in New York. ``It's been worse than disappointing. For major department stores, it's been a calamity. It's the worst year for major department stores since the Great Depression. They not only didn't meet last year's figures, they fell behind the rate of inflation,'' he said. ``Retailers used every trick in their bag and nothing seemed to work. The trick now will be, how big will the clearance sales in January be?'' ``Consumers were very tight with their dollars,'' said David A. Williamson, a retail analyst for the Advest Group Inc. ``Retailers had to be very promotional just to get customers into the stores, let alone buy stuff.'' On Wednesday, however, some retailers were encouraged by what they saw. ``The parking lot's packed and there are people in the store. It's generally one of the busier days of the year,'' said Julie Sertner, special events manager at the Macy's store in the Dallas Galleria.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Again, Stocks Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen for the sixth consecutive day today, and Tokyo share prices edged up. The dollar closed at 136.65 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's close of 136.25 yen. After opening at 136.75 yen, it ranged between 136.45 yen and 137.10 yen. Gaining 3.62 yen in six trading days, the dollar closed at its highest since Oct. 3, when it also closed at 136.65 yen. Spot trading totaled $6.02 billion, up from Wednesday's $2.85 billion. Currency dealers said importers were buying dollars for month-end settlements, and even small amounts of buying had an impact on the thin year-end market. The dollar has been pushed up recently by instability in the Soviet Union, as well as the Persian Gulf crisis, as investors look for a safe haven in dollar holdings. The dollar closed higher despite being sold later in the day on reports that Iraq had expressed willingness to talk with the United States, said Tomoko Hirai, a dealer at Citibank. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,940.70 points, up 53.14 points, or 0.22 percent, from its close on Wednesday at 23,887.56 points. The Nikkei average gained 119.68 points Wednesday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 330 million shares, up from 223.5 million shares Wednesday. The market's mood picked up after an overnight rise in share prices in New York, traders said. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 15.84 points, closing at 2,637.13 points Wednesday. ``Optimism about the new year is beginning to be reflected on the market,'' said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer at Nikko Securities. He said speculation that the Middle East situation may be heading toward a peaceful resolution also helped boost market sentiment. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 88.15 points from Wednesday's close of 87.96. Their yield fell to 7.040 percent from 7.080 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Orders For Durable Goods Fall More Than 10 Percent In November
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3, bgng: The decline, with 4 grafs to CORRECT layoff figures and include comment
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for ``big ticket'' durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in November to the lowest level in two and a half years, the government said today. The decline matched the post-1958 record for one month set in January of this year and indicates the recession most economists believe started this fall is deepening. The drop likely is a harbinger of further layoffs at manufacturing plants, where payrolls have hrunk by 800,000 jobs over the past two years - 200,000 in November alone. Order declines were widespread, but were biggest in the transportation and defense industries. ``It's a precipitous decline indicative of a U.S. economy that is ending 1990 on a very harsh note,'' said economist Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Co. ``I think the manufacturing sector right now is in the worst of the recession.'' Overall, orders for durable goods - items from bicycles to battleships expected to last three or more years - totaled a seasonally-adjusted $115.9 billion last month. That was the lowest since May 1988. Orders had risen 3.6 percent in October, but have been down in six of 11 months so far in 1990. Transportation orders fell 27.4 percent in November. That included a drop of 38.8 percent in aircraft and parts, more than offsetting October's 20.4 percent increase. Boeing Co. earlier reported new orders of $5.2 billion, down from $10.7 billion a month earlier. Automobile and parts orders also fell. Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders fell 3.5 percent to their lowest levels in two years after edging down 0.2 percent in October. New orders for defense equipment dropped 9.6 percent. Orders excluding defense were down 9.6 percent. Non-defense capital goods - a key barometer of business' investment in expansion and modernization - fell 16.4 percent in November. Only orders for non-electrical machinery - which includes computers - showed no decline. They were unchanged from October to November. Electrical machinery orders fell 7.6 percent and primary metals orders dropped 9.8 percent. The backlog of unfilled orders - a good indication of how busy factories will be in months ahead - dropped 1.1 percent to $497.5 billion. It was the largest one-month decline since November 1985. Shipments dropped 3.6 percent to $121.7 billion, the lowest level since last January.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Bars Pilots' ickout for One Week
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge temporarily has barred American Airlines pilots from staging sickouts and other job actions that would further delay and cancel flights. American's lawyers complained that sick leave, equipment-caused delays and other allegedly illegal acts had skyrocketed since American's contract with the Allied Pilots Association became eligible for renegotiation last Jan. 1. U.S. District Judge John McBryde on Wednesday issued the temporary retraining order and scheduled a hearing for next Thursday to devided whether it would be made permanent. Union officials declined comment until they study the ruling. Previously they have denied charges of a work slowdown in response to stalled contract negotiations. American's complaint alleged pilot actions that are illegal under the Railway Labor Act, the federal law governing airline labor contracts. The airline in its court complaint accused the pilots of ``capricious and excessive'' reporting of alleged equipment problems, increase sick leave, slow taxiing and other actions. American has accused the APA, which represents about 8,000 pilots, of staging a sickout to compel management to agree to pilots' contract terms. Airline officials said that pilot sick hours peaked at 28,082 for November, compared with 19,319 in November 1989. On Nov. 27, 386 American Airlines pilots were out sick, tying the company record, officials said. American said daily flight delays attributable to pilot actions have run as high as 215 on Dec. 19, compared with an average of 89 delays per day in 1989. Flight cancellations this month due to lack of pilots reached 194 Wednesday, American said. American said that since negotiations turned sour, the company has attributed to pilots 55 delays per 1,000 flights. In 1989, the average was 38.6 delays per 1,000 flights.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat, Corn Futures Slip, Soybeans Gain In Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and corn futures prices were fractionally lower while soybeans were mostly higher in quiet early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn opened lower after a weekly Agriculture Department report released late Wednesday showed lower-than-expected amounts of those commodities were inspected for export last week. Losses in wheat were tempered by forecasts for another blast of Arctic air this weekend in the Great Plains, renewing the threat of frost damage to the winter wheat crop. ``You won't really know how much winterkill there is until later in the year,'' said Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``The wheat seed that is used nowadays has become fairly resistant to these winter freezes,'' he said. Soybean export inspections were higher than expected, which lent light support to the soybean complex this morning. Cattle futures were mostly lower and pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .13 cent lower to .07 cent higher with February at 77.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent to .33 cent lower with January at 89.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .28 cent higher with February at 49 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .35 cent higher with February at 64.65 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Competitor Countries More Heavily Unionized than U.S., Economist Says
DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Most countries that compete successfully with the United States for trade have stronger labor unions than this country has, according to figures put together by an American economist. ``The U.S. has among the lowest unionization rates in the world today,'' wrote Thomas Karier, who teaches economics at Eastern Washington University in Cheney, Washington. ``It is especially difficult to argue that unions have impaired U.S. competitiveness when much stronger unions in Japan, Canada and West Germany seem to have had no such effect,'' Karier said. His study, ``Trade Deficits and Labor Unions,'' was done for the Economic Policy Institute. The group is financed by labor unions, foundations and corporations. Unions bargain for higher wages and better working conditions that raise the costs of production. Higher production costs raise the prices of products and make them less competitive with products from other countries. But Karier argues that Japan, Canada and what used to be West Germany - which together account for most of the U.S. trade deficit - are already high-wage countries. But Fariborz Ghadar, professor of business administration at George Washington University, found Karier's reasoning too simple. Competitiveness has to be judged over time and industry by industry, he said in an interview. ``The fact is, the industries where the United States is most competitive - biotechnology, aircraft, computers - are the least unionized,'' he said. ``If I were doing a study, I would start from there and try to find the relationships.'' At the Brookings Institution, Senior Fellow Robert Z. Lawrence also suggested that the approach to competitiveness should be broader, taking into account standards of living. Labor union strength in the United States has declined in recent years. Karier estimates that 18 percent of the U.S. workforce was unionized in 1985. The economist compared the United States in this regard with 13 of its leading competitors. Only Hong Kong with 15 percent and South Korea with 10 percent had lower unionization, according to figures Karier quoted from the CIA in its World Fact Book for 1987. Japan, which usually has the biggest surplus in trade with the United States, was quoted as 30 percent unionized, while West Germany was 34 percent and Canada was 31 percent. But Taiwan, another big competitor of the United States, was at the same level, 18 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Small Privatization to Begin in January
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia will begin to auction off small shops and state-owned businesses next month in its first round of privatizations, the state CTK news agency reported Thursday. The privatization is part of the government's program of economic reforms. It is designed to turn over to private hands some 130,000 small shops and enterprises. The first auctions are to be held on the last weekend in January in Prague, CTK said. Auctions will be held in two rounds, with the first accessible only to Czechoslovak citizens and those who left the country after 1948 when the Communists took over. Shops and enterprises unsold in the first round will be auctioned in the second, at which some foreigners will be allowed to bid. The privatization process is a key part of reforms aimed at transforming Czechoslovakia's centralized economy into a Western-style market system. Thousands of vendors across the country staged symbolic strikes in September demanding they be given first crack at buying the shops and a chance to pay up to half the price in installments spread over a seven-year period. However, a law approved in October did not grant preferential treatment to any potential buyers. CTK said the government would take at least a year to sell the 130,000 shops and enterprises at auction. Privatization of large industrial plants and the agricultural sector is expected to begin later in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Fall, Biggest Weekly Drop Since Persian Gulf Crisis Began
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline at the pumps has fallen nearly 9 cents a gallon since the week before Christmas, the biggest weekly drop in prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the American Automobile Association said Thursday. Self-serve unleaded cost $1.282 a gallon this week, an AAA survey of stations nationwide showed. That's 8.9 cents lower than the price on Dec. 18, and the lowest since a gallon of gas cost $1.273 on Sept. 5. Oil and gasoline prices have been volatile since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Persian Gulf countries produce a substantial portion of the world's crude oil, and any disruption of supplies likely would cause prices to soar. But prices have been moderating since mid-October on increased prospects for peace in the gulf. Oil buyers have also been worried about a glut of oil, because users have reduced consumption and oil-producers have accelerated their output to make up for the loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. AAA said prices also fell this week for higher grades of gasoline. The average price for a gallon of mid-grade unleaded was $1.368, down 9.8 cents from Dec. 18. The average price for a gallon of self-serve premium was $1.45, down 8 cents. The average price for self-serve regular gas was $1.287, down 7.4 cents. The AAA Fuel Gauge Report is based on a nationwide survey of stations conducted by Computer Petroleum Corp. of St. Paul, Minn. AAA is based in Orlando, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Agnos Signs Landmark VDT Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Agnos signing law; picks up in 3rd graf, Tom Hsieh. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Art Agnos today signed the nation's strictest law regulating video display terminal use by workers, despite a political rival's last-minute charges that the ordinance is illegal. The law requires 15-minute breaks and other safety measures, including proper lighting, anti-glare screens and adjustable furniture and equipment for VDT users. Tom Hsieh, a city supervisor opposing the measure, charged Wednesday that the ordinance violates the city charter. But Jonathan Holtzman, special assistant in the city attorney's office, said it clearly does not. ``I am gravely concerned that the city is about to enact a law that is extremely vulnerable to legal challenge,'' said Hsieh. Hsieh said a section of the city charter mandates that supervisors can't make changes in working conditions for city employees until the city's civil service commission makes various studies. But Holtzman said the section cited by Hsieh applies only to changes in their pay. The law would take effect in 30 days. It applies to employees of private businesses and city workers. Agnos said Sunday that he would sign the ordinance after his staff, labor and businees officials reached agreement on compromises on certain provisions that gave businesses four years instead of two to comply. Opponents of the ordinance said the law would be so costly - an estimated $36 million to about $70 million citywide - that it could drive some business away.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Confidence Edges Lower in December
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence edged lower in December but Americans had a slightly more optimistic outlook for the economy in the next six months, the Conference Board reported Thursday. The business-supported research group said its consumer confidence index, compiled from a survey of consumers across the country, slipped to 61.3 from 61.7 in November. A year ago, the index stood at 113. The index inched lower earlier this year as the economy weakened and then plunged after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. It stood at 101.7 in July and fell to 84.7 in August. A lack of consumer confidence was cited consistently as the main reason for a drop in retail spending after the Middle East crisis began. Many retailers reported they had a difficult Christmas season as consumers shopped frugally. The Conference Board survey found consumers expect to remain very cautious in their spending. Of those questioned, 5.9 percent said they planned to buy a car, down from 6.5 percent in November and from more than 7 perct a year earlier. But the survey also found some easing in consumers' bleak outlook. While 26 percent of those surveyed said they expected business conditions to worsen over the next six months, that figure was down from 30 percent in November. There was more pessimism about unemployment, as nearly 33 percent of the respondents said jobs are hard to come by, up from 29 percent in November. The consumer confidence survey was conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, which questioned 5,000 households.

DOC.HEAD: Outlet Communications President Dies
DOC.TEXT: David E. Henderson, an executive with Outlet Communications Inc. for 18 years, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack at his East Greenwich home. Henderson, 62, became ill at home about 10 a.m. and was pronounced dead at Kent County Memorial Hospital in Warwick. Henderson has been chairman, president and chief executive officer of Outlet Communications since 1989, when he replaced the retiring Bruce G. Sundlun, now Rhode Island's governor-elect. Outlet is the parent company of WJAR-TV in Providence and WCMH-TV in Columbus, Ohio. He spent 42 years in broadcasting, much of it with Group W Productions, a subsidiary of Westinghouse Broadcasting Co. While at Group W, he held executive sales and managerial positions at WBZ-TV in Boston, KYW-TV in Philadelphia and WJZ-TV in Baltimore. He produced the ``Mike Douglas Show'' and David Frost programs while at Group W. He began his career as an announcer and director at WBAL-TV in Baltimore. Henderson had been active in community affairs in Providence, where he served on the boards of Trinity Repertory Company, the Rhode Island Public Expenditure Council and Roger Williams College. He also held a variety of posts in industry associations. Henderson is survived by his wife, Joan; daughter, Susan E. Henderson; and sons David E. Henderson, Jonathon C. Henderson and Jeffrey J. Henderson.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Weaken In Thin Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately lower Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing the previous day's gains amid profit-taking and reduced fears of cold-weather damage to the winter wheat crop. Trading volume was light as many players remained on holiday vacations. Wheat futures fell after a three-day rally, suggesting the winterkill fears that had driven prices higher were exaggerated, analysts said. ``The wheat seed that is used nowadays has become fairly resistant to these winter freezes,'' said Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Analyst Don Roose of U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines, Iowa, said soybean prices were pressured by expectations for heavy deliveries against the January contract on Monday, the first day for traders to attempt physical delivery of soybeans purchased for January delivery. The occasion is known as first notice day. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to 3} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2\ cents lower with March at $2.33 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1} cents lower with March at $1.13 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 5{ cents lower with January at $5.61} a bushel.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 7.92 points to 2,629.21 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, down \ at 30; General Electric, down [ at 57\, and General Motors, down ] at 34]. DOC.HEAD: Southwest Slashes Rates Between Phoenix, Seven Other Cities
DOC.TEXT: Southwest Airlines is cutting fares between Phoenix and seven other cities to $20, during what is traditionally a slow time of year for the airline industry. The $20 fares are good each way between Phoenix and Las Vegas, Albuquerque, El Paso, Los Angeles, San Diego, Oakland and Ontario, Calif. The tickets must be purchased before Jan. 21 for travel from Jan. 3 through April 5. Southwest is tying its promotion to a 20th anniversary celebration, but industry observers see it as a way to fill planes, grab some publicity and possibly force competitor America West Airlines to sell seats at money-losing prices. ``It's a slow time of year, and crazy things happen during slow times of the year,'' said Steve Litvin, president of USTS-Freedom Travel, a travel agency in Phoenix. Don Valentine, vice president of marketing for Dallas-based Southwest, said the airline was using Phoenix as a test market for the $20 fares. He said he expected the promotion to increase business on the routes and attract new customers. America West spokesman Dick Shimizu said his airline was studying Southwest's move and ``will remain competitive.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Market Continues To Weaken
DOC.TEXT: The labor market continues to weaken, judged by the volume of help-wanted advertisements in newspapers around the country, the Conference Board reported Thursday. The Board said ad volume declined last month in all nine major regions, with the Pacific, East North Central and Middle Atlantic regions posting the steepest drops. The Board's Help-Wanted Advertising Index stood at 108 in November, down from 116 the previous month and a sharp 35 points below the year-ago level. The seasonally adjusted index registered 100 in 1967. ``The labor market has been weakening for the last six months, and it may be another six months before it turns around,'' said Conference Board Economist Ken Goldstein. But he said the news ``sounds bleaker than it really is. Want-ad volume is unlikely to lose another one-fifth of its total of the next six months. In fact, we could see signs of a turnaround ... six months from now, and maybe even sooner.'' A survey of help-wanted ads in 51 newspapers nationwide revealed that labor conditions in oil-producing states have held up better than anywhere else, the Board said. Still, the regions reported ad declines of between 10.8 percent for the Pacific region to a drop of 1.9 percent in the Mountain region. Want-ad volume has proven to be sensitive to labor market conditions. The Labor Department reported the nation's unemployment rate registered 5.9 percent in November.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market's Nerve Center Tries To Reduce Vulnerability
With AM-Stock Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The stock market's nervous system is a bank of computers in a downtown building that officials are duplicating at another site to avoid accident-induced shutdowns. Little known outside Wall Street, the Securities Industry Automation Corp. was formed in 1972 by the New York and American stock exchanges after the markets no longer could handle the trading paperwork load manually. A transformer fire Thursday at SIAC delayed the start of trading at the NYSE and Amex by 90 minutes, pointing out the precarious nature of the nation's increasingly complex, interwoven and technology-driven financial markets. SIAC is a two-acre mass of 15 major computer systems with about 300 processors. SIAC processes the stock quotations from the nation's major exchanges, produces the consolidated tape of prices and provides support for all computer systems that power the exchanges. All systems on the trading floors at the NYSE and Amex are run through the SIAC system, including trading and clearance and settlement of trades. In addition, SIAC also ties together data on securities listed on the nation's regional exchanges and over-the-counter market, though those trading systems can operate independently of SIAC. ``We're basically the industry processor for the U.S.A.'s stock exchanges,'' said Richard E. Leyh, SIAC's executive vice president and chief operations officer. ``Outside, the world sees the exchanges. They don't necessarily see us standing behind the exchanges.'' Thursday's fire was caused by a transformer explosion shortly after midnight. None of SIAC's computers were damaged, but fire officials closed off the building while checking for chemical contamination. It was the second fire at SIAC in 13 months. In November 1989, the NYSE and Amex were shut down for one hour by an electrical fire. In both instances, the lack of an off-site backup system meant delays in restoring normal trading operations. SIAC - which is two-thirds owned by the NYSE and one-third by the Amex - is moving its base of operations to a new facility across New York harbor in Brooklyn deigned to avoid unforeseen shutdowns. SIAC is shifting about half its computers to the new location and designing the system so that in the event of a failure at one site, the other site could be reconfigured handle the full processing load. The new facility is expected to be fully operational by mid-1992, Leyh said. ``Our goal is that in the event of a catastrophic failure we would be back in business within a day,'' he said. ``In lesser events we would be back sooner.'' The Brooklyn and Manhattan systems will operate on separate power and telephone grids served by different electric company substations to minimize the possibility of both systems going down because of an outage. In the 1989 fire, in a basement electrical vault, SIAC was forced to switch to backup generators. Delays were caused because some of SIAC's older computers needed 30 minutes or more to be activated on the backup system. Most of the older models were replaced this year, Leyh said. While the outages have illustrated the financial system's vulnerability, some market experts said short shutdowns shouldn't be cause for alarm. ``Technology brings a price,'' said William J. Breen, a finance professor at Northwestern University's Kellogg Graduate School of Management. ``There are snowstorms, power lines come down, the Federal Reserve has to fiddle with the money supply because an airport got closed,'' he said. ``I would doubt if there's a whole lot of people who got hurt by the market not opening for an hour and a half this morning.''

DOC.HEAD: Yields on New Notes Fall
DOC.TEXT: Yields on four-year Treasury notes fell in Thursday's auction to the lowest level in a year. The average yield was 7.66 percent, down from 8.53 percent at the last auction on Sept. 26. It was the lowest rate since four-year notes averaged 7.65 percent on Dec. 20, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 7| percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,988.10. A total of $8.57 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $22.5 billion.

For release Monday, Dec. 31, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: IBM Makes Comeback After Slashing Costs, Revamping Products
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: A few years ago, some experts feared that IBM, one of the nation's most important companies, had slipped into a dangerous slump. Its products were outdated and overpriced, and its payroll and cost structure too bloated to deal with a slowdown in computer industry sales, these critics said. Instead of its sales growing 15 percent or better a year as IBM predicted, annual growth averaged less than half that from 1984-89. IBM's profit fell from $6.6 billion in 1985 to $3.8 billion in 1989, and its stock price slipped from as high as $173 a share in 1987 to a low of $93 a share in December 1989. The downturn was troubling not just because International Business Machines Corp. is the nation's fourth-largest industrial company, but because IBM's health is a benchmark for the U.S. economy and its technical prowess. Some said IBM - which employs more people than live in Minneapolis - was too big and bureaucratic to change. But in the past year or so, the world's largest computer company appears to have executed a neat turnaround. Its profit and stock price are on the rebound, its product lineup has been revitalized and thousands of unneeded employees are gone. IBM also has become more customer-oriented, helping dispel its reputation as an arrogant giant, industry analysts say. ``In the mid-80s, other (computer) companies started to do well. IBM was marking time,'' said Barry Bosak, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``Now, in 1990, IBM seems to be doing better in general than the computer industry. ``I'm impressed by the ability of IBM to make a good number of cutbacks and at the same time roll out what is a fairly extensive line of new computers,'' he added. IBM had been losing ground in the product area to nimbler, younger competitors. Compaq Computer Corp. lured away corporate customers for personal computers, while Sun Microsystems Inc. outshined IBM in the fast-growing computer workstation market. In 1990, IBM replaced its slow-selling workstations with machines that won critical praise and strong orders. It made a promising return to the home computer market, while selling off its low-tech typewriter business. Most important, it announced the biggest overhaul of its mainframe computers since the 1960s. Mainframes, the room-sized computers that store huge amounts of data for companies such as airlines, are IBM's most important business. The machines and associated equipment and services account for more than half of IBM's revenue and profit. Analysts say they generally are pleased with IBM's revamped products. Rick Martin of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. calls it the company's most competitive lineup since the early 1980s. Analysts also applaud the way IBM handled the transition to its new mainframe line, announced in September. Such transitions to a new generation of technology often disrupt orders while customers await the announcement. While IBM felt that lag, it was not as severe as some analysts expected. IBM is now ``shipping all we can build'' of the new mainframes, said Bill Grabe, an IBM marketing vice president. IBM needed the new machines to meet increased competition for its once-exclusive mainframe customers. Two U.S. companies that are partially Japanese-owned, Hitachi Data Systems Corp. and Amdahl Corp., offer competitive machines that are fully compatible with IBM models. IBM's mainframes also face competition from the No. 2 computer maker, Digital Equipment Corp., which began shipping its first mainframes in 1990. In the past few years, IBM also has increased its presence in software - an area of growing importance - by buying minority stakes in dozens of small software houses. These companies have developed programs that tailor IBM computers for specific industries. Under Chairman John Akers, who took charge in 1986, IBM reduced its worldwide payroll from a high of 407,000 that year to 383,000 at the end of 1989 through voluntary severance offers. The figure is a few thousand lower now, though the company hasn't disclosed the exact total. Under the most recent cutback, announced in December 1989, IBM said it would eliminate 10,000 U.S. workers. The company took a $2.4 billion charge against its 1989 profit to pay for the severance deals, resulting in the steep earnings drop that year. IBM also has reassigned workers from factory floors and headquarters to sales offices, where they are helping improve customer service and beef up orders. IBM's transformation began after the company reported a 27 percent drop in earnings in 1986, which it blamed in part on a downturn in the U.S. economy and the computer industry. ``We also did some real introspection and concluded that part of the problem was ours,'' said Frank A. Metz Jr., IBM's chief financial officer. That self-examination led to the recognition that IBM's overhead was too costly. Its payroll and plants were at a level that required annual revenue growth of 13 percent to 15 percent to turn a profit, while revenue actually was growing at about half that rate. IBM also decided it must ``re-emphasize our commitment to our customer,'' Metz said in a recent interview at the company's hilltop headquarters, about 25 miles north of New York City. ``We concluded that although our products were good, it was taking us far too long to get our products to the marketplace, and too often they weren't as responsive as they needed to be to our customer requirements,'' he said. That led IBM to loosen the centralized decision-making that had long been its hallmark. ``There are a lot of decisions made in this company today - important decisions, operational decisions - that we're not involved in here,'' Metz said. An association that represents IBM customers says it has noticed the company's new attitude. ``The openness has changed tremendously,'' said Merrikay Lee, secretary of Common, which represents users of IBM midrange computers. ``They used to listen but never really incorporated their customers into the fold. Now they're much more willing to talk and listen.'' Metz said the process of downsizing IBM will continue, though he doesn't expect another major restructuring. IBM's moves already have boosted its profit. For the first nine months of 1990, IBM earned $3.56 billion compared with $3.17 billion in the same period a year earlier. Analyst Cliff Friedman of Bear, Stearns & Co. predicts IBM will earn $10.20 a share for 1990, up from the $9.05 a share IBM earned in 1989 before the restructuring charge slashed profit to $6.47. IBM's improving fortunes have been reflected in its stock price, which has risen to about $113 a share. Although rejuvenated, IBM isn't out of the woods. One looming threat is the recession. Another is the increasing competition in the computer industry as its growth rate slows. In addition, IBM's profit could be squeezed by the increasing interest among computer uses for ``open'' systems, those that follow industry standards so that machines from differ makers can work together easily. Open-system computers have a lower profit margin than proprietary models such as IBM's mainframes and minicomputers. ``Over the long term, IBM's going to wind up losing market share,'' claimed analyst Stephen Cohen of SoundView Financial Group Inc. ``Industry (profit) margins are going to be declining because it's a maturing industry. I think IBM is going to face some very stiff competition.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv Monday, Dec. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Companies Sign Agreement With Soviets for Cellular Phones
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. communications companies, Millicom Inc. and U S West Inc., said Thursday they have signed an agreement to provide cellular telephone service in the Soviet Union, starting in Moscow. The companies signed the agreement with the Soviet Ministry of Communications last week, Millicom said. Also part of the pact is Dr. Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a Soviet eye surgeon and entrepreneur who helped negotiate the deal. The value of the agreement was not disclosed. The companies plan to provide cellular service in Moscow starting in the third quarter of 1991. The exact role of each partner has not been defined, said Millicom spokeswoman Andrea Van Raalte. The group would build one of two cellular phone systems envisioned for Moscow, Millicom said. The group would build systems in other Soviet cities subject to the negotiation of further agreements, it said. U S West and Millicom are the latest of a number of Western phone companies that have signed agreements to modernize phone systems in the former East bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson Family Radio Stations Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: The family of former President Lyndon Johnson has put the KLBJ radio stations on the market, a company executive said Thursday. John Barr, executive vice president of The LBJ Co., said the family has retained the Ted Hepburn Co. to entertain offers for the AM and FM stations. He said their value has been placed at $13.5 million. The Johnson family has owned the business for more than 40 years. The family tried to sell it in 1987 for $27.5 million, but the deal fell through when The Chase Group, a New York-based investment company, did not meet the deadline to complete the sale. Bill Jamar, whose Jamar and Associates handled the 1987 sales attempt, said it would be hard to get $13.5 million in today's economic climate. But Barr said, ``The stations are basically making money. They always have.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar settled mostly lower in extremely thin trading Thursday. Gold prices also were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 30 cents a troy ounce to settle at $385.30. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $384.40, up 20 cents an ounce. A report showing U.S. durable goods orders fell a steeper-than-expected 10.5 percent in November influenced trading. Analysts had been expecting a decline of about 2.2 percent, and the much larger drop fueled concerns that the U.S. recession is deepening. European markets, which had closed for the Christmas holidays, reopened Thursday to find traders mostly selling the dollar. Domestic trading was extremely light. ``We had about an hour's worth of trading after the durable goods numbers, and that was it for the whole day,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. Despite the weakness of the durable goods report, it was ``not enough to make people reopen their books and dump dollars before the New Year,'' said Michael Malpede, an analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. He noted that a good portion of the decline reflected auto plant shutdowns rather than declines in a variety of industries. The German mark was boosted by the confirmation of Gennady I. Yanayev as Soviet vice president. He was Mikhail S. Gorbachev's choice for the newly created office, and the approval offered an air of stability to the politically torn Soviet Union. ``The focus was on U.S. economic fundamentals, the Soviet Union and the Persian Gulf crisis,'' Malpede said. ``The dollar has been bouncing off that triad, with no clear direction in trading.'' In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 136.65 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 136.75 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 136.40 yen, up from 136.10 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8870, compared with $1.8740 late Monday. In New York, it cost $1.8895 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.8815. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5255 German marks, down from 1.5348; 1.3040 Swiss francs, down from 1.3082; 5.1935 French francs, down from 5.2080; 1,151.75 Italian lire, down from 1,155.00, and 1.1616 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1595. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5310 German marks, down from 1.5390; 1.3090 Swiss francs, down from 1.3120; 5.2050 French francs, down from 5.2200; 1.7292 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7345; 1,152.75 Italian lire, down from 1,158.00; and 1.1618 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1601. Gold was quoted at a late bid price of $382.25 per troy ounce in London, down from $383.00 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $382.20, down from $382.50 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped 11 cents an ounce to close at $384.07. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.093 a troy ounce, down slightly from Wednesday's $4.095. In London the metal traded at a bid price of $4.08 a troy ounce, up from $4.04 on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Disrupts Nationwide Stock Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Changes `natural' to `unforeseen' in lead; subs grafs 17-18 pvs to UPDATE with no PCB contamination found and that markets closed at normal time.
DOC.TEXT: A transformer explosion and fire in Lower Manhattan delayed stock trading nationwide for 90 minutes Thursday, a reminder that Wall Street's sophisticated computer systems are vulnerable to unforeseen calamities. The trading halt marked the third such disruption this year, but stock exchange representatives emphasized that none of the problems centered on their own computer operations. The fire at the 55 Water St. skyscraper in southern Manhattan broke out shortly after midnight, sending smoke into the Securities Industry Automation Corp., a joint venture between the New York and American stock exchanges controlling the computer system that supports trading. The New York and American exchanges were the first to announce that the usual 9:30 a.m. opening would be delayed. But the nation's regional stock exchanges also refrained from trading, bowing to a request from the Securities and Exchange Commission. SEC spokeswoman Mary McCue said the regulatory authority wanted all the markets to reopen at the same time to give all investors equal opportunity to buy or sell. Regional exchanges, which include the Midwest, Pacific, Cincinnati, Boston and Philadelphia exchanges, trade some of same stocks as the New York and American exchanges, but they handle only a small percentage of the total volume of stock traded on the major exchanges. Hundreds of workers milled about the chilly streets while others followed instructions on handwritten notes by the doors of the building and reported for work elsewhere. For example Citibank, the nation's biggest banking company which occupies several floors of the building, relocated employees to other offices in the city. Despite the upheaval in the streets, market observers said the fire did not cause too much of a problem for investors, since trading is typically thin during the Christmas-New Year's holiday week. ``Fortunately it happened at a time ... when there's very little to do,'' said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co., adding that most large institutional investors already have realigned their portfolios ahead of the new year and were not actively buying or selling stocks. Short-term traders and other professionals were the most affected. ``With the market closed for part of the day, they have a smaller arena in which to operate,'' Metz said. ``It amounts to an unprofitable day.'' Trading disruptions are relatively rare, but the Thursday delay was the third this year. On Nov. 23, a power failure delayed trading on the NYSE for 90 minutes shortly after the opening bell. On Aug. 13, a fire at a Con Edison power substation forced the American Stock Exchange, New York Mercantile Exchange and other futures markets in southern Manhattan to close by early afternoon, but the New York Stock Exchange was unaffected. More than a year ago, another fire-related power problem at SIAC briefly delayed NYSE trading. ``I'm surprised there isn't some failure-proof source of power,'' Metz said. NYSE spokeswoman Sharon Gamsin said in the next 12 to 14 months, SIAC will have a back-up facility across the East River in Brooklyn. The facility, located at what is called the MetroTech complex, will allow SIAC to switch to an alternative computing source, which can process 500 million trades a day, in case of a fire or other emergency. Though the blaze was under control at 3:16 a.m., officials feared hazardous polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, may have contaminated several floors of the 54-floor skyscraper. Samples of the building were taken to an Environmental Protection Agency lab for analysis, but the building was later found to be untainted by the cancer-causing substance. SIAC was allowed to enter the building at midmorning, and its computers were up and running by 11 a.m., when the New York and American stock exchanges opened trading. The markets closed at the normal 4 p.m. time. Trading in over-the-counter issues began as usual at 9:30 a.m. Over-the-counter stock trading is conducted independently of the NYSE and the American exchange. The National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System, or NASDAQ, reports quotes for over-the-counter stocks. Twenty-six firefighters and 14 others were treated for possible exposure to PCBs as a result of the fire, said Lt. Jim Powell, a New York City Fire Department spokesman. Four firefighters were hospitalized.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Drop As Winterkill Fears Ease
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices fell Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing most of the market's recent gains amid reduced fears of weather damage to the Great Plains winter wheat crop. Other grain and soybean futures also retreated. On other commodity markets, crude oil futures dropped; precious metals were little changed; orange juice futures slipped; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower. Volume was light in most markets as many traders remained out on holiday vacations. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 3} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March down 3} cents at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents lower with March at $2.33 a bushel; oats were } cent to 1} cents lower with March at $1.13 a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 5\ cents lower with January at $5.61} a bushel. The sell-off wiped out most of the 5.5-cent gain that March wheat racked up in the three previous trading sessions on speculation that several days of bitterly cold weather had caused significant damage to winter wheat. Analysts said the downturn suggested the winterkill fears were exaggerated. ``The feeling that there was a lot of damage done has started to be dispelled,'' said Don Roose of U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines, Iowa. ``The wheat seed that is used nowadays has become fairly resistant to these winter freezes,'' said Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. ``You won't really know how much winterkill there is until later in the year.'' Roose said soybean prices were pressured by expectations for heavy deliveries against the January contract on Monday, the first opportunity for traders to attempt physical delivery of soybeans purchased for January delivery. The occasion is known as first notice day. Crude oil futures ended modestly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a day of erratic trading that reflected mixed news from the Middle East. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventories report said U.S. crude oil stocks rose by 3.3 million barrels last week, a greater increase than most analysts had expected. A 960,000-barrel decline in gasoline stocks and a 1.2 million-barrel drop in heating oil stocks were within expectations. Light sweet crude oil settled 1 cent to 21 cents lower with February at $27.01 a barrel; heating oil was .38 cent lower to .17 cent higher with January at 80.88 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .16 cent to .50 cent higher with January at 68.64 cents a gallon; natural gas was 3.9 cents lower to 1 cent higher with February at $1.96 per 1,000 cubic feet. Gold and silver futures, which have mainly shadowed the crude oil market since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, were little changed in light trading on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold settled 30 cents lower to 20 cents higher with December at $385.30 a troy ounce; silver was 0.2 cent to 0.5 cent lower with December at $4.093 a troy ounce. Orange juice futures fell moderately on the New York Cotton Exchange as profit-taking ended a five-day rally linked to the extensive frost damage sustained by the California orange crop. Frozen concentrated orange juice finished .40 cent to 1.6 cents lower with January at $1.165 a pound. Livestock futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on profit-taking and slow cash markets. Pork bellies fell sharply in response to lower fresh-belly prices and a weekly exchange report showing active movement of bellies into commercial freezers outside of Chicago. Live cattle finished unchanged to .32 cent lower with February at 77.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .02 cent higher with January at 89.20 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 48.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.48 cents to 1.93 cents lower with February at 62.87 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Fell By $1.1 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 533 money market mutual funds fell by $1.1 billion in the latest week to $427.90 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $1 billion rise in fund assets the previous week to a record $429.01 billion. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group originally reported fund assets rose $856.2 million to a record $428.86 billion but later revised it upward. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 267 general purpose funds fell $226.3 million to $150.41 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds fell $251.9 million to $166.02 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds fell $627.6 million to $111.47 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.16 percent from 7.17 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.21 percent from 7.23 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 51 days, down from 52 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 5.91 percent as of Wednesday from 5.95 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.04 percent from 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.26 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.32 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.35 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.41 percent; 7.48 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.54 percent; and 7.72 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 7.75 percent.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a moderate loss Thursday in a quiet session shortened by problems that resulted from an overnight transformer explosion in the financial district. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had risen 15.84 points on Wednesday, dropped 11.63 points to 2,625.50. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 598 up, 892 down and 514 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 102.90 million shares, against 78.73 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 128.88 million shares. The New York and American stock exchanges began trading at 11 a.m. EST, 90 minutes later than usual, after operations were restored at the Securities Industry Automation Corp. SIAC reports and records transactions that take place in issues listed on the NYSE and Amex. Once activity got going, analysts said it was hard to discern any clear-cut shifts in the mood among investors, even though interest rates fell in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose about $5 for each $1,000 in face value, reducing their yields to the 8.24 percent-8.26 percent range. Often at this time of year there is much excitement about the so-called January effect - a historical tendency for stocks in general, and smaller issues in particular, to rally once the pressure of December tax selling is lifted from the market. But interest in such phenomena apparently has been muted this winter by uncertainty over the direction of events in the Middle East. Losers among the blue chips included American Telephone & Telegraph, down [ at 30[; General Electric, down [ at 57\; Exxon, down { at 51\, and General Motors, down ] at 34]. Tiffany & Co. fell 2\ to 35 on top of a 4]-point loss Wednesday, when the company said its holiday sales in the United States came in below expectations. Bank stocks were also weak. J.P. Morgan dropped 2 to 44; BankAmerica } to 26{; First Chicago 1\ to 16{; Citicorp \ to 13; Chase Manhattan { to 10[, and Manufacturers Hanover ] to 22}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $18.82 billion, or 0.61 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.12 to 179.48. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.72 to 384.37, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.56 at 328.29. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.35 to 371.05. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 303.67, down 1.32.

Editors:
The government has delayed the release of the weekly money supply figures until Friday this week and next week due to the holidays.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Asks Federal Hearing on Pan Am, TWA London Route Sales
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines Thursday asked the U.S. Department of Transportation to hold a formal hearing on plans by Pan Am and TWA to sell trans-Atlantic air routes to the country's two largest airlines. Chicago-based UAL Corp., parent of United Airlines, agreed in October to buy most of Pan Am's London routes and other assets for $400 million. Fort Worth-based American said in mid-December it would buy TWA's routes to London and other overseas points for $445 million. The deals hinge on whether American and United will be allowed to serve London's Heathrow Airport. Britain has resisted American carriers' attempts to fly to Heathrow, forcing them to use less convenient Gatwick. Delta is concerned that it and other U.S. carriers will bear the burden of any concessions the U.S. government makes to get British support for the deals. ``The DOT should not approve these transactions until it knows what `price' must be paid to the British to obtain their approval,'' Delta said in its filing. The transfers ``are so massive that they raise fundamental policy issues affecting competition and market structure internationally and domestically,'' Delta Chairman and President Ronald W. Allen said. ``Never before has such an enormous restructuring of the international air travel market structure been proposed.'' Delta is seeking to add to its two U.S.-London routes. If the deals are completed, United and American would both serve London from Los Angeles and two New York-area airports - Kennedy and Newark. American also would fly between London and Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia, St. Louis and Baltimore, while United also would fly between London and Washington, San Francisco and Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Down in Slow Day; Gasoline Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, On the ..., to CORRECT contract month to February; ADDS 4 grafs after 14th graf, Natural gas ..., with American Petroleum Institute weekly figures.
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices fell slightly Thursday in extremely light trading that brokers attributed to little significant news from the Persian Gulf. Unleaded gasoline prices rallied on reports that refineries were cutting back production because of marginally reduced demand, traders said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude for February delivery fell 21 cents to $27.01 per 42-gallon barrel after rising $1.30 on Wednesday. Other contract months also fell. ``The market was trendless,'' said Christian Gohler, a trader with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Traders said a statement by Iraq that it was ready for ``serious and constructive'' dialogue on the Middle East crisis was offset by a denial it was launching a new peace initiative ahead of a United Nations deadline. The U.N. has given Iraq until Jan. 15 to withdraw from Kuwait, and has authorized the use of force after that date to evict Iraqi forces. Furthermore, President Bush said there had been no progress in efforts to work out a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Baghdad to discuss a peaceful situation to the gulf situation. The crude oil market ``is just drifting lower as the whole Jan. 15 date looks like it could be pushed back. That has had a calming effect on the market,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Crude oil prices have risen on the prospects of war since oil supplies likely would be curtailed during a war, increasing their value. Market professionals also said crude oil contracts were being sold in advance of the end of the month and the year as traders liquidate positions. Among refined products traded on the Mercantile Exchange, unleaded regular gasoline for January delivery rose .50 cent to 68.64 cents a gallon after a 1.90-cent rise Wednesday. Later months also were higher. Tagler said oil refineries reported they were reducing gasoline production because gasoline per barrel was selling for only slightly higher than crude oil, due to slightly lower demand. Lower production means less supplies, which pushes prices higher. Home heating oil futures fell 0.38 cent to 80.88 cents per gallon on contracts for January delivery after rising 2.32 cents on Wednesday. Traders attributed the drop to reports that cold weather would not last in the Northeast. Later months were mixed. Natural gas for February delivery was down 3.9 cents at $1.960 per 1,000 cubic feet. Later months were mostly higher. After the market closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the nation's crude oil inventories rose in the week ending Dec. 21 to 334.7 million barrels from 331.5 million barrels the previous week. But that was still down sharply from 342.0 million barrels a year ago. Crude oil imports rose in the week to 5.6 million barrels daily from 5.1 million barrels the previous week, API said. Imports were lower, though, than 6.2 million barrels daily a year ago. Among other products, API reported that distillate inventories, which include home heating oil, fell to 131.5 million barrels from 132.6 million barrels a week ago. But inventories were higher than 112.2 million barrels a year earlier. Gasoline inventories dropped to 223.7 million barrels from 224.6 million barrels a week ago, but were up from 221.7 million barrels a year earlier, API said.
